title: American Autobiography: A Bibliography
summary: A comprehensive bibliography providing access to over 5,000 American autobiographies published from 1945 through 1980.

title: Aaron, r-f
summary: In a low-key, conversational style, the author tells how he went from shortstop in one of the great Black barnstorming baseball teams to a major league hitter pushing Babe Ruth's career home run record. An afterword written by Bisher is added to the 1968 edition describing Aaron's life up to 1973.

title: As high as my heart: the Sammy Aaronson story
summary: The story of his fight against juvenile delinquency in New York's East Side and Brooklyn, where he set up gymnasiums and sports activities for boys.

title: The journey home: some words in defense of the American West
summary: Author and conservationist Abbey describes his discovery of the West, his passion for the land, and his efforts to preserve it from destruction by machines, land developers, and excessive population.

title: Adventures in the world of science
summary: An interesting record of his sixty years among international research scientists by a physicist who pioneered in solar energy and became affiliated with the Smithsonian in 1898, serving as its secretary from 1928 to 1944.

title: Watching the world go by
summary: Abbot tells of his lifelong career in newspaper journalism, from his early days in New Orleans, through Kansas City, Chicago, New York, and Boston. Politics fascinated him and most of his recollections concern the political conventions, elections, and maneuverings he observed and took part in.

title: Mister Abbott
summary: A successful showman writes about Broadway, his memories of friends and enemies among the celebrities of the entertainment world, including an honest appraisal of himself.

title: Memoir of the Rev. David Abeel, D.D.: late missionary to China
summary: The life of a Dutch Reformed missionary is told through extracts from his simple but formal journals and letters, which reveal his concern with the love of God and the salvation of the 'heathen souls.' Although plagued with ill health, Abeel nevertheless managed to travel to Greece, England, Europe, the Far East, and China, spreading the gospel.

title: The confessions of a hoaxer
summary: A professional prankster describes many of his best hoaxes (e.g., a fictitious Mrs. Yetta Bronstein who ran for President of the United States, a fake recording by a phony count that won Billboard's Pick of the Week), his unusual comic theory, and his motivation for living it.

title: Back roads and bicarbonate: the autobiography of an Arkansas country doctor
summary: Anecdotal recollections largely of the first half of his life. Beginning with post-Civil War rearing on a cotton plantation, he describes his education as a pharmacist and physician and his experience as part-time banker and farmer while he practiced medicine in rural Arkansas and Oklahoma.

title: Ghost of Bataan speaks
summary: An American soldier describes the fall of Bataan, the Death March, the events at Camp O'Donnell and Cabanatuan, and the sufferings of Filipino and American troops after they had made their hopeless stand in defense of Bataan and Corregidor.

title: The making of a woman cop
summary: Policewoman describes her development on the Washington, D.C. police force from a naive rookie to an experienced sergeant supervising male officers. She fights crime and sexism with intelligence, level-headedness, and good humor.

title: The education of Sonny Carson
summary: Growing up in Brooklyn, being sent to reformatory, serving in the Army, and going to college all contributed to Carson's education. Later he became involved with the activities of CORE but differed with some of their policies. He believes that Black people must control their own police system and educational system in order to control their own destinies in their own communities.

title: Bella! Ms. Abzug goes to Washington
summary: The cantankerous and feisty Abzug chronicles her first year in Congress as the representative from New York during the Nixon Administration. A champion of Blacks, women, the poor, and the young, she provides lively, if self-serving, anecdotal accounts of her struggles with the 'smug, incestuous, stagnant institution.'

title: Grapes from thorns
summary: This collection of articles, speeches, and letters assembled from 1950 until his death provide an engaging portrait of a compassionate, humane and witty statesman.

title: Morning and noon
summary: After a quiet New England boyhood followed by an interlude working on railroad construction in Ontario, Acheson went to Washington as law clerk to Supreme Court Justice Brandeis. There and in private practice he learned to profit from his association and to respect his fellow men. Later under FDR he became involved in great affairs of state.

title: Present at the creation: my years in the State Department
summary: As Assistant Secretary of State, Under Secretary of State, and Secretary of State, he focuses on foreign policy during World War II and the Cold War.

title: Sketches from life: of men I have known
summary: An analysis of his long career in the State Department, sharing personal views of remarkable colleagues.

title: A pathfinder: inventor, scientist, industrialist
summary: Details his journey through hardship to create groundbreaking products, including carborundum and colloidal graphite lubricants.

title: Twilight of the tenderfoot: a western memoir
summary: A contemporary narrative of frontier life by an Eastern poet detailing her experiences on a large cattle ranch in New Mexico.

title: Here lies the heart
summary: A thoughtful and exuberant account of her quest for a meaningful life as a writer.

title: My diary: August 30th to November 5th, 1874
summary: Records her family's cross-country trip in 1874, detailing transportation and social life.

title: Dinner at the White House
summary: Starts with a dinner at the White House in January 1942 and examines the relationship between Roosevelt and Churchill.

title: My America: 1928-1938
summary: Combines personal history with a social and political history of the U.S. and interprets communist and socialist movements.

title: The native's return; an American immigrant visits Yugoslavia and discovers his old country
summary: After emigrating to America, he returns to Yugoslavia and reflects on its beauty and deteriorating political situation.

title: Familiar letters of John Adams and his wife Abigail Adams, during the Revolution; with a memoir of Mrs. Adams
summary: Collection of letters that reveals the depth of feeling between the Adams during the Revolutionary struggle.

title: New letters of Abigail Adams, 1788-1801
summary: Describes Abigail Adams' life between 1789 and 1801, focusing on her letters during John's Vice-Presidency and Presidency.

title: Diary of Charles Francis Adams
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Unpublished journal detailing the life of the grandson and son of presidents.

title: The education of Henry Adams
summary: Analyzes his lifelong education and interprets American history from a personal and intellectual perspective.

title: Henry Adams and his friends; a collection of his unpublished letters
summary: Over 750 previously unpublished letters written to 100 different people, from 1858 to 1918, giving a rich and varied view of Adams' intellect and an unusual image of his warmth and compassion.

title: The selected letters of Henry Adams
summary: These letters have all been previously published and cover a period of 60 years, from his student letters from Germany in 1858 to the last year of his life, 1918.

title: From gags to riches
summary: Making it as a comic in New York, a narrative filled with quips, show business gossip, and name-dropping.

title: The God bit
summary: A comedian, author, and all-around show business personality tells anecdotes — some humorous, others serious — but all emphasizing the faith and belief in God which show people have.

title: Cindy and I: the real life adventures of Mr. and Mrs. Joey Adams
summary: A wise-cracking, anecdotal account of the first five years of the marriage of comedian Joey Adams and his wife, Cindy (nee Heller).

title: Adams-Jefferson letters: the complete correspondence between Thomas Jefferson and Abigail and John Adams
summary: An early project of the Institute of Early American History and Culture, this edition includes their complete correspondence.

title: Correspondence between John Adams and Mercy Warren
summary: A lively and sometimes bitter exchange between John Adams and poetess, playwright, and staunch anti-Federalist, Mercy Warren.

title: Diary and autobiography
summary: Adams' diaries include Vol. I: Diary 1755-1770; Vol. II: Diary 1771-1781; Vol. III: Diary 1782-1804, fragmentary diaries of Abigail Adams, Autobiography Part I, and Vol. IV: Autobiography Part II.

title: The earliest diary of John Adams: June 1753-April 1754; September 1758-January 1759
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: These fragments help to illuminate the mind and personality of the young John Adams.

title: The John Adams papers
summary: Selected letters, papers, and other documents arranged to show John Adams in various roles.

title: The papers of John Adams
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: This judicious selection includes letters, committee reports, polemical writings, and state papers detailing Adams' commitment to public service.

title: Diary of John Quincy Adams, 1794-1845: American diplomacy and political, social, and intellectual life from Washington to Polk
summary: A selection from a twelve-volume Memoirs traces a lifetime of public service in domestic and foreign affairs.

title: John Quincy Adams and American continental empire: letters, papers and speeches
summary: A selection of writings by the sixth U.S. president intended to reveal his mind and passions.

title: John Quincy Adams in Russia: comprising portions of the diary of John Quincy Adams from 1809-1814
summary: A reprint of Volume II of his memoirs, comprising the record of his experiences during his successful mission to the court of Czar Alexander I, beautifully written, eloquent in detail.

title: Wings on my tennis shoes
publisher: Sampson Low, Marston and Co., Ltd.
summary: The development of her career in tennis and her achievements as a professional player.

title: Letters of George Ade
summary: With keen observation tempered by humor, Ade wrote stories and fables populated with characters typical of his small-town Indiana background. His correspondence follows his progress from Chicago journalist to popular author and playwright and back to his Indiana homeland and the life of a gentleman farmer.

title: I have considered the days
summary: Adler writes with thoughtful eloquence of his distinguished career as a Middle Eastern scholar, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, and participation in many international educational, cultural, and religious symposia. A benevolent Jewishness pervades his orientation to the world.

title: Philosopher at large: an intellectual autobiography
summary: Adler discusses his career as a popularizer of philosophy, particularly under the aegis of Robert Hutchins at the University of Chicago. Adler has been instrumental in establishing the Great Books series, and in planning and producing the fifteenth edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica.

title: A house is not a home
summary: A madam explains her life as a prostitute and madam in New York City. The Roaring Twenties, the era's gangsters, problems with the law, and social stigma are all part of the narrative.

title: Memoirs of the life of John Adlum in the Revolutionary War
publisher: Caxton Club, for the William L. Clements Library Associates
summary: An engaging account of a young patriot's participation in the Revolutionary War. Adlum, a private, fought in the War when he was fifteen to seventeen years old. He witnessed the British capture of New York City in 1776 and was himself taken prisoner-of-war in 1776.

title: The last letter of James Agee to Father Flye
summary: Dated May 11, 1955, this last of a long series of his letters to Father Flye was found unmailed on the mantel of Agee's living room when Agee died.

title: Letters of James Agee to Father Flye
summary: Letters (1925-1955) from the writer to his friend and former teacher reveal the bond of understanding and the shared feelings between them.

title: My animals and me: an autobiographical story
summary: Pleasant memories of her childhood in rural Maryland, her first pets, her parents and sisters, and a warm happy life.

title: Where he stands: the life and convictions of Spiro T. Agnew
summary: A collection of statements articulating Agnew's conservative stand on civil rights, health and welfare, education, the Vietnam War, civil disobedience, and crime, compiled from speeches, press releases, and interviews, mostly in 1967 and 1968.

title: A proper job
summary: Born in England, Aherne acted in movies and on the stage there before coming to the United States and making his debut on Broadway (1931) and in American films (1933).

title: Ushant: an essay
summary: This book by a poet and author is an experimental autobiography. Written in third person, it is 'an interior monologue autobiography of a literary man.' It does not relate a sequence of physical events, but stresses the emotional and psychological life of the author in England.

title: A surgeon's fight to rebuild men: an autobiography
summary: Recollections of a long active life in surgery including descriptions of innovative techniques and world-wide recognition of his work.

title: Dear Grandson
summary: A letter to the author's 13-year-old grandson, in which the elder tells of his adventures in escaping from Russia to America; his self-education; his employment as singer, bellboy, salesman, cigar-maker, and partner in a chain of drug stores; and his admiration of the free enterprise system.

title: Odyssey of a desert prospector
summary: A wonderfully appealing story of prospecting, a lonely but richly rewarding life. As a neophyte, Albert learned by doing and by observing the old timers he met.

title: Letters of A. Bronson Alcott
summary: The first collection of all extant Alcott letters printed in full, this volume provides a valuable glimpse of nineteenth-century intellectual life as well as insight into the personal character of this man of letters, whose interests include education, women's rights, communal living, and philosophy.

title: Louisa May Alcott: her life, letters, and journals
summary: Letters and journal entries are arranged with commentary by the editor, following chronologically from a genealogy through the writing of Little Women to the last years. Includes entries from family acquaintances such as Emerson.

title: A hilltop on the Marne, being letters written June 3-September 8, 1914
summary: A polished, often witty and intelligent series of letters written by a New Englander living above the Marne in France at the beginning of World War I. An account of the quiet charm of the area, then the growing tension and the experience of being on the edge of a battlefield.

title: On the edge of the war zone, from the battle of the Marne to the entrance of the Stars and Stripes
summary: A continuation of the author's A Hilltop on the Marne, this volume contains the human details and domestic concerns of a small village situated along the Marne and near the battlefront up to the U.S. entry in the war.

title: Return to earth
summary: Astronaut Aldrin writes of the training, the trip to the moon, and the historic first walk on the moon with Neil Armstrong, the instant fame requiring difficult adjustment, and his resulting mental depression, treatment, and recovery.

title: Cavalry wife: diary of Eveline M. Alexander, 1866-1867
summary: This diary contains a good-natured account of the author's journey to join her husband at Ft. Smith, Arkansas, and of their travels with the cavalry throughout the territories of Texas, New Mexico, and Colorado.

title: Chromatography: an adventure in graduate school
summary: Alexander tells what it was like to be a graduate student at the University of Wisconsin in the late 1940's, doing doctoral research on chromatography to earn his Ph.D. in chemistry.

title: Pen and politics: the autobiography of a working writer
summary: Possessed by a compulsion to write, Alexander gave up teaching, steeplechasing, and a life of security in his father's insurance firm to try to make his way by writing magazine articles, novels, biographies, and eventually syndicated newspaper columns.

title: My love affair with music
summary: An author of books for children and adults writes of his passion for music, not as a professional but as an ordinary man addicted to the arts.

title: Israel and me: a behind-the-scenes look by a longtime U.S. Zionist leader and returned Israeli immigrant
publisher: Schenkman Publishing Co., Two Continents Publishing Group
summary: Alexander, a lawyer and active Zionist, focuses on the establishment of Israel as a nation and on his role in abetting the emerging country through his activities in B'nai B'rith and other American Zionistic organizations.

title: Tales of my life and family
summary: Alger, an engineer with General Electric Company for forty years, was instrumental in the adoption of the city manager government for Schenectady in the 1930's and charter government for Schenectady County in the 60's. The appendix includes speeches and papers by him and a list of patents, honors, books and articles.

title: A whaler & trader in the Arctic: 1895-1944: my life with the Bowhead
summary: Allen recounts his adventures throughout fifty years as a whaler and trader of whale ivory and sealskin in Barrow and other places in Alaska.

title: Born to lose, bound to win: an autobiography
summary: A poor Missouri farmer born again in the middle of the Depression, he became a successful preacher and evangelist for the Pentecostal Church.

title: Daddy's girl: a memoir
summary: Convinced that no one loved her except her father, Allen began an incestuous relationship with him at age eight, which she describes in graphic detail. Her personal life became more complicated until she found some release in her father's death.

title: To do justly
publisher: The Press of Western Reserve University
summary: She served as a common pleas judge, a justice of the Ohio Supreme Court, and a judge of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Her book describes growing up in Ohio and Utah, going to law school at Chicago University and New York University where she became involved in the woman's suffrage movement, returning to Ohio to set up her law practice, and becoming a judge.

title: Fred Allen's letters
summary: Known for his wit both offstage and on, comedian Allen reveals his sharp and zany humor in this selection from the thousands of letters he wrote to fans and friends in and out of show business.

title: Much ado about me
summary: He died before completing the book, which is a narrative of his boyhood in the Boston suburbs, his apprenticeship as a comedian, and his gradual success as a vaudeville performer, up to 1929.

title: Treadmill to oblivion
summary: A comedian describes the development and early days of radio comedy in New York and his part in the industry. The book contains excerpts from a number of the actual scripts used by Allen on the air.

title: Presidents who have known me
summary: Allen, under Franklin Roosevelt a commissioner of Washington, D.C., and a Truman appointee to the Reconstruction Finance Committee, offers a hilarious account of his years in business and politics, focusing on Eisenhower, Henry Wallace, Alben Barkley, Adlai Stevenson, as well as Roosevelt and his favorite, Harry Truman.

title: Life experience and gospel labors of the Rt. Rev. Richard Allen
summary: Born a slave to a prominent Quaker lawyer in Philadelphia, he became a Methodist minister. In 1787 he and other Negro Methodists withdrew from the Philadelphia Methodist Episcopal Church because of prevailing practices of racial discrimination. In 1816 the A.M.E. Church was formally organized, with Allen consecrated as its first bishop.

title: Mark it and strike it: an autobiography
summary: A critical review of his career as an entertainer on radio and television, with an interesting analysis on the subject of comedy.

title: Reaching for the sea
summary: Allin, a civil engineer and expert on port construction, tells about his extensive work at the ports of Houston, Stockton, San Francisco, The Dalles (Oregon), Miami, and Port Bhavnagar, India. He also describes his world travels, 1906-10, illustrated with many photographs.

title: Ambassador from the prairie; or, Allison wonderland
summary: The author, who started without private means or public influence, writes of his thirty-year career in the Foreign Service, beginning as a clerk and ending as ambassador. He was especially concerned with aspects of American foreign policy with respect to Asia.

title: The Arizona of Joseph Pratt Allyn: letters from a pioneer judge: observations and travels, 1863-1866
summary: Allyn, appointed to the first supreme court of the Arizona Territory, wrote these letters to his newspaper editor friend Charles Warner, recording his travels, information about settlements and outposts, mining operations, Indians, Arizona pioneers, and Mexicans. The letters reflect his faith and enthusiasm in Arizona's future as a great mining and ranching state.

title: From college to cow country
summary: A college graduate raised in Brooklyn, in 1906 he went to Colorado to become a rancher. A tenderfoot, then a cowboy, he started his own ranch in the high Rockies.

title: Deer Creek; the story of a golden childhood
summary: Describes the author's middle-class childhood in the 1880's, the strong influence of her Grandma May in rural Deer Creek, Pennsylvania, and of her father in his Brooklyn ministry at St. Ann's Episcopal Church. Ambivalence about being a lady, nostalgia for innocence, and respect for learned obedience to the rules of survival.

title: Stay of execution; a sort of memoir
summary: In 1971 he discovered he had a rare form of leukemia. His book describes his fear and understanding of the disease, his efforts to prepare for his death and yet to survive. He lived as a journalist, with a regular column in Newsweek.

title: To Marietta from Paris
summary: These letters were written during the fifteen-year period the author spent in Paris as the wife of Bill Patten, a Foreign Service reserve officer. She describes to her friend Marietta Tree her social life, her observations of people and politics, and her own well-considered opinions with style, wit, and intelligence.

title: A year at a time
summary: Emphasizing landmark ballgames, Walter 'Smokey' Alston describes his career as a baseball manager, moving up from the minor leagues, at 44, to a 23-year job with the Dodgers in Brooklyn and Los Angeles.

title: Momma: a start on all the untold stories
summary: A poet closely identified with the Women's Liberation Movement writes of love, motherhood, independence, freedom, and of the importance of learning to live with the paradox of love and independence.

title: Call of the cricket
summary: Harsh memoirs of a 'gentleman thief con man', from unhappy childhood (including sexual initiation by an aunt on the day of his bar mitzvah) to criminal adulthood. He was encouraged to write it all down by a former school-teacher cellmate at Folsom Prison.

title: Alvarez on Alvarez
summary: Alvarez looks back on 93 years as physician and son of a physician, researcher, and medical writer. His research on stomach and intestinal disorders at the Mayo Clinic frequently pointed up emotional causes as well as physiological ones, leading him to write books for lay persons on nervous disorders.

title: Incurable physician: an autobiography
summary: Because of his popular newspaper column he became known as 'America's family doctor,' a kindly man who cares about his patients. His book, like his column, also depicts him as an outspoken critic on many subjects, including Freud, psychoanalysis, conformity, and religion.

title: Light of Notre Dame
summary: Alvin uses 'The Lady of the Golden Dome of the University of Notre Dame' as the inspiration of his life and the motif of this book. He focuses on his career as a journalist in Chicago and a public relations man in Hollywood. He particularly enjoyed his stint as head of the News and Special Events of the NBC Pacific Division during World War II.

title: Mile high: the story of Lyle Alzado and the amazing Denver Broncos
summary: This account of a Denver Broncos football player emphasizes his rags-to-riches rise from a Brooklyn slum to Yankton College (South Dakota) to the 1978 Super Bowl (the Broncos lost to Dallas). It juxtaposes Alzado's enormous size (6'3', 260 pounds) and fierce behavior on the football field with his gentle treatment of his wife and his philanthropic endeavors for handicapped children.

title: If you don't weaken: the autobiography of Oscar Ameringer
summary: Ameringer narrates his activities as a lifelong socialist committed to devoting his full efforts to unionizing laborers, organizing strikes and political protests, publishing antiwar and various other Socialist statements. After studying art in Munich, Ameringer lived in Milwaukee, Louisiana, Texas, and Illinois, ever fighting the good fight.

title: Beyond theology: the autobiography of Edward Scribner Ames
summary: Ames, a professor of philosophy at Butler College (Indianapolis) and at the University of Chicago, interweaves a narrative of his childhood, education, and career with a spiritual autobiography and statement of his philosophical and theological views as a minister in the Disciples of Christ church. He favors 'practical' rather than doctrinaire faith and writes with thoughtful, articulate candor.

title: Oakes Ames: jottings of a Harvard botanist 1874-1950
summary: This collection of writings, diaries and letters portrays Ames as a botanist, a world authority on orchids, a teacher and administrator, a sportsman, a traveler, and a family man. His letters reveal his ardent devotion to his career and to his wife.

title: Vibrations: The adventures and musical times of David Amram
summary: The story of Amram's lifelong love of music, his education and experience with music from his first instrument — a Boy Scout bugle — to his tenure as composer in residence with the New York Philharmonic and the performance of his own compositions by major orchestras.

title: Outsider in the senate: Senator Clinton Anderson's memoirs
summary: Major events of the 1950's and 60's, enlivened with anecdotal material by the chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, the Senate Aeronautical and Space Sciences Committee, and the Senate Interior Committee.

title: From sunflowers to bluebonnets
summary: Anderson recalls her years as a school teacher, particularly the first years at a one-room country school in eastern Kansas and her last years in a larger school in a southern Texas town.

title: Miss Elizabeth: a memoir
summary: A fascinating memoir by Sherwood Anderson's wife (1922-27) written after he summarily dismissed her. During her marriage to Anderson she ran a bookstore in New York and knew many authors, whose personalities and idiosyncrasies she describes anecdotally.

title: Personal recollections of Captain Enoch Anderson
summary: Written to his nephew, these letters constitute a brief and sketchy record of military life in the Delaware regiment.

title: Main spark: Sparky Anderson and the Cincinnati Reds
summary: Anderson explains his philosophy as a three-time pennant winner, recounts experiences with notable players, and shares memorable games.

title: Notre Dame, Chicago Bears, and Hunk: football memoirs in highlight
summary: Anderson recounts his days as a football player for Notre Dame, his experiences as a coach at various universities, and his accounts of games.

title: The Anderson papers
summary: Anderson discusses the power of the press as an adversary to politicians and relates various political events.

title: Out without my rubbers: the memoirs of John Murray Anderson
summary: A theatrical director describes his productions in various settings and his interactions with famous individuals.

title: Pilgrim circuit rider
summary: A Congregational missionary shares her early life experiences and observations in rural America.

title: The fiery fountains
summary: A prominent member of art circles recounts her life experiences and friendship with Georgette Leblanc, including emotions tied to her friend's death.

title: My Lord, what a morning: an autobiography
summary: An inspiring story of the author's journey in the concert world amidst racial prejudice and personal determination.

title: Woman at work: the autobiography of Mary Anderson
summary: The life story of a working woman and her contributions to women's advancements through her career as a union organizer.

title: Dramatist in America: letters of Maxwell Anderson, 1912-1958
summary: In letters, Anderson reflects on his careers in various literary fields and his philosophies regarding theater.

title: The diary and journal of Richard Clough Anderson, Jr.: 1814-1826
summary: Anderson's diary provides insights on political and social issues during his time, along with personal and family reflections.

title: Letters
summary: The letters of this author span the years 1916-1944 and are addressed to friends, relatives, other writers, and publishers.

title: Return to Winesburg: selections from four years of writing for a country newspaper
publisher: The University of North Carolina Press
summary: Having achieved literary and social success after the publication of Winesburg, Ohio, Anderson sought to relive his youth in rural America.

title: Sherwood Anderson/Gertrude Stein: correspondence and personal essays
summary: A record of the unlikely literary friendship between Midwestern ex-businessman Anderson and sophisticated esthete Stein.

title: A story teller's story: a critical text
publisher: The Press of Case Western Reserve University
summary: Written at the height of his popularity, this work gives authenticity to Anderson's 'legends' — his impoverished childhood, his parents, and his revolt from business life.

title: Tar: a midwest childhood: a critical text
publisher: The Press of Case Western Reserve University
summary: A semi-fictional memoir of his pastoral, gently sad boyhood about growing up, his grief at his mother's death, and his acceptance of loss.

title: War-time journal of a Georgia girl, 1864-1865
summary: The diary of a young Southern woman reflects the rebel philosophy after the Civil War as she chronicles her adventures.

title: Memory pages of my life
summary: Her autobiography includes brief recollections of childhood, with a major focus on her career.

title: Memoirs of a poor relation; being the story of a post-war Southern girl and her battle with destiny
summary: Describes her post-Civil War childhood and her years as an art student in Washington in the 1890's.

title: Corner of Chicago
summary: A view of his experiences in Chicago writing and establishing a reputation.

title: An explorer comes home: further adventures of Roy Chapman Andrews
summary: A naturalist's look at the people and animals of his rural Connecticut home.

title: Under a lucky star: a lifetime of adventure
summary: Describes his expeditions and career through personal experiences, including years in China.

title: Dangerous voyages of Captain William Andrews
summary: The first of two diaries by Andrews detailing his transatlantic voyages.

title: I was the Nuremberg jailer
summary: N/A

title: Diary of Colonel Israel Angell: commanding the Second Rhode Island Continental Regiment during the American Revolution, 1778-1781
summary: Includes notes on his experience at the Battle of Brandywine and during the winter of Valley Forge.

title: Reminiscences of James Burrill Angell
summary: The story of a prominent educator and diplomat who served as president of the University of Vermont and the University of Michigan and was sent on diplomatic missions to China and the Ottoman Empire.

title: Gather together in my name
summary: The author has studied and taught dance, helped produce and star in plays, written for newspapers in Cairo and Ghana and for TV, and the theater. In this book she recalls experiences of her youth before she became a successful writer.

title: I know why the caged bird sings
summary: The life of a young Black girl who later studied dance, starred on the stage, and wrote for newspapers and television. Her story is a sensitive narrative of her gradual awareness of the realities of life, of prejudice, of cruelty, of ignorance, but also of love.

title: Singin' and swingin' and gettin' merry like Christmas
summary: In this third autobiographical volume, Angelou masterfully recreates her lean years as record shop clerk and B-girl, followed by her rapid ascent to cabaret singer and dancer and her subsequent role with the touring company of Porgy and Bess.

title: When I was a boy in Boston
summary: A collection of stories, several of which were published earlier in little magazines, of the author's boyhood.

title: A summer month; or, recollections of a visit to the falls of Niagara, and the lakes
summary: The account of a tour of upper New York and Canada and observations of scenery and people, the joys and the difficulties of travel in the early nineteenth century.

title: Ransom & gems: the DeLong Ruby story
summary: The author, a writer, was doing research in south Florida in 1965 on gem thefts when he discovered a clue that led him to the DeLong Ruby.

title: Bad boy of music
summary: A glib and brassy narrative by the composer of 'Ballet Mecanique' describing his life as a concert pianist and composer.

title: This is where I came in: the impromptu confessions of Edward Anthony
summary: An anecdotal narrative of the varied career of a writer — his Manhattan boyhood, his days as a cub reporter...

title: How to grow old disgracefully
summary: Traces author's career as artist-journalist; he became editor of Ballyhoo...

title: The ghost in my life
summary: The namesake and grandniece of the famous suffragist writes of a life made difficult by that heritage...

title: Youth in Acadie: reflections on Acadian life and culture in Southwest Louisiana
summary: Arceneaux provides a brief history of the 1604 French settlement of Acadie and explains how the Acadians migrated to Louisiana in 1763.

title: Bomber pilot: a memoir of World War II
summary: After a brief eulogy to the victims of World War II, this book glorifies patriotism, fighting for one's country, war, and being a man among men.

title: Exiles
summary: Arlen writes of his father, a celebrated novelist in the Twenties, his mother, and himself in a haunting quest of discovery.

title: Passage to Ararat
summary: Arlen set out on a journey to discover the heritage of his Armenian forebears.

title: Arsha's world and yours
summary: Arsha was an Armenian teenager living near Istanbul when World War I broke out and all Armenians were deported to the interior of Turkey. Arsha stowed paper, pencils and her Bible in a sack and kept a diary of her family's forced travels and struggles to survive...

title: Jay J. Armes, investigator
summary: Armes is to private investigation what Melvin Belli is to trial law. He describes his hyperactive, flamboyant life, and unorthodox, not always legal, methods of solving crimes...

title: My life with women: confessions of a domesticated male
summary: A prolific writer of spoofs and humorous books, articles, and poems, Armour here writes about himself, particularly about married life.

title: Cry Babel: the nightmare of aphasia and a courageous woman's struggle to rebuild her life
summary: At 46, Armstrong was afflicted with aphasia that reduced her from a prolific author and theology professor to the physical and linguistic level of an eighteen-month-old baby...

title: House with a hundred gates
summary: Armstrong tells of life with her author parents, Fulton and Grace Oursler, including estrangement when her mother's alcoholism became rampant and union when her father and then Armstrong converted to Catholicism...

title: Gloves, glory and God: an autobiography
summary: In novelistic form, this third-person autobiography describes a Black athlete's rise to become the world's lightweight champion boxer, followed by a slow decline and many injuries.

title: Louis Armstrong— a self-portrait: the interview
summary: The major portion of this interview was published in Life, April 15, 1966. In it the famous trumpeter tells anecdotes of his youth in New Orleans and his later success in Chicago and elsewhere.

title: Satchmo: my life in New Orleans
summary: A wizard with his horn, Armstrong here tells of his childhood, his start in music, the bumptious life in New Orleans, great bands, great musicians, and his break into the big time in Chicago.

title: Through troubled waters
summary: The story of a man and his three young children coping with the sudden death of their wife and mother.

title: It's a long way from Chester County
summary: His career as a country singer was solidly established by his recording of 'That's How Much I Love You' in 1946. It peaked, declined, and grew again by the mid-sixties...

title: Global mission
summary: Author describes his childhood in Pennsylvania, education at West Point, early years of flying, and detailed account of World War II...

title: A boundless privilege
summary: Harking back to the first twenty years of the twentieth century, the author examines the accelerated rate of change and its effects on the old simple life in the rural region of Rusk County, Texas.

title: Fair fights and foul: a dissenting lawyer's life
summary: Arnold's book reviews the cases and causes he has known and describes the legal, economic, and religious ideas which he accepted in his youth...

title: Voltaire and the cowboy: the letters of Thurman Arnold
summary: The detailed, precise, and witty biographical introduction is a fitting prelude to the extensive selection from 17,000 of Thurman Arnold's letters, written from 1910-1969...

title: Old Burnside
summary: With precise details and a homey nostalgia reminiscent of Wilder's Little House on the Prairie series, Arnow recreates her turn-of-the-century family life in Burnside, Kentucky...

title: Indian agent in New Mexico: the journal of Special Agent W.F.M. Amy
summary: Amy's journal records his visits (May-October, 1870) to various New Mexican Indian tribes — including Abiquiu, Apache, Navajo, and Ute. He knows and loves the Indians, provides much census data and many sensible recommendations.

title: Free enterprise
summary: This is an extensively detailed history of Aronson's founding and development of the Aronson Machine Company in Arcade, New York. Aronson regards his life as a Horatio Alger story and is proud of his mechanical ingenuity, honesty, and acumen as his business expanded, 1946-1969, to a multi-million-dollar enterprise.

title: The galloping Swede
summary: At fourteen, he had saved enough money to immigrate to America, and he kept traveling west until he reached Montana. There he worked as a rancher, established his own construction company, and eventually served as a two-term governor.

title: Broken hills: the story of Joe Arthur, cowpuncher and prospector, who struck it rich in Nevada
summary: Arthur told his wife this story of rough living in the turn-of-the-century American West, working on cattle ranches and prospecting for precious ores; she recorded it in the first person. Arthur 'struck it rich' at the Broken Hills (Nevada) lode.

title: Advantage Ashe
summary: Ashe was the first Black man to play in the white-dominated amateur tennis circuit. Trained by a Black coach, he played tournaments in the United States and Australia. At 22 he became the ranking amateur in the United States.

title: Incidents in the life of the Rev. J. Asher: pastor of Shiloh (coloured) Baptist Church, Philadelphia, U.S.
summary: Written and published to raise funds for his ministerial services, Asher's memoir is an account of personal indignities suffered in Northern states prior to the Civil War.

title: Actress: postcards from the road
summary: A harsh and sometimes vulgar account of Ashley's struggle with success, professional blacklisting, insecurity, and mental instability. A Tony Award-winning Broadway star at 23...

title: The West of William H. Ashley: the international struggle for the fur trade of the Missouri, the Rocky Mountains, and the Columbia, with explorations beyond the Continental Divide, recorded in the diaries and letters of William H. Ashley and his contemporaries
summary: A dominant figure in Western history who was also a Missouri politician and U.S. Congressman, Ashley left a diary that sheds light on fur trading and Western exploration during the early 1800's.

title: Many-colored toga: the diary of Henry Fountain Ashurst
summary: The diary (1910-1937) of one of Arizona's two first senators who served thirty years in the U.S. Senate and played a leading role in maintaining the independence of the judiciary through his chairmanship of the Committee on the Judiciary.

title: The Wallowas: coming of age in the wilderness
summary: Ashworth wrote this evocative account of his decade of mountaineering in the Wallowa Mountains of Oregon as a plea for ecological conservation and to show the progressive stages of his relationship to the wilderness.

title: In joy still felt: the autobiography of Isaac Asimov, 1954-1978
summary: This book is a continuation of Asimov's first autobiographical work, In Memory Yet Green. It describes simultaneous developments of the successful science fiction writer and a frustrated academic career.

title: Steps in time
summary: Astaire describes his years as a touring Vaudeville performer with his sister Adele in revues, musicals, and nightclubs. The narrative is infused with his love for his wife and children.

title: Patchwork child
summary: Because her father was a high-ranking Marine officer, she spent her childhood in several foreign countries from which she derived what she calls a patchwork of experience. Her book reflects the life of a socialite growing up in military and international settings, including China just before the revolution.

title: A life on film
summary: Her second autobiographical work focuses less on her personal problems and more on her life as an actress, stressing the tension, difficulties, and tedium of that world.

title: My story: an autobiography
summary: In the context of her film career, the book focuses on her struggle with and recovery from alcoholism.

title: The age of Jim Crow
summary: A Black leader writes of his life disciplined by hard work, by illness, by deprivation, but successful in gaining education, knowledge, and the satisfaction of helping in the struggle for racial equality and equal opportunities.

title: Child of Satan, child of God
summary: A member of Charles Manson's sex-and-drug oriented 'family' writes of the sordid events of her alienated life that culminated in the wanton murder of actress Sharon Tate. She became a fugitive from society and the law in her teens.

title: Intellectual tramp: the autobiography of a schoolteacher
summary: An anecdotal illustration of the author's definition of 'intellectual tramp' — a human being with considerable native intelligence who shifts from place to place as either necessity or opportunity may dictate.

title: Texas surgeon: an autobiography
summary: An ophthalmologist, internationally recognized for his work on glaucoma, devotes half the book to his early life and hard-earned medical education.

title: Wilmer Atkinson, an autobiography
summary: Atkinson was a journalist in Delaware who founded the Farm Journal and supported the Woman's Rights Movement and Women's Suffrage.

title: Along the Alcan
summary: Atwood, a carpenter from Minnesota, was a member of a construction crew that helped to build airports, hangers, line camps, and pumping stations along the Alcan Highway from Edmonton, Alberta, to Fairbanks, Alaska, throughout 1943.

title: A writer's capital
summary: A privileged life of private schools, travel, homes on Long Island and Bar Harbor furnished much of the background material for Auchincloss's novels.

title: Letters from Iceland
summary: A unique travel book written in the form of verse letters with interspersed prose commentaries.

title: Rap sheet: my life story
summary: An exciting cops-and-robbers tale from the robber's point of view. Audett ran away from home in Canada at thirteen and became involved in organized crime.

title: Audubon and his journals
summary: An unabridged edition of the journals of his travels and observations in Europe and North America by a famous naturalist.

title: Audubon's western journal: 1849-1850
summary: His daily journal is a sensitive depiction of the times, influenced by the painter's trained eye.

title: Red Auerbach: winning the hard way
summary: In twenty years as a professional basketball coach, aggressive, colorful Auerbach won more championships (nine with the Boston Celtics), coached more games (1585), and paid more fines ($17,000) than any other coach in professional sports. Here he discusses his players, his strategy, his feuds, and his philosophy of the game.

title: Funny men don't laugh
summary: Auerbach recalls five sober, tense years during the Depression when he worked as a gag writer for Lou Jacobs (pseud.), learning the craft superbly, as did his colleague, Herman Wouk. Their best known client was Fred Allen, 'a champion [whose] combination of style, viewpoint and wit' has never been duplicated. This is not a funny book.

title: Sad nun at Synanon
summary: She entered a convent at nineteen, taught elementary school, and then at 22 volunteered to work at Synanon, a rehabilitation center for drug addicts. Her book describes the shock and difficulty of that experience, coming to terms with social issues, adjustments in her personal life, and finally leaving the convent.

title: Literary America, 1903-1934: the Mary Austin letters
summary: Out of the 115 letters in this collection, only eight were written by Mary Austin. Editor Pearce supplies generous commentary and biographical background as well as a section of brief sketches of many of the literary figures who produced the letters contained. He makes frequent reference to Austin's autobiography, Earth Horizon.

title: Back in the saddle again
summary: Autry describes his discovery by Will Rogers as the 'singing cowboy,' his career in Western movies and television (particularly in the series Annie Oakley), and his experience in corporate management and politics.

title: Ten years in the saddle: his memoirs
summary: This highly detailed memoir discusses Averell's education at West Point (1851-55), from which he emerged as a cavalry officer sent to subdue the Indians in Arizona and New Mexico. He regarded these territories and Old Mexico as curiosities and presents a thorough description of their culture. At the outbreak of the Civil War Averell was designated commander of the Third Pennsylvania Cavalry, Union Army. The memoir breaks off after a description of the Battle of Bull Run and the Peninsula campaign in 1862, and is concluded with an editorial epilogue.

title: Ridge runner: the story of a Maine woodsman
summary: Colorful, well-written description of life in the Maine woods, warm relation to grandfather in early youth, later experience in logging camp and as a game warden from 1933-1946.

title: Diaries 1871-1882 of Samuel P. Avery, art dealer
summary: One of the founding fathers of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Avery is best remembered for having started the Metropolitan's art library. His diaries, five volumes of which are included here, record his purchases, itineraries, and observations from eleven years of collecting.

title: Florence Ayscough and Amy Lowell: correspondence of a friendship
summary: Letters from 8 December 1917 to 1 May 1926. Their friendship included an exchange of information about Chinese art and China, where Florence Ayscough lived for years.

title: Actions and reactions: an autobiography of Roger W. Babson
summary: A forthright, moralistic narrative based on a philosophy of common sense, ingenuity, and independence, describing his New England boyhood, his education, and his success as a statistician and founder of three colleges.

title: By myself
summary: With candor, integrity, and humor, Bacall describes her upbringing by a strong Jewish mother, her sudden film stardom, and romance with Humphrey Bogart, married and 25 years her senior. Despite improbable odds, their sixteen-year marriage which lasted until Bogie's death in 1957 was dominated by immense love and personal and professional integrity.

title: Journal of an itinerant artist
summary: Bacigalupa's journal is divided into twelve months, beginning in December ('the format of the liturgical calendar'), and is illustrated with striking woodcuts. He intersperses vignettes of his travels in Europe and Mexico with brief portraits of memorable people. His love for humanity and his own family is paramount.

title: Diary of Isaac Backus
summary: McLoughlin states of this enormous diary: it 'makes clear [Backus's] importance as a [Baptist] leader . . . The diary, covering the sixty-year span from the First to the Second Great Awakening, describes [Backus's] . . . campaigns for religious liberty ... It reveals his early struggles to fulfill his mission as pastor, . . . describes his work in consolidating the growing Baptist denomination, and discusses the situations that led him into theological controversies.' The diary also shows Backus as a family man, farmer, bookseller, ironmonger, and citizen of an emerging republic.

title: Rocks on the roof
summary: Television and film actor best known as the voice of Mr. Magoo and his wife, Henny, a sculptor, collaborate to tell amusing anecdotes about their sociable years in Hollywood.

title: Correspondence of John Badollet and Albert Gallatin, 1804-1836
summary: The letters exchanged between two friends, both Jefferson Republicans, who participated in the development of their adopted country.

title: Daybreak
summary: Reminiscences of her childhood and youth as well as incidents during her career and her work for non-violence and resistance.

title: From the tablets of my heart
summary: Crippled by polio at fourteen months of age, Bagby became a highly successful and inspiring minister.

title: Sidestepping the barbarians: glimpses of a real experience
summary: Reminiscences of life in the Japanese-occupied Philippine Islands.

title: Unfinished autobiography of Alice A. Bailey
summary: Occult teacher relates her transition from British socialite to believer in the Disciples of Christ.

title: Sold to the lady in the green hat
summary: Her book describes their gradual adaptation to New England, the development of a successful business, and a new life.

title: My summer in a Mormon village
summary: She spent the summer recording her impressions of the Mormon lifestyle.

title: The defense never rests
summary: Bailey describes some of the famous cases he was involved in.

title: The raw Pearl
summary: Pearl tells the story of her life and career with warmth and concern for people.

title: Talking to myself
summary: A second book of reminiscences about people, attitudes, emotions, and faith.

title: High tension: the recollections of Hugh Baillie
summary: The story of his forty years in journalism.

title: The autobiography of Waldron Baily
summary: Baily recounts his life history in North Carolina, adorned with poetry and a mixture of literary styles.

title: Polish circuit rider: the Texas memoirs of Adolf Bakanowski, 1866-70
summary: After four years serving as a missionary in Texas, he returned to Europe and then was reassigned to Chicago.

title: Stolen sweets
summary: Baker recounts his youthful escapades as a jewel thief and his eventual transition to working in the movies.

title: I had to know
summary: Accounts of her experiences with mysticism, serious illness, and her career as a successful journalist culminate in her conversion to Catholicism under Bishop Fulton J. Sheen's guidance.

title: Josephine
summary: Josephine Baker's memoirs were almost finished at the time of her death; narrative ellipses have been filled in by friends' recollections of her remarkable life.

title: Out on a limb
summary: A humorous account of coping with life with only one leg, even roller skating and horseback riding.

title: More adventures with David Grayson: adventures in understanding, adventures in solitude, and great possessions
summary: Previously published as separate volumes, this edition is a sequel to The Adventures of David Grayson which combined three earlier works.

title: Wheeling and dealing: confessions of a Capitol Hill operator
summary: Baker tells tales of corruption in Congress and of his close association with Senators Lyndon Johnson and Robert Kerr.

title: Fighting for life
summary: Dr. Baker spent her lifetime promoting hygiene, especially for children.

title: Move that mountain!
summary: Evangelist Bakker tells of his estrangement from God during his teenage years, his newfound faith after thinking he had killed a child in an automobile accident.

title: Ingenue among the lions: the letters of Emily Clark to Joseph Hergesheimer
summary: Emily Clark wrote these letters giving a daily account of the journal and the literary world of the Twenties.

title: Come North with me: an autobiography
summary: An aviator explorer describes his experience on famous expeditions with Richard E. Byrd.

title: Time and chance
summary: Newspaper sketch artist, illustrator, and author records early training and travels.

title: Of diamonds and diplomats
summary: The happy, exciting life of Baldridge, who was social secretary for ambassadors in Paris and at the White House.

title: Roman candle
summary: The story of a six-foot blond from Omaha whose dream was fulfilled when she became social secretary to Ambassador to Italy.

title: Billy Baldwin remembers
summary: For over forty years he was interior decorator for many of America's well-known celebrities.

title: Reliquiae Baldwinianae; selections from the correspondence of the late William Baldwin, M.D.
summary: Although his career as a botanist was relatively short, Baldwin collected over 3000 species from the coastal plain and the Piedmont.

title: My threescore years and ten: an autobiography
summary: A sculptor best known for his equestrian statue of George Washington in Boston's Public Garden and other heroic-sized statues documents his major commissions and describes his struggles to bring them to technical and expressive perfection, records methods of study and work, and offers advice to young artists based on the evolution of American art.

title: Melvin J. Ballard: crusader for righteousness
summary: Born to early Mormon-convert parents, Ballard became a Mormon missionary in South America and was elected to the First Presidency and Council of the Twelve of the Mormon Church. Two hundred pages of this book are devoted to his Mormon-oriented discourses on immortality, church leadership, tithing, motherhood, the resurrection, Temple work, and other matters of concern to Mormon Church members.

title: Autobiography of Adin Ballou, 1803-1890, containing an elaborate record and narrative of his life from infancy to old age with appendixes
summary: Called to the Christian ministry at age nineteen, Ballou spent his life preaching, teaching, and helping found the Hopedale Community in Massachusetts, a new social experiment, among other good works.

title: Glitter and the gold
summary: Her life as an American heiress, an English duchess, and the fond wife of a French colonel.

title: One reel a week
summary: A motion-picture pioneer who started with the Lubin Company in 1905, Balshofer became a producer; Miller, who writes alternate chapters, was a cameraman. Together they trace much early movie history and chronicle the development of movie-making machinery.

title: Scientist on the trail: travel letters, 1880-1881
summary: These travel letters were originally published in a Highland, Illinois, newspaper and describe the explorer-historian's experiences studying Indian pueblos in documents and by observation.

title: The Southwestern journals of Adolph F. Bandelier
publisher: The University of New Mexico Press
summary: Concerned with Bandelier's initial trip to the Southwest, the first volume, 1880-1882, shows his early interest in using a common archaeological-historical approach. The second volume follows his field work among the Pueblo Indians. The third volume continues his record of the anthropology, botany, folklore, geography, history, and culture of the Indians of the Southwest.

title: Tallulah: my autobiography
summary: An actress from Alabama describes her life and career as she traveled and lived in places such as London, New York, Hollywood, and Washington, DC, reminiscing about famous people she has known and discussing many rumors concerning her life.

title: Wing of scarlet
summary: Describes boyhood in Red Wing, Minnesota, homesteading in Lonesome Prairie, Montana (1911-1919), and later life in Cannon Falls, Minnesota; includes accounts of spiritual dreams and visions.

title: Albert Franklin Banta: Arizona pioneer
publisher: Historical Society of New Mexico Publications in History
summary: A colorful, adventure-laden account of one man's participation in the settling and taming of the Wild West.

title: A good time was had
summary: As an explorer and mining engineer he spent much of his time in Ecuador and other parts of South America, and was also closely associated with many artists and intellectuals of the New York scene.

title: The schoolhouse at Prairie View
summary: Recollections of his boyhood experience in a one-room schoolhouse in Kansas during the 1870's by a man who became an internationally known biologist specializing in malaria.

title: Show me the way to go home
summary: Red Barber, a seasoned sportscaster and a lay reader in the Episcopal Church, writes of his family and career, concentrating on his Christian faith and his activities as a lay reader.

title: A naturalist's scrapbook
summary: For many years Director of Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology, he writes with care and affection of his life, the museum, his friends, and colleagues.

title: The doctor wears three faces
summary: A blunt, earthy, humorous description of her life as a doctor's wife, with a poignant recognition of the life-death center in his work played against her desire to have more of his time for family life.

title: Forty odd
summary: Occasionally glib and flippant, the book describes a Nebraska woman's fear of passing forty, of losing her sexual attractiveness and sense of identity, and the way in which she comes to terms with the sense of loss and mortality.

title: Just be yourself
summary: A lively, pleasantly humorous account of a young mother's initiation and development as a Brownie troop leader in the Puget Sound region.

title: Portraits with backgrounds
summary: Before becoming an American citizen in the 1940's, Madam Barjansky wandered many European countries, creating portraits of the famous and unfamous.

title: Ramblings in the field of conservation
summary: Barker discusses his long career as director of the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish.

title: Missouri lawyer
summary: His life in the law from 1898, with anecdotes of prominent characters and legal matters.

title: The doctor has a family
summary: Anecdotes of family life containing humorous criticism of suburban mores.

title: I love my doctor
summary: Describes with humor the difficulties of early marriage and establishing her husband's medical practice.

title: That reminds me
summary: The politician recalls his political career and his association with various presidents.

title: I married the Veep
summary: The story of her courtship and marriage to Vice-President Alben Barkley.

title: Recollections of growing up in America's Southland and of 26 yrs. in Pre-Communist China: 1888-1936
summary: A well-written account of the author's development as a Christian missionary and of his 26 years in China.

title: Life in Custer's cavalry: diaries and letters 1867-1868
summary: This superbly edited collection of letters brings alive frontier fighting between the Plains Indians and the U.S. Cavalry.

title: Barnum's own story: the autobiography combined and condensed from the various editions published during his lifetime
summary: A reprint of the 1927 edition which condenses two volumes and various editions of Struggles and Triumphs.

title: Struggles and triumphs of P.T. Barnum: told by himself
summary: The great impresario recalls the highlights of his career as owner of 'The Greatest Show on Earth.'

title: Correspondence of Rev. Louis Baroux, Missionary Apostolic to Michigan, to Rev. M.J. DeNeve, Superior of the American College at Louvain
summary: Clergyman and missionary Baroux wrote this letter in 1862 to his superior in France to tell him how his efforts to Christianize the Pokagon and Potawatomi Indians in Michigan were going and how successful he was...

title: A shepherd without sheep
summary: An anecdotal account of how a 'strayed shepherd,' an ordained priest forbidden to take communion or exercise his priestly powers because of his earlier rebellion against the Church, can still remain in the fold.

title: Bowery to Bellevue: the story of New York's first woman ambulance surgeon
summary: From the perspective of retirement, the author recalls her internship at Gouverneur Hospital from 1902 to 1904, especially on ambulance duty, and combating antagonism from her colleagues because of her sex.

title: The natural bent: the memoirs of Dr. Paul B. Barringer
summary: Part I contains memories of childhood in Civil War and Reconstruction periods, with descriptions of hardships and shortages faced by Southern families; Part II contains an account of Barringer's education.

title: Bellevue is a state of mind
summary: An investigative report of a week spent in the violent ward of Bellevue; a grim account of the tragedy, despair, and hope of mental illness.

title: Forty years in Washington
summary: Starting as a page in the Senate in 1875, Barry recalls first-hand impressions of people and national and international events during his long tenure in Washington.

title: I'll be seeing you
summary: Blinded by a shell in World War II, a veteran describes his recuperation and training for a new civilian life.

title: Confessions of a basketball gypsy
summary: This story of his rise, fall, and re-entry into the world of sports superstars offers a view of basketball as big business and athletes as big businessmen.

title: Too much, too soon
summary: Written after her attempted suicide, the book tries to account for her turbulent life, beginning with her unhappy, chaotic childhood and adolescence.

title: All my sins remembered
summary: Life with John Barrymore was never dull but punctuated with his violent passion, mercurial temper, romantic interludes, bouts of alcoholism, jealousy and desire for domination.

title: Memories: an autobiography by Ethel Barrymore
summary: The story of her long and successful career as a prominent actress on stage and film, with details of her early life and theatrical family.

title: Confessions of an actor
summary: Dominated by the aura of theatrical egotism, the book is sparse in detail and includes nothing that resembles a confession.

title: We Barrymores
summary: Member of an extensive family of actors and actresses reminisces about his personal and professional life in theater and film.

title: I lost a thousand pounds
summary: A theater and night club entertainer writes to explain the childhood origins of his obesity and to illustrate the thesis that 'I've lost a thousand pounds in my time.'

title: The papers of Josiah Bartlert
summary: This volume consists primarily of letters to and from Bartlett, 1775-1795, revealing his political activities and personal insights.

title: My lifetime in sports
summary: A sports reporter and sports editor of the Minneapolis Tribune for fifty years reminisces about notable sports events and players, mostly in boxing, football, and baseball, and identifies some of his notable sports scoops.

title: Travels of William Bartram
summary: In 1773 Bartram set out for a trip in the South 'for the discovery of rare and useful productions of nature, chiefly in the vegetable kingdom.' His record is a major source of information on early American geography, anthropology, and natural history noting the characteristics of rivers, plants, fish, reptiles, birds, and Indian civilization and customs in the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida.

title: Baruch
summary: A distinguished statesman and economist discusses his personal philosophy, his early years, and his success on Wall Street. The second volume emphasizes his active role in public life for fifty years.

title: Adventures of a prisoner of war, 1863-1864
summary: A Confederate officer, Barziza was wounded and captured at Gettysburg and imprisoned at Johnson's Island, Ohio. A year later he escaped while being transferred to another prison, made his way to Canada and finally back to North Carolina via a Canadian underground system established to assist Rebel soldiers.

title: I grew up with basketball: twenty years of barnstorming with cage greats of yesterday
summary: A retired commissioner of the New York State Basketball League recalls the early years of basketball when he was coach-manager of the Globe Trotters-Oswego Indians (1903-1923).

title: The long shadow of Little Rock
summary: As head of the Arkansas NAACP and a resident of Little Rock, she led the two-year struggle of the Black community to integrate schools. During those violent years she lived under armed guard and carried a gun after her life and those of her sons were threatened repeatedly. As co-publisher of the State Press with her husband, she fought against police brutality, for CIO organizers, and for other social causes.

title: The diary of Edward Bates: 1859-1866
summary: A remarkably detailed record of public and private life during these years, including those he served as U.S. Attorney General, with accounts of political and military strategy, of national and local politics in St. Louis, of books he read, of the weather, his garden, the cost of a watch.

title: Through sunlight and shadow
summary: The story of an American missionary couple in Landour, North India, and Kodiakanal, South India, who learned to enter the exotic world of the Hindi. Their work was interrupted by Evelyn's illness, polio, which occurred when their son was eight months old and which left her paralyzed, but not demoralized. She learned to type with her left hand and wrote religious pieces and this autobiography during her convalescence.

title: Harold Bauer: his book
summary: A lively account of Bauer's London upbringing and musical training, twenty years as a concert pianist in Europe based in Paris, followed by forty years' residence and musical activities in America, particularly in New York and Hartford. Full of pleasant anecdotes about his musical contemporaries.

title: Secret service chief
summary: In 1934 he became a Secret Service agent; in 1948 he became chief. His book describes his work for three presidents and their families and the criminal world he protected them from.

title: It was all quite different: the memoirs of Vicki Baum
summary: By the time she immigrated to the U.S. in 1931 she had established herself as a novelist (Grand Hotel); soon after that she became a well-known screenwriter in Hollywood. Her book describes her life among writers and intellectuals in Vienna, Berlin, and the U.S.

title: Pass it on: four generations of missionary service
summary: Bausum tells the story of his career as a third-generation Baptist missionary with his wife in China, mostly in Kweilin. The account of religious zeal and hard work is intertwined with a history of Sino-Japanese politics in the 1920's and 30's, culminating in war which ultimately became part of World War II. For Bausum the war reflected the opposition of Communism (atheism) and Christianity. The Bausum family traveled hundreds of thousands of miles in evangelical activities on furlough in the United States.

title: Intermission: a true story
summary: Movie actress tells the story of her marriage to rancher and businessman Ron Gait, 1959-63, with whom she learned to love the Australian outback at Giro, Gait's ranch near Worcester. It was an exhilarating struggle to cope with marriage, maternity, and movie-making.

title: Bax seat: log of a pasture pilot
summary: This collection of the best of Baxter's humorous 'Bax Seat' columns and feature articles is a log of his love affair with airplanes and people.

title: Village creek: the first and only eyewitness account of the second life of Gordon Baxter
summary: A disc jockey discusses his 27-year marriage to 'the perfect mother' of his eight children, whom he left at 51.

title: Marvella: a personal journey
summary: Marvella Bayh's forthright, compelling, intensely moving life story begins on an Oklahoma farm and continues through her life as the wife of a senator.

title: MS and us: an autobiography
summary: Beach, a victim of multiple sclerosis, describes the gradual onset of the symptoms and the psychological and physical toll of the disease.

title: Shakespeare and company
summary: Her book describes her life as a bookseller, lending librarian, publisher, and patron to many who became prominent in the literary circle of Paris.

title: Yankee auctioneer: wherein are to be found the reminiscences and philosophy of a country auctioneer
summary: His experience on the back roads of the Connecticut Valley depicts a vanishing lifestyle.

title: My story: the autobiography of a down-East merchant
summary: L.L. Bean discusses his business and its impact on the Freeport economy along with family life and various hunting and fishing expeditions.

title: Pro: Frank Beard on the golf tour
summary: A year in the life of a golf pro on tour based on his diary for 1969.

title: Diary of a Kriegie
summary: A journalist who was a German prisoner of war completed his diary after the war, expanding his notes and including facts and opinions he could not safely have recorded in prison.

title: Journals of Charles Beatty, 1762-1769
summary: Journals of three trips by Reverend Beatty, gathering information and preaching along with letters and other documents.

title: Memoirs of a volunteer, 1861-1863
summary: Beatty's diary records the war with candor and humor, documenting his rise from private to brigadier general.

title: Career ambassador
summary: Highlights of a 27-year career as Foreign Service officer and ambassador primarily in Central and South America.

title: Wm. Beaumont's formative years: two early notebooks, 1811-1821
summary: Notebooks include notes on his medical observations and travel, especially during the War of 1812.

title: America day by day
summary: After traveling the United States for four months, the author shares her impressions of America's cities and culture.

title: Treat it gentle
summary: Transcribed from tapes he dictated before his death, the story of his life as a jazz musician in New Orleans and Paris.

title: All the years were grand
summary: An Indiana Methodist minister's wife recalls her earlier, livelier days of work and travel.

title: Second carrot from the end
summary: Experience with Roger Dahljelm as partner in development of the Farmers Market in Los Angeles.

title: Fighter pilot
summary: Written near Paris in July 1944, while Beck awaited escape through the French Underground, this narrative reveals the spirit and idealism characteristic of many in World War II.

title: "What is the good of history?": selected letters of Carl L. Becker, 1900-1945
summary: Historian Becker's letters deal extensively with historical writing, university and higher education, war, peace, domestic politics, family, and friendships.

title: The life and adventures of James P. Beckwourth: mountaineer, scout, and pioneer, and chief of the Crow Nation of Indians
summary: Beckwourth was one of the living legends of the West, a man respected among white men and Indians.

title: Adventures with a Texas naturalist
summary: A naturalist, professor of speech, and friend of J. Frank Dobie describes his experience in the Texas outdoors.

title: Journal of Dr. Lewis Beebe. Eyewitness Accounts of the American Revolution
summary: An interesting account of his experience on an expedition against Canada in 1776.

title: A bishop of the Great Plains
summary: Recollections of the romance, obligations, and responsibilities of his life's work by the Episcopal bishop of western Nebraska from 1910 to 1943.

title: Autobiography
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: The notes, recollections, and correspondence of a prominent New England minister reflect his staunch devotion to Calvinism.

title: A mind that found itself: an autobiography
summary: His book records in precise detail his illness, the inadequate and often destructive treatment, and his later years as a philanthropist.

title: Deadline
summary: Begley focuses on her career as a reporter, primarily for the Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: Martin Behrman of New Orleans: memoirs of a city boss
summary: Kemp's introduction supplies a balanced correction to Behrman's understandable defense of his years as mayor and political boss of New Orleans.

title: People in a diary; a memoir
summary: Behrman offers a finely crafted account of his life among and fascination with the wealthy, sophisticated, and amusing denizens of Hollywood and New York.

title: The suspended drawing room
summary: A collection of playwright Behrman's shorter prose pieces.

title: Tribulations and laughter: a memoir
summary: A loosely structured account of a prominent playwright's career in the theatrical worlds of Broadway and Hollywood.

title: Worcester account
summary: A playwright recalls his youth in Worcester, Massachusetts, and his Jewish upbringing.

title: Civil War letters of George Washington Beidelman
summary: Beidelman was an enlisted man in the Union Army from 1861 until he died, probably of pneumonia, in March, 1864, just before his 25th birthday. In heavily religious letters to family and friends, he describes in detail a number of the major Civil War battles in which he participated, including the Second Battle of Manassas and the Battle of Gettysburg.

title: Miracle in the evening: an autobiography
summary: The extraordinary life of a designer-engineer whose work spanned art, dance, theater, and industry, a modern renaissance architect.

title: Josiah Belden, 1841 California overland pioneer: his memoir and early letters
summary: The dictated memoir of Belden's journey with the 1841 Bartleson overland expedition and his description of early days in California. Letters to his sister, extensive notes, commentary, and bibliography are included.

title: A journey to Ohio in 1810 as recorded in the journal of Margaret Van Horn Dwight
summary: The witty, lively account of a twenty-year-old woman's wagon trip from New Haven, Connecticut, to Warren, Ohio, recording the accents and actions of the people she meets, the discomfort of poor inns, poor roads, November weather in the mountains, rowdy Pennsylvania Dutch wagoners, and Methodists who fail to observe the sabbath as she would have them.

title: The lives and times of just Molly: an autobiography
summary: At 91, Bell wrote this book as "a celebration of freedom in personal relationships." She vividly describes her childhood in Minneapolis, her pleasure in music and love of kindergarten teaching, both traded for marriage with Dwight Bell in 1911, and the challenges of raising six children during the Depression.

title: Irregular gentleman
summary: A breezy narrative of travel, sex, and adventure in various exotic ports, by a writer attempting to convey the significance of "real" experience in a meaningful life.

title: Melvin Belli: my life on trial: an autobiography
summary: This flamboyant California trial lawyer recounts his childhood, his college days, and notable trials in which he often won large settlements for injured clients.

title: To Jerusalem and back: a personal account
summary: Jewish novelist Bellow describes a trip he and his wife took to Israel in 1976, characterizing its population and discussing the country's past, present, and future.

title: Fabric of memory
summary: The story of her remarkable career as a prominent actress, her retirement, and her second career as a patron of the arts and welfare leader.

title: Under eleven governors
summary: Belton, an Oregon farmer, provides a brief account of his public service under eleven governors, identifying major accomplishments and political challenges.

title: My life in art
summary: An artist-writer discusses his early interest in painting and the years in Paris when he learned to use oils.

title: Catch you later: the autobiography of Johnny Bench
summary: A catcher recounts his journey from the minor leagues to the Cincinnati Reds, the World Series, and the record books.

title: Translated from the Hungarian; notes toward an autobiography
summary: After serving in World War I, he became an architect in Philadelphia, reflecting the wit of his satire and the enormous pleasure of his life.

title: Selected letters
summary: A cross-section of letters selected from his extensive correspondence to illustrate the development of his personal and professional life over the years.

title: Sage of Petaluma: autobiography of a teacher
summary: Purports to be a 'mythical autobiography' and claims that the events never happened to anyone in particular and yet 'they happened to everyone of my generation and background.'

title: Fifty years in neurology and psychiatry
summary: The author describes his own work and achievements, his teacher-scholar contacts in younger days, unusual cases demonstrating the growth of knowledge through research, and hospital activities.

title: Forts and forays: the diary of a dragoon in New Mexico, 1850-1856
summary: A volunteer at 18, Bennett moved with the army from Rochester, New York, to Santa Fe, New Mexico. His diary vividly describes the primitive conditions of army life, the brutal treatment within the army as well as in Indian wars, and the conflict of cultures among Whites, Spanish, and Indians.

title: Bennett playbill
summary: Bennett's recollections of her volatile and controversial theatrical family. 'The Bennetts,' she says, 'were like a forest fire; the minute the flames were put out in one spot, they'd pop up in another.'

title: Kaibah: recollection of a Navajo girlhood
summary: A third person narrative about Kaibah (Kay Bennett) describing her life in an 'average Navajo family' on a reservation in New Mexico (1928-1935), including good detail of daily life and rituals, the struggle to maintain Navajo ways in a changing culture, and a chapter on the Depression.

title: Out of bondage: the story of Elizabeth Bentley
