summary: Agent who worked with the American Communist Party and Russian Secret Police describes what she did, the people with whom she was involved, and her subsequent decision to report all to the FBI.

title: Diary of William Bentley, D.D., pastor of the East Church, Salem, Mass.
summary: A popular pastor noted for his Catholic and liberal views of Christianity and distinguished for his social virtues as well, who helped prepare the way for Unitarianism.

title: Oklahoma tenor; musical memories of Giuseppe Bentonelli
summary: As Giuseppe Bentonelli, he was the first major American operatic artist to become highly popular in Europe. He made his American debut in Chicago, sang several roles at the Metropolitan, and then toured extensively before he returned to his home state and served as a professor of music at the University of Oklahoma.

title: An American in art: a professional and technical autobiography
summary: An account of his technical development as an artist, as distinct from his personal autobiography, An Artist in America. This volume includes 68 reproductions of his paintings and 'American Regionalism: A Personal History of the Movement.'

title: An artist in America
summary: The amplified version of Benton's well-written autobiography includes comments on the artist from the perspective of his role in the regionalist movement in American art. This edition also includes his activity since the 1951 edition when he was contemplating retirement.

title: Bernard Berenson treasury: a selection from the works, unpublished writings, letters, diaries, and journals of the most celebrated humanist of our times, 1887-1958
summary: An anthology of the art critic's writings, half previously unpublished, affords a record of his thoughts about and reactions to ideas, people, and events through his books, essays, letters, and diaries from 1887 to 1958.

title: Conversations with Berenson
summary: A compilation of notes of many conversations, 1931-1940, which Morra had with art critic Berenson at his villa in Italy. Berenson speaks on a variety of subjects: worldly and artistic experience, knowledge of the past and present, of men and of nations, and of art, history, music, literature.

title: Passionate sightseer: from the diaries, 1947-1956
summary: A distinguished art historian records his passion for the visual world of art and nature in journals of his travels in North Africa and Italy after World War II.

title: Rumor and reflection
summary: Written primarily from his villa outside Florence, Italy, from January, 1941, to November, 1944, this wartime diary contains the author's day-to-day impressions of what was happening in Italy and the world beyond.

title: Sketch for a self-portrait
summary: Written somewhere in hiding during World War II, this book reflects the warmth and dignity, the wisdom and curiosity of the man who was a major influence in the establishment of American art collections during the early part of the century.

title: Sunset and twilight: from the diaries of 1947-1958
summary: Selections from his diaries intended to depict his personal life and thoughts more fully than previous publications from the diaries.

title: Molly and me
summary: In 1929 she sold NBC on a script called 'The Rise of the Goldbergs.' She played the part of Molly; the show grew out of her deeply Jewish family life and entertained radio audiences for years.

title: Memoirs of an anti-Zionist Jew
summary: The memoirs of an anti-Zionist, pro-Arab Jew whose rabbinical connections led high-level Jewish organizations to oppose the view that Israel should be a real homeland for Jews and to promote the rights of Arab Palestinians.

title: Ingrid Bergman: my story
summary: Actress Bergman candidly discusses her rise from Stockholm's Royal Dramatic School to international film stardom.

title: Navigating the rapids, 1918-1971
summary: A graduate of Harvard and man of broad interests, Berle records in his papers his never-finished study of the interaction between corporate and political power.

title: Milton Berle, an autobiography
summary: Using the brusque aggressive tone of his comic image, Berle talks about his sixty years in show business.

title: The three worlds of Leonid
summary: With a painter's eye for detail, Leonid recounts his privileged life in pre-revolutionary Russia and Germany and his perilous flight from the revolution.

title: Self-portrait of a family: letters by Jessie, Dorothy Lee, Claude and David Bernard
summary: Sociologist Bernard edits and interprets the letters to and from her children during the 1950's and 60's to illustrate what it is like to rear a family of three children as a single parent.

title: My father, the actor
summary: A sentimental account of an Austro-Hungarian immigrant and his life as an actor in the Yiddish Theater in the United States.

title: Biography of an idea: memoirs of a public relations counsel
summary: An account of public relations as a new discipline and profession in this century.

title: A surgeon's domain
summary: Written while Bernheim was Associate Professor of Surgery at The Johns Hopkins Medical School, this book is a self-study, as well as an analysis of surgery and surgeons.

title: A sky of my own
summary: At age 45 she was a biochemist teaching and doing research. Her book describes what she learned and felt, the freedom and fear of flight.

title: Yogi: the autobiography of a professional baseball player
summary: Rated as one of the best fielding catchers in baseball history, he grew up in St. Louis, played for the New York Yankees, and was widely popular among sports fans.

title: America is hard to find
summary: A collection of essays, poems, and letters written during his four months in the underground and eighteen months in prison reveals Berrigan's commitment to the radical reshaping of America.

title: Lights on in the house of the dead; a prison diary
summary: The journal of Berrigan's eighteen months in the Federal Prison in Danbury, Connecticut.

title: Prison journals of a priest revolutionary
summary: In 1968 he was imprisoned in the Federal penitentiaries at Lewisburg and Allenwood, Pennsylvania, for participating in the napalming of draft files in Catonsville, Maryland. This defense of his action was written during his incarceration.

title: Widen the prison gates; writing from jails, April 1970-Dec. 1972
summary: Berrigan was ordained a priest in 1955; in 1973 he left the priesthood and married Elizabeth McAlister. He served forty months in the U.S. Army during World War II. He served 39 months in federal and local prisons for resisting the war in Indochina. This volume is a collection of his journals and letters written while imprisoned.

title: Amazing grace; with Charles Evers in Mississippi
summary: Berry records his experiences during the 1971 Mississippi gubernatorial campaign when he worked as press secretary for Charles Evers.

title: John Bertram of Salem, Massachusetts: his own account of incidents in his life
summary: Bertram's account chronicles a long lifetime of maritime activities, including imprisonment on a ship during the War of 1812 and his subsequent experiences as a sailor and businessman.

title: Early memoirs of a country gentleman
summary: Best kept a diary 1902-1925, detailing his coming-of-age experiences, his enjoyment of Princeton, and his reflections on life leading to his eventual marriage.

title: Northern farm: a chronicle of Maine
summary: Farm life in the woods of Maine, with an argument against modern man's alienation from nature.

title: The outermost house: a year of life on the great beach of Cape Cod
summary: Written in solitude, a meditative description of nature and the human spirit.

title: Bulls, balls, bicycles and actors
summary: A memoir featuring the author's experiences in various jobs leading to a fifty-year career in the entertainment industry marked by defiance of conformity.

title: A casual past
summary: A record of Biddle's illustrious forbears, education, and early career as a Philadelphia lawyer leading up to 1939.

title: In brief authority
summary: A continuation of A Casual Past, divided into four sections covering significant legal and governmental roles of Biddle.

title: Tahitian journal
summary: Prefaced with memories of World War I experiences, Biddle's journal from his stay in Tahiti recounts his interactions with the native culture.

title: The letters of Ambrose Bierce
summary: A collection of Bierce's letters showcasing his satirical wit and exploration of hate as a form of creative energy.

title: Twenty-one letters of Ambrose Bierce
summary: A series of letters pertaining to poetry submitted by Loveman, containing both critiques and friendly correspondences with Bierce.

title: Young sports photographer with the Green Bay Packers
summary: Young sports photographer who started helping his father, the official photographer for the Packers, at a young age.

title: The journal of Andrew Bihaly
summary: Bihaly reflects on the changes during the sixties in his adopted America, struggling with despair from his war experiences.

title: Of me I sing
summary: A narrative about a Michigan high school dropout who rose in journalism, touching on social and political history of his time.

title: Amazons: an intimate memoir by the first woman ever to play in the National Hockey League
summary: A funny account of her experiences in an athletic career as a rookie with the New York Rangers.

title: Something for everybody is not enough: an educator's search for his education
summary: An account of Birenbaum's education and experiences as President of Staten Island Community College.

title: Notes on a journey in America: from the Coast of Virginia to the Territory of Illinois
summary: Birkbeck's impressions of America and evaluation of farm sites, reflecting on his journey after emigrating in 1817.

title: It was fun while it lasted
summary: Recollections of his boyhood and family life in Harlem, capturing nostalgic anecdotes around family and community.

title: Letters of James Gillespie Birney, 1831-1857
summary: A collection of letters providing insight into the antislavery movement from a Southern perspective.

title: A lady's life in the Rocky Mountains
summary: An Englishwoman's letters describing her travels and experiences living in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Abraham Bisno: union pioneer
summary: A narrative of Bisno's life and his role in the garment workers’ union movement.

title: My life on the Mississippi, or why I am not Mark Twain
summary: Bissell shares humorous anecdotes from his days as a riverboat pilot, humorously challenging comparisons to Mark Twain.

title: Moscow was my parish
summary: An account of Bissonette's experiences in Moscow, focusing on travel and personal reflections.

title: This is my life
summary: A memoir filled with warm anecdotes about Thyra's life after her first book, highlighting her achievements beyond being a housewife.

title: Sincerely your friend: letters of Mr. Justice Hugo L. Black to Jerome A. Cooper
summary: A brief collection of correspondence from Supreme Court Justice Black to Jerome A. Cooper.

title: Black Elk speaks
summary: A powerful narrative of Indian life, detailing the spiritual value of old traditions amidst changing times.

title: Life of MA-KA-TAI-ME-SHE-KIA-KIAK, or Black Hawk, dictated by himself
summary: The story of the famous Sauk chief, based on the 1833 edition which he is said to have dictated to an army translator.

title: Torpedoboat sailor
summary: Blackford writes of his naval service in World War I aboard the destroyers Paulding and McDougal. He skillfully evokes the group camaraderie among the enlisted men and re-creates military strategy in his accounts of naval raids on other ships.

title: Letters from Lee's army: memoirs of life in and out of the army in Virginia during the war between the states
summary: The letters of Susan Leigh Colston Blackford and Charles Minor Blackford record their observations of war-time life in the South, 1861-1865. This is an abridged version of a small edition privately printed in 1894.

title: Pioneer work in opening the medical profession to women: autobiographical sketches
summary: Blackwell fought to study and practice medicine in the mid-nineteenth century, learning first from medical books, then studying at Geneva University. Acceptance was hard won on all fronts, but she emerged as the first woman in America to receive a complete medical education.

title: Very Willing Griffin: the story of the smallest boat ever to compete in the Single-handed Transatlantic Race
summary: After describing the extensive preparation for his race, the book is primarily his daily log kept for the 52 days of the race.

title: The Red Blaik story
summary: Part I describes Blaik's life as Army head football coach until his resignation in 1959. Part II carries the story into the 60's and adds his recollections of other coaches, presidents, and generals.

title: You have to pay the price
summary: A football coach for 25 years at Dartmouth and West Point, his book is about the game, the Army, and the values inherent in both.

title: Of life and love and things
summary: The ordinary life of a pleasant, ordinary woman living among friends and family in a small town in West Virginia, emphasizing her work as wife, mother, and Girl Scout Leader.

title: A sports editor finds Christ
summary: Blake intermingles the account of his career as a newspaper sports reporter with his activities as a Christian 'saved' from alcoholism by evangelical religion.

title: The papers of Alfred Blalock
summary: An enormous compendium of the professional papers of Alfred Blalock, M.D. These range from investigations of biliary tract disease to various aspects of heart disease.

title: The guts to win
summary: Feminist golfer Blalock describes her career on the Ladies Professional Golf Association circuit. She offers advice on how to play golf and assesses women's future in professional sports.

title: Personal and controversial: an autobiography
summary: Blanchard traces his career from Christian fundamentalist to humanist atheist, and from stodgy Puritan to sexual rebel.

title: Challenging years: the memoirs of Harriot Stanton Blatch
summary: A brisk narrative of the author's childhood, education, and the suffrage movement in New York, along with a look at the world's work left yet for women.

title: Narrative of John Blatchford: detailing his sufferings in the Revolutionary War, while a prisoner with the British, as related by himself
summary: In 1777 he enlisted as a cabin boy on a continental ship which was soon captured by the British. For the next six years he was on several prison ships, was sent to do forced labor in the East Indies, and finally was returned home.

title: I'll tell them I remember you
summary: The author of The Exorcist writes fondly of the difficult years of urban poverty in New York, his Lebanese immigrant parents, but especially of his mother with whom he believes he has made contact after death.

title: Fighting back
summary: Pittsburgh Steeler linebacker Bleier offers an unusually candid and critical self-appraisal. After playing football for Notre Dame and for the Pittsburgh Steelers in 1967 and 1968, Bleier was drafted and sent to Vietnam in 1969. His foot was badly damaged by a grenade. Through perseverance and extensive physical therapy and weight lifting, he not only recovered but returned to the Steelers to play much better than before his injury.

title: Hoofs in the distance
summary: "The Gibson Girl of Madison Square Garden" horse shows nostalgically describes the shows she entered, mounts she rode, travels she took to Maine and Europe, and hunts she rode in as Mistress of the Fox Hounds.

title: Autobiography of Sol Bloom
summary: In 1945, Bloom, aged 75, was one of seven American delegates sent to draft the charter of the United Nations. The son of Polish immigrants, he sold newspapers at age six, rose in the entertainment world to become the biggest publisher of popular music in the United States by 29, became a congressman at 54, serving under four presidents for over 25 years.

title: Bobst: the autobiography of a pharmaceutical pioneer
summary: A magnate in the modern pharmaceutical industry writes a sentimental account of his rise to wealth and subsequent philanthropic activities.

title: Knight of the napkin: memoirs of fifty years' experience in many lands
summary: A waiter, proud of his work, summarizes his apprenticeship in Europe before immigrating to the United States, his many years of service in restaurants here since 1907, with brief opinions about various aspects of his work life.

title: My life and loves in Greenwich Village
summary: Poet Max Bodenheim recalls his encounter with a variety of often seamy, sordid aspects of Bohemian life in Greenwich Village in the 1920's and 1930's. Through the volume parade mostly impecunious artists, writers, sexual deviants, lovers at peace and at war, and benevolent landlord Albert Strunsky, who donated living quarters to starving artists.

title: Love in Shadow
summary: Boettinger provides biographies of his parents Anna Eleanor Roosevelt (the only daughter of FDR. and Eleanor) and newspaperman John R. Boettinger whom Anna met on an F.D.R. campaign tour in 1932. Married in 1935, they were divorced in 1949, after successfully editing the Seattle Post-Intelligence for six years. Boettinger's military service in World War II contributed to his depression and ultimate suicide in 1950. His son's reminiscences are autobiographical in the last three chapters.

title: What the woman lived; selected letters of Louise Bogan, 1920-1970
summary: Bogan earned her living by writing literary criticism, but poetry was her life interest. Her letters are often to major figures on the literary scene, providing insight into the writer, the receiver, the creative process, and the struggle and growth of a personality.

title: Much have I learned
summary: A thoughtful analysis of ordinary experience that became significant for what it taught him, written by a prominent urban sociologist at the University of Southern California after his retirement.

title: Alexander letters, 1787-1900
summary: These letters of the Alexander family begin with their settlement in Washington County, Georgia, in 1787 and end in 1900. The most numerous represent exchanges among the ten children of Adam Leopold Alexander and his wife, Sarah Hillhouse Gilbert, in the 1850's and 1860's. They are educated families of plantation owners and bankers and consider their culture, manners, and breeding vastly superior to the Yankee invaders during the Civil War.

title: Witness to history, 1929-1969
summary: Memoir of a diplomat involved in American-Soviet relations from 1929 to 1969. Bohlen writes his impressions of the men who led the United States during this period.

title: Backcount'y journal: reminiscences of a wilderness photographer
summary: Illustrated with thirteen examples of his work, his book reflects the somewhat mystical quality of his landscape photographs.

title: True adventures of a little country girl: an autobiographical narrative
summary: Recalls cheerful childhood on a farm in Rutland, Vermont, with a loving family and lots of pets.

title: Under Gemini: a memoir
summary: Mary Miller writes about a decade in her childhood after her parents died when she and her twin sister, Grace, were reared in Goshen, New York.

title: Letters: 1925-1967
summary: Five hundred of the 2300 lively, perceptive letters exchanged between writers Bontemps and Hughes, including insights into the identity of each writer.

title: The honeymoon is over
summary: Traveling as entertainers with four teenage daughters presented many problems, met with Christian resolve and human impulsiveness.

title: Between actor and critic: selected letters of Edwin Booth and William Winter
summary: These annotated letters chronicle the professional activities of the famed American Shakespearian actor.

title: Edwin Booth: recollections by his daughter, Edwina Booth Groosmann, and letters to her and to his friends
summary: The collected letters of a famous nineteenth-century actor reveal his great affection for his daughter and interesting details of his personal life.

title: Fabulous destinations
summary: An author-clergyman travels alone in the Orient during a sabbatical leave right after World War II.

title: Country editor's boy
summary: The transition years of a boy, a town, and an area, the high plains of eastern Colorado when the days of the Old West were disappearing.

title: High, wide and lonesome
summary: A journalist describes his boyhood in eastern Colorado, where frontier life of the Old West still existed.

title: Eighty-one years of living
summary: Boyhood in Wisconsin, medical practice in Spring Green, Wisconsin.

title: My love affair with the Navy
summary: Bosworth, a career Navy public relations officer, mingles accounts of his military service with anecdotes about Navy life.

title: Trial judge, the candid, behind-the-bench story of Justice Bernard Botein
summary: His book describes what it felt like to be a judge, including problems he had not been trained to deal with.

title: Memoirs of Anne C.L. Botta, written by her friends
summary: The collection consists of the recollections by friends and selections from Anne Botta's correspondence.

title: Player-manager
summary: Boudreau, shortstop and manager for the Cleveland Indians, recounts his career in sports, highlighting notable games and players.

title: Born remembering
summary: One of the founders of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom describes her early education in New Jersey, her career as a social worker in New York, her conversion to Quakerism, her marriage, and five children.

title: Part of a long story
summary: A well-written narrative of her struggling days as a writer in Greenwich Village and of her love and early years of marriage to Eugene O'Neill.

title: Music hunter; the autobiography of a career
summary: For 35 years Mrs. Boulton traveled in remote parts of the world to discover and record the traditional and liturgical music of people whose cultures were scarcely known.

title: On the border with Crook
summary: Written by a member of General George Crook's military staff, this is a detailed account of the subjugation and management of the Indian tribes from Mexico to the Dakotas.

title: Portrait of myself
summary: The famed photographer writes a compelling narrative of her world-wide adventures, many on assignments from Life magazine.

title: Ranch schoolteacher
summary: She describes her development as a teacher primarily of non-English-speaking pupils during Arizona's pioneer days.

title: Woman in Levi's
summary: Teaching school during the week and running a homestead ranch on weekends, the author finds joy in both jobs.

title: The world of Randolph Bourne
summary: Mainly an anthology of his writings, including letters from 1912 to 1918 by this promising young critic.

title: Ball four: my life and hard times throwing the knuckleball in the big leagues
summary: A diary of a baseball season spent on an expansion team by a former New York Yankee.

title: I'm glad you didn't take it personally
summary: A humorous account of what happened to the author after the publication of his first autobiography, Ball Four.

title: Flight 13: thirteen years with Castro
summary: He writes of his work as an independent pilot, supplying arms to Cuban revolutionary forces until his disillusionment with Fidel Castro.

title: The journals of Ashley Bowen (1728-1813) of Marblehead
summary: Bowen's journals cover the years he spent as a seaman and merchant captain, detailing his daily activities and navigation specifics.

title: Adventures of a biographer
summary: Recollections of her experience during research travels for material on the lives of famous people she wrote about.

title: Family portrait
summary: A gentle, loving portrait of her family that celebrates and mourns for bygone youth.

title: Friends and fiddlers
summary: The book explores her joy in amateur music performance as a daily comfort and intimate family activity.

title: Ships, machinery and mossbacks: the autobiography of a naval engineer
summary: Vice-Admiral Bowen describes naval engineering activities during his time in the U.S. Navy, covering advancements in steam engineering and electronics.

title: Through the years: personal memoirs
summary: A thoughtful, intellectually and spiritually sophisticated analysis of the author's life as a religious educator, primarily at the College of the Bible in Lexington, Kentucky, and at the University of Chicago Divinity School.

title: My life: the memoirs of Claude Bowers
summary: A historian, politician, newspaperman, and diplomat describes his progress from happy boyhood in Indianapolis through a varied career in and out of politics ending with his ambassadorship in Chile (1939-1953) and the years afterward.

title: Learning to live
summary: An eloquent, appealing memoir by an Episcopalian clergyman who served as a chaplain in World War I and at St. Paul's and Grace Churches in Richmond, Virginia, throughout the 1920's and 1930's. In the 1940's and 1950's he was a faculty member at Union Theological Seminary and always an articulate spokesman for civil rights, ecumenism, and enlightened church reform.

title: Promises to keep: my years in public life, 1941-1969
summary: A record of his public life which began when he was forty and lasted for 29 years, this volume reflects, in Bowles' words, 'one man's futile effort to buck the so-called 'Establishment'.'

title: Across the continent: a summer's journey to the Rocky Mountains, the Mormons, and the Pacific States with Speaker Colfax
summary: Although dominated by mannered descriptions of the wealth of Midwestern cities and the unlimited opportunities of Western lands, this account occasionally sparkles with the newspaper editor's surprise and delight in the physical beauty he finds on his journey. He comments on the Indian Question, polygamy, exploitation of natural resources, spicing the lot with what he frankly acknowledges to be gossip.

title: The world that was
summary: A nostalgic recollection of his boyhood, emphasizing the strong influence of his father's wisdom and values by a man who became Chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Belle Boyd in camp and prison: written by herself; a new edition prepared from new materials by Curtis Carroll Davis
summary: Perhaps the most notorious among women who spied during the Civil War, Belle Boyd worked for the Confederacy, then took her name and fame to the stage and lecture platform where the legends of her days in espionage developed even further.

title: As I live and breathe: stages of an autobiography
summary: In 1951 Boyd left Hollywood, where he had been a radio-television partner of Mary Pickford and Buddy Rogers, to study for the Episcopal priesthood. Thereafter he was a college chaplain, civil rights demonstrator, and fighter against poverty, discrimination and the Vietnam War. Here he writes of his angers, his fears, his motivations and beliefs.

title: Baa, baa, black sheep
summary: He gave up his commission in the U.S. Marines to join Claire Chennault's elite mercenaries, The Flying Tigers, which, along with a reputation as a hard-drinking, hard-living adventurer, led him to become a military outcast. By 1943 he was out of work and desperate for an active military assignment. He was assigned to command a group of misfits known as his Black Sheep, who brought him and themselves a certain renown for their courage and heroism. The book was the basis of the TV series by the same name.

title: The long walk at San Francisco State
summary: A member of the creative writing faculty at San Francisco State University during the 1968-69 student strikes, she describes the violent clash between youth and the authority represented by S.I. Hayakawa, then university president.

title: Diplomats and demagogues: the memoirs of Spruille Braden
summary: A graduate of Yale, fervent anti-communist, and longstanding member of the John Birch Society, Braden was Ambassador to Colombia, Cuba, and Argentina, before being appointed Assistant Secretary of State by Harry S. Truman in 1945.

title: The letters of Gamaliel Bradford: 1918-1931
summary: The letters reveal the breadth of Bradford's interests as critic and scholar, from Shakespeare and other Elizabethans to Darwin, Confederate generals, theater, politics, and sports. His wit, humor and gentleness are expressed in correspondence to a wide and multifarious circle of friends from Cambridge scholars to the young authors such as Robert Frost and H.L. Mencken. Companion volume to his journals.

title: Life and I: an autobiography of humanity
summary: Bradford presents a psychological and philosophical study of the 'I,' with chapters on 'Love and I,' 'Power and I,' 'Thought and I,' 'Christ and I,' and even 'Christ and Not-I,' concentrating on the many desires which threaten to pull the 'I' apart.

title: Born with the blues; Perry Bradford's own story; the true story of the pioneering blues singers and musicians in the early days of jazz
summary: The story of his campaign to get commercial recording companies to make records of Negro girl singer, Mamie Smith, and other blues and jazz singers and combination bands, leading to million-dollar profits for Okeh Company and others. He awakened the industry to the tremendous market for the rhythmic beat of the blues.

title: A soldier's story
summary: American General of the Army recounts his experience during World War II from the perspective of the field command post. He includes personal relationships with his colleagues, especially Patton, Eisenhower, and Montgomery, in addition to detailed accounts of actions ending with the surrender of Germany in 1945. He writes honestly about his involvement with the Korean War, six years after the events described in his book.

title: Along the way: an autobiography
summary: A minister of the Peoples Church of Chicago for over fifty years writes of his youth, education, and his prominent ministry which became international.

title: Will Bradley, his chap book
summary: An American contemporary of William Morris and The Kelmscott Press, his approach to graphic arts was as adventuresome, but more democratic, targeting magazines, newspapers, and advertising houses. In 1954 he was awarded the gold medal of the American Institute of Graphic Arts 'for a half-century of typographic achievement.'

title: Life on the run
summary: New York Knicks basketball star's intriguing analysis of the professional touring athlete's life on the road. Bradley offers an exceptionally sensitive interpretation of the way a professional team functions humanly, on and off the court, at home and away, in its relations with coaches, trainers, rival players, fans, friends.

title: Big top: my forty years with the greatest show on earth
summary: The author, an equestrian director and stage manager, describes his own and his wife's life with the Barnum and Bailey, Ringling, and North circuses. The book traces the development of the circus in the United States and contains a glossary of circus terminology in addition to descriptions of the greatest acts.

title: Terry Bradshaw: man of steel
summary: A candid and articulate account of Bradshaw's career as quarterback for the Pittsburgh Steelers, 1971-1979, interlaced with comments about life in Shreveport, Louisiana, with his parents and brothers, college football at Louisiana Tech., and unsatisfying marriage to skater Jo-Jo Starbuck. Bradshaw's Christian commitment is pervasive.

title: Superchic
summary: The former publisher of Women's Wear Daily and Harper's Bazaar gives an irreverent and opinionated account of the designers, models, editors, columnists, and advertisers who people the elegant world of haute couture.

title: I remember
summary: Painter Brainard's book consists entirely of one-sentence paragraphs, each of which begins, 'I remember . . .' These focus mostly on childhood and adolescent memories of family life, holidays, American culture, and sex: 'I remember knowing what 'c-a-n-d-y' meant long before I knew how to spell.'

title: Journey with David Brainerd: forty days or forty nights with David Brainerd
summary: A devotional guide compiled of selections from the diary, journal, and letters of Brainerd, a missionary among the Indians during the early Colonial era. The guide is intended to assist people seeking 'a dynamic spiritual experience within the evangelical Christian tradition.' Each of the forty short selections closes with a prayer.

title: Life and diary
summary: This account of Brainerd's life and work among the American Indians was originally published in Vol. Ill of The Works of President Edwards in Eight Volumes (London: James Black & Son, 1817). It provides an interesting record of his spiritual growth, the conditions of the Indians, and his perception of the effect of mission work upon them.

title: False starts
summary: An up-beat, witty, and philosophical book about the author's first forty years. By 14, abandoned by mother, father, and stepmother, Braly became a ward of the state and began a career as a thief, which lasted until he was forty. He published his first novel while in prison and went on to become the respected author of In the Yard, a novel about San Quentin.

title: Fling wide the gates
summary: Brandeis, an evangelical Baptist minister, writes 'so others may know how Jesus Christ became real to me.' High school valedictorian, he joined the Navy at sixteen to fight Hitler. There he traded his Jewish faith for atheism when his best friend was killed in the Battle of Luzon. He became an alcoholic and chronic gambler; car theft resulted in a sentence at Florida State Prison where he was converted to Christianity.

title: Letters of Louis D. Brandeis
publisher: State University of New York Press
summary: A towering figure in his own time and in the broader sweep of American history, Brandeis was a leading reformer in the progressive era, the synthesizer of American Zionism, and a great jurist of the Supreme Court. His letters demonstrate his outstanding character and accomplishments in helping to make the world and his country a better place.

title: Here's Bob
summary: In the 1960's Braun was a big fish in the Cincinnati TV pond, with the 'Fifty-Fifty Club' noontime TV show and others of the 'audience participation, guest-star, live music' format. His autobiography, illustrated with many publicity stills, enhances his image as a good-natured entertainer, surrounded by celebrities and housewives.

title: Journal of William H. Brawley, 1864-1865
summary: Edited by his grandson, the journal records his experience in England and France where he was apparently sent as a Confederate envoy and law student after losing an arm while fighting for the South Carolina Volunteers.

title: Helldorado: bringing the law to the Mesquite
summary: He served as a deputy sheriff in Tombstone, Arizona, and spent many years as a lawman in Tucson, both during the late nineteenth century when the notorious gamblers and guns were in their prime. A vivid recollection of life on the Western frontier.

title: The political education of Arnold Brecht: an autobiography, 1884-1970
summary: A blend of personal reminiscence and political contemplation form an extraordinary account of German history from the start of World War I through the period of Weimar democracy to the ascent of Hitler.

title: Yes, Lord
summary: Minister and man of a thousand schemes, Bredesen recounts his Lutheran seminary days and promotion of various Christian endeavors from fund-raising for the World Counsel on Christian Education to the Gospel Association, followed by marriage and ministry in an upstate New York Church.

title: An immigrant's shenanigans: thirty-three jobs in twenty years
summary: Proud of his success in America, Breen recalls his childhood and youth in Ireland, his assortment of jobs after immigration, and, later, an extended trip to Europe to visit relatives.

title: Life with my Mary
summary: A newspaper reporter and editor celebrates the joys of marriage and fatherhood, always within the context of Roman Catholicism.

title: An assassin's diary
summary: The would-be assassin of George Wallace left thirteen handwritten diary entries later found in his car, representing an interesting though incoherent articulation of his original plans to kill the president and then Wallace.

title: From mine pit to pulpit
summary: A contented reminiscence by a retired Methodist clergyman who, when aged eight to eleven, worked in the Pennsylvania anthracite mines. His interim occupation as a barber and his long-term career as a Methodist clergyman seem easy by comparison and thoroughly pleasurable.

title: The seven stairs
summary: By 1960 he had a prosperous bookshop on Chicago's Michigan Avenue and a daily TV program, 'Books and Brent,' that Variety called the best daytime TV show. He writes about getting started in the book business with little more than a love of good books and a great deal of determination and naivete.

title: Brereton diaries: the war in the air in the Pacific, Middle East and Europe, 3 October 1941-8 May 1945
summary: A personal account of World War II by the Commander of the Far Europe East Air Forces, who was later assigned to the Middle East.

title: The little grandmother of the Russian Revolution; reminiscences and letters of Catherine Breshkovsky
summary: Although primarily concerned with Breshkovsky's involvement in the Russian Revolution, this mixture of letters, speeches and secondary material includes an account of Breshkovsky's fund-raising visit to New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Chicago, and her reception by the settlement movement workers.

title: Time of my death
summary: A chemical engineer analyzes the plane crash in July 1963 in which he was severely maimed and burned and describes in detail the rehabilitation process that required 46 operations and much loving support from his wife and medical personnel.

title: The world of Jimmy Breslin
summary: Breslin became a sportswriter for the New York Herald Tribune in 1963. By the time this book, a collection of his columns, was published, his reputation as a serious journalist was well established. He is admired for his Irish humor and sensibility, his compassion, and the strength of his critical insight.

title: A story of toil and tears/of love and laughter
summary: Brewer emphasizes his lifelong career as a gospel preacher and devotes chapters to confession, salvation, rebaptism, anthropomorphisms — describing God in human terms.

title: My dear wife from your devoted husband: letters from a rebel soldier to his wife
summary: This plainspoken narrative of an infantryman's activities during the Civil War is typical and ultimately moving in its accounts of good and poor commanders, tattered clothing and barefoot marches, sickness and health, ample and insufficient food, missing pay, and a dearth of letters from home.

title: Up and down in California, 1860-1864: the journal of William H. Brewer
summary: Brewer wrote three picturesque letters while serving as a horticulturalist for the California State Geological Survey under the direction of Josiah Dwight Whitney.

title: Journal of an African cruiser: comprising sketches of the Canaries, the Cape de Verde, Liberia, Madeira, Sierra Leone, and other places of interest on the West Coast of Africa
summary: A fascinating account of the author's voyage as a naval officer to the West Coast of Africa, 1843-44, when he noted customs, trade, religion, and other aspects of their cultures.

title: Farewell to Foggy Bottom: the recollections of a career diplomat
summary: A career diplomat for nearly forty years, Briggs reminisces about his experiences in amusing or serious circumstances and makes suggestions for improving the effectiveness of the Foreign Service.

title: My cap and my cape: an autobiography
summary: Socialite Philadelphian recalls her nursing experiences during World War I and II.

title: Diary of a short-timer in Vietnam
summary: The diary of a Black surgeon in the Vietnam War, written during the second half of his tour of duty before he returned to the United States in May, 1968.

title: An America that was: what life was like on an Illinois farm seventy years ago
summary: A recreation of the author's youth on an Illinois farm makes vivid the self-sufficient and simpler ways of rural living before the turn of the century.

title: The Devils' coach. And Joe Gilmartin
summary: A baseball coach recalls his experience with the Arizona State University Sun Devils and reflects on his coaching philosophy and experiences before and after his conversion.

title: Fifty years of prison service: an autobiography
summary: Brockway devoted his long life to the work of reformation and rehabilitation of prisoners and the protection of society, working in various prisons.

title: This is Norman Brokenshire: an unvarnished self-portrait
summary: A prominent disc jockey and radio commentator describes his life and his long struggle with alcoholism.

title: From my experience: the pleasures and miseries of life on a farm
summary: A realistic but pleasant account of his years as a farmer after assessing the experience of World War II.

title: A family narrative: being the reminiscences of a Revolutionary officer
publisher: New York Times and Arno Press
summary: A brief account of a career which he began as a private in Washington's army and ended as judge of Virginia's Court of Appeals.

title: Clenched fist
summary: The record of their experience as teachers in the federal schools of Alaskan territory during the early 1900's ends with a patriotic plea to preserve Alaska from the U.S.S.R.

title: A Southern lawyer: fifty years at the bar
publisher: The University of North Carolina Press
summary: A pleasant reminiscence by a lawyer and Southern gentleman, describing his boyhood on a North Carolina plantation during Reconstruction, his early days as a lawyer and prosecuting attorney, and his 57-year legal career.

title: Gramercy Park: memories of a New York girlhood
summary: Recollections of her girlhood in the 1890's and early 1900's include anecdotes of many celebrities attended by her father, a doctor, and others who came to the Sunday salons held by her mother, a lover of the arts (Mark Twain, Lillian Russell, Enrico Caruso, et al.).

title: Report from part one
summary: This autobiographical statement by an outstanding Black poet contains 'Report from Part One,' previously published in McCall's magazine as well as sections on her African experience, photographs, and three interviews in 1967, 1969, and 1971.

title: Days of the phoenix: the nineteen-twenties I remember
summary: Because he lived at the center of the literary world, his personal reminiscences are also literary history, including his experience with such writers as Lewis Mumford, Sinclair Lewis, Sherwood Anderson, and Theodore Dreiser.

title: From the shadow of the mountain: my post-meridian years
summary: The third volume of the essayist's autobiography concerns his life from 1931, when he returned to normal life after four years in mental hospitals, until 1961.

title: Scenes and portraits: memories of childhood and youth
summary: Recollections of his boyhood and early years to 1914, including his years at Harvard, his close friendship with Maxwell Perkins, and many prominent artists and intellectuals.

title: Van Wyck Brooks: an autobiography
summary: Brooks' autobiographical trilogy describing his life and literary America from the early 1900's to the 1960's— Scenes and Portraits, Days of the Phoenix, and From the Shadow of the Mountains.

title: Van Wyck Brooks-Lewis Mumford letters: the record of a literary friendship, 1921-1963
summary: This collection is unique, according to its editor, 'in that it is so unliterary in the usual sense of gossip, incidental literary criticism, and the thrill of entree to the mysterious but nondescript world of literary and artistic personalities.' The letters document a deep and moving friendship.

title: Here I am take my hand
summary: Although she had previously worked in several election campaigns, her book concerns primarily her work for the George McGovern campaign when she became the first Black advance woman. She describes her duties as publicist for the Women's Rights Division and the frustrations and triumphs of the campaigns.

title: Big Bill blues: William Broonzy's story as told to Yannick Bruynoghe
summary: Big Bill Broonzy tells fascinating tales about his development as a country blues singer and guitar player, showing how many of his over three-hundred songs lamented painful incidents in his life or the lives of his friends and lovers.

title: Twice a pioneer
summary: Stories of homestead life in Minnesota and South Dakota, originally published serially in The Dakota Farmer.

title: A miner's life, an autobiography
summary: Brophy, the CIO's full-time director until 1939, was in the forefront of every organizing campaign 1933-1939. He fought for the eight-hour day, campaigned to become president of the UMW, and was part of the early organization of the CIO. He continued his work on various special assignments until his death.

title: The long season
summary: A personal account of the 1959 baseball season, written by a pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds.

title: A studied madness
summary: Broun describes his experiences as an actor of stage, screen, and television; his views on the theater (both from the actor's and the writer's perspectives); and, from his background as a sports writer, makes comparisons between acting, horseracing, and baseball.

title: Tumultuous merriment
summary: A popular news and sportscaster writes of his working life, with special attention to the ways in which sports has become a business.

title: J. Brousch, conqueror of adversity; an autobiography
summary: Brousch's book offers advice illustrated by his own experiences on how everyone can change their level of thinking and rise to a higher plane of living through a program of personal growth.

title: Contempt of Congress: the trial of Earl Browder
summary: In the record of his trial and acquittal for contempt of Congress charges, the author cites his belief in Marxist principles, his objections to the paths taken by American communists, and his belief in challenging the Senate Committee rather than invoking the Fifth Amendment.

title: Me, and other advertising geniuses
summary: A brisk, exuberant narrative of his forty-year career in advertising. He includes stories of his work in newspapers, radio, and television.

title: Judge Addison Brown; autobiographical notes for his children
summary: He describes growing up in nineteenth-century Massachusetts, establishing his law practice in New York in 1854, his long years of practice as a lawyer and judge, with sections on the Civil War, notable buildings and events in early New York, and comments on world affairs.

title: Memoirs of a centenarian
summary: Dr. Brown writes eloquently of his extraordinarily active and distinguished career as a clergyman for twelve years in Wisconsin, Illinois, and Portland, Oregon. Until retirement, he was Secretary to the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church.

title: You may take the witness
summary: A vivid, fast-moving account of the author's courtroom experiences as a trial lawyer in San Antonio, written to entertain the general reader rather than a legal audience, though Brown articulately discusses courtroom strategy.

title: Reagan and reality: the two Californias
summary: Published just prior to the 1970 California gubernatorial election, this book offers Brown's admittedly "unobjective" appraisal of Reagan's first term in office by comparing it to his own performance as Governor and his own perception of California history.

title: Stubborn fool: a narrative
summary: A narrative of her sixteen years with the Indian Service working administratively on reservations in South Dakota and Arizona, and her subsequent indictment of its exploitation of the rights of American Indians.

title: Die, Nigger, die!
summary: Distinguishing between whites, Blacks, and Negroes, i.e., institutionalized Blacks who are allied with whites, Brown advocates violence, militancy, and whatever means are necessary to secure freedom and destroy the system that oppresses Black people.

title: Monkey off my back: an ex-convict and addict relates his discovery of personal freedom
summary: The grim details of his life as a criminal and dope addict, with graphic descriptions of his experience in various prisons, including one in which he shared a cell with Clyde Barrow. Written by a born-again Christian devoting his life to exposing the horrors of drugs and crime.

title: Letter book of James Brown, of Providence, merchant, 1735-1738: from the original manuscript in the library of the Rhode Island Historical Society
summary: Details of his merchandise business reveal very little of his personal life.

title: Laughter is a wonderful thing
summary: The story of his development as a comedian and actor, through circus days and vaudeville, stage and screen.

title: Morning faces: a book of children and parents
summary: Narrative chapters, most previously printed in The Saturday Review of Literature, describe the interactions of father and two sons growing up together.

title: I testify; my years as an undercover agent for the F.B.I.
summary: From 1951 to 1960 Mrs. Brown, as an FBI confidential agent, was inside the communist network. She worked in various subversive organizations, met many top Party functionaries, and reported her activities and contacts to the FBI. This book tells of those activities and of her testimony in 1962 before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

title: Adventures with D.W. Griffith
summary: During his fifty years in the motion-picture business Brown was an important part of cinema history. He was assistant cameraman on all of the D.W. Griffith pictures from 1913 until World War I and later photographed The Covered Wagon and directed Stark Love, a documentary filmed in the mountains of North Carolina. His book contains vivid reminiscences about the people and the history of film-making.

title: I married a dinosaur
summary: Humorous account of her first four years of marriage, spent fossil hunting in India and Burma, by a young woman called Pixie by her husband, whom she met and married in India.

title: P.B.: the Paul Brown story
summary: This forthright, good-natured account of Brown's career as a football coach exemplifies his philosophy that 'everything we do must be in terms of our team and doing our best.'

title: The hills are strong
summary: A writer and teacher recalls growing up in southeastern Ohio, the events which contributed to his maturity, and his development as an author.

title: Aaron Burr expedition: letters to Ephraim Brown from Silas Brown, 1805-1815
summary: Silas Brown left upstate New York as a member of Aaron Burr's expedition to Mississippi in 1908. Brown is aware of Burr's indictment for treason and acquittal; but he is evasive about his connections with Burr and the nature of their enterprise.

title: Narrative of William W. Brown: a fugitive slave, and a lecture delivered before the Female Anti-Slave Society of Salem, 1847
summary: This book by a Kentucky-born slave became a best seller in 1847; two years later he published Clotel. or the President's Daughter, the first novel published by an American Negro.

title: A dangerous journey: California 1849
summary: The natural beauty and violence among men and animals recorded during his mule trip between San Francisco and San Luis Obispo in the summer of 1849 as a revenue agent.

title: J. Ross Browne: his letters, journals and writings
summary: Assessing his limitations and capabilities early in life, Browne set out to accomplish two ambitions: to see the world and to become a writer.

title: Yusef: or, the journey of the Frangi: a crusade in the East
summary: Browne, an inveterate traveler and sometime statistician, writes with zest and American chauvinism about his trip, c. 1851, to Sicily, Greece, Turkey, Syria, Lebanon, and the Holy Land.

title: Autobiography of a female slave
summary: Although somewhat melodramatic in style, this is an excellent narrative of slave life, its pain and degradation, written by a woman finally freed by the death of her mistress.

title: Forty-four years of the life of a hunter: being reminiscences of Meshach Browning, a Maryland hunter, roughly written down by himself
summary: A remarkable record of early nineteenth-century life in the Maryland mountains, written in an interesting and readable style by a hunter who survived the severe conditions of wilderness life.

title: Autobiography of Louis Brownlow
summary: Volume I is a detailed account of the author's childhood in Missouri, his informal education, and his career as a journalist in Tennessee and Washington, DC. to 1915.

title: Brownson-Hecker correspondence
summary: The editors have provided extensive notes, biographical sketches, a history of the correspondence, and an appendix to this collection of letters dating from 1841-1872.

title: Hog wild: the autobiography of Frank Broyles
summary: The athletic director for the Arkansas Razorbacks gives a play-by-play account of his career, both as Georgia Tech football player and in assistant and head coach positions.

title: Honey: the life and loves of Lenny's shady lady
summary: The extraordinarily sordid life of Lenny Bruce's wife for six years, detailing her experiences and struggles.

title: How to talk dirty and influence people; an autobiography
summary: Some people found Bruce's comedy offensive, some, self-indulgent; some thought him creative and some, obscene and subversive. Most, however, agreed that he was free-speaking and uninhibited, unafraid of shocking audiences and breaking taboos.

title: To have your cake and eat it. Illustrated
summary: The wife of Wilber M. Brucker describes the social activities and trips (to Europe, the Far East, the Middle East, and around the United States) she participated in while her husband was Secretary of the Army, 1955-61.

title: Gold Rush: the journals, drawings, and other papers of J. Goldsborough Bruff, Captain, Washington City and California Mining Association, April 2, 1849-July 20, 1851
summary: A life-long resident of Washington, DC, in 1849 he was intrigued by the discovery of gold and formed a mining company. Based on diaries of his overland journey, his extensive journals were revised for publication.

title: Memoirs of a doctor of the old and new worlds
summary: After describing his boyhood, medical education, practice, and family life in Vienna, he writes of his immigration to New York in 1938 and the Austrian-American synthesis in his private and professional life.

title: As now remembered: the interesting life of an average man
summary: The book describes his personal and professional life, focusing on his contributions to social research.

title: The oilman who didn't want to become a millionaire: his own story
summary: Brunson was reared on a Mississippi cotton farm during the Reconstruction and for thirty years worked for others on oil fields in California, Oklahoma, and Texas. At 50 he formed his own company and nearly went broke before making a million dollars.

title: Memoirs of William Jennings Bryan: by himself and his wife
summary: Bryan left only a first draft of his life story through his college years. His wife Mary completed their memoirs, using his correspondence, documents, and her diary, leaving an interesting record of their personal and political lives.

title: The letters of William Cullen Bryant
summary: The poet-journalist's letters are written to his wife, Frances, his literary confidante, Richard Henry Dana, and other friends; they comment extensively on literature, politics, and travel.

title: I have lived with the American people
summary: He writes of his experience as a well-educated Filipino immigrant confronted by American prejudice against Orientals, chiefly in California.

title: Women are my problem: the autobiography of an obstetrician and gynecologist. Illustrated
summary: After discussing his childhood and medical training in Cleveland, an obstetrician-gynecologist devotes considerable space to defending and justifying the then radical medical philosophy and techniques of gyneplastic repairs and puerperal gynecology.

title: Mr. Buchanan's administration on the eve of the rebellion
summary: Buchanan's formal interpretation of events leading up to the Civil War, filled with excerpts from government documents, is intended to prove that the Northern abolitionists caused not only the Civil War, but most of the country's problems thereafter.

title: Who's calling my name?
summary: In a series of good-natured parable-like chapters, Buchanan analyzes his 'Type A' personality, hard-working, competitive, hyperactive and hyper-reactive to the emotional stress of being a Baptist clergyman.

title: The story of a labor agitator.
summary: Born in Hannibal, Missouri, he worked on a newspaper there, then in Denver and Leadville, Colorado, where he joined a trade union and soon became prominent as a union organizer. A detailed, readable document for labor history.

title: Red carpet at the White House: four years as Chief of Protocol in the Eisenhower administration.
summary: A behind-the-scenes look at state visits to the White House by foreign dignitaries, written by the Protocol Chief during the second Eisenhower term, 1959-1961.

title: Bucher: my story.
summary: Bucher was commander of the U.S.S. Pueblo which in January 1968 was seized by the North Koreans. Here he writes of that international incident, his eleven-month captivity with his crew, their release, and the Court of Inquiry which followed.

title: American argument.
summary: An autobiographical dialogue by Buck, a white author raised in China, and Robeson, a Black author raised in the United States, in which they explore the values which formed their characters and the differing ways in which they confront difficult contemporary issues.

title: A bridge for passing.
summary: The story of her return to Japan to work on the filming of her book, The Big Wave. A sensitive understanding of the people and an appreciation of Japanese ways.

title: The child who never grew.
summary: Published first as an article in Ladies Home Journal, the book is an account of awareness and accommodation to her child's lack of mental development.

title: My several worlds: a personal record.
summary: A Nobel Prize-winning novelist looks back upon her childhood in China and the various visits she made to that country... The process of finally becoming completely American.

title: Personal memoirs and recollections of editorial life.
summary: These memoirs of his life in printing, publishing, and editing speak of hardships, failures, discouragements, but ultimate satisfactions of a stern, upright man.

title: Airborne: a sentimental journey.
summary: In new journalistic style, laced with pithy observations... Buckley narrates the transatlantic voyage of his sailboat Cyrano with its crew of six.

title: United Nations journal; a delegate's odyssey.
summary: As a member of the U.S. Delegation to the UN General Assembly... Here he writes a readable and informative analysis of his experiences.

title: The unmaking of a mayor.
summary: In the 1965 New York mayoralty elections, Buckley recounts his campaign and the events that led to that election day.

title: This is my story.
summary: Budenz describes the rationale of his conversion to the Catholic Church after eleven years in the Communist Party.

title: Don Budge: a tennis memoir.
summary: Budge describes various key tennis matches he played and intersperses accounts of his professional career with advice on how to play good tennis.

title: The memoirs of Clarence Clough Buel, 1850-1933: condensed from the original manuscript entitled 'Sixty Years with the Press.'
summary: An engaging narrative of Buel's life as an English immigrant and a reporter, with excerpts from his editorials and articles.

title: The life and letters of Charles Bulfinch, architect, with other family papers
summary: A leading architect in Boston, he designed Boston's first theater, the State House on Beacon Hill, and was appointed to complete the work which Benjamin Latrobe had begun on the National Capitol in Washington. This volume combines diary entries and letters to depict his life chronologically.

title: America is in the heart: a personal history
summary: Describes growing up in a poor Filipino village, immigrating to America in the 1920's where he was sold to an Alaskan cannery contractor for $5, and recounts the struggles with racial bias, poverty, and labor union conflicts.

title: The story of Jim Bunning
summary: The sixth pitcher in modern major league baseball to pitch a perfect game, Bunning tells the story of his rise in baseball in chapters separated by inning-by-inning accounts of that perfect game.

title: Memoirs of eighty years of farming
summary: A story of farm and country living in Oregon and Washington during the first half of the twentieth century.

title: Now I remember: autobiography of an amateur naturalist
summary: Famous as the author of Mother West Wind books for children, he writes here of his childhood on Cape Cod, his clerking days in Boston, and the gradual development of his career as a writer of over seventy books and more than 15,000 newspaper 'Bedtime Stories.'

title: The thief: the autobiography of Wayne Burk
summary: Written from interviews and police documents, the book portrays the life of a professional thief and gunman who considers himself happy and successful.

title: With a feather on my nose
summary: Describes her career on stage, her marriage to Florenz Ziegfeld, Jr., and details of theater life and people in this period.

title: With powder on my nose
summary: Her second book explains her mode of being a feminine woman, the techniques of maintaining that appearance, and the values that appearance represents.

title: Anointed for burial
summary: Burke and his wife describe their missionary activities in the Khmer Church (Cambodia), where they taught the Bible and performed other benevolent acts until forced to evacuate Phnom Penh in the communist takeover.

title: I die daily: the story of a woman whose love will live forever
summary: Moving account of the year before her death by cancer of the uterus.

title: I have known many worlds
summary: Burlingame explains how his career as a writer evolved from his family background, tastes, talents, and experience.

title: Recollections and opinions of an old pioneer
summary: Boyhood in Missouri; pioneer in Oregon; jurist and politician in Oregon and California; first Governor of California.

title: The late Liz: the autobiography of an ex-pagan
summary: A slangy, semi-tough account of the author's three affluent marriages, her struggles with addiction, and her discovery of lifesaving evangelical religion.

title: I love her, that's why!: an autobiography
summary: After a brief description of his early life, he writes mostly of his career as an actor and comedian on stage, radio, and film, highlighting his partnership with Gracie Allen.

title: Living it up: or, they still love me in Altoona!
summary: An account of comedian George Burns' 72-year career, laden with anecdotes and comedy routines.

title: Memoirs of Aaron Burr: with miscellaneous selections from his corre- spondence
summary: Burr turned all of his papers and correspondence over to Davis, who then wrote the 'memoirs' and controlled what should not be included, e.g., notes revealing Burr's strong dislike of George Washington.

title: Private journal of Aaron Burr: during his residence of four years in Europe; with selections from his correspondence
summary: Burr was living in Europe after being found not guilty of treason or a misdemeanor in his fatal duel with Alexander Hamilton. Originally written for his daughter, this is an excellent record of early nineteenth-century life and travel.

title: John Burroughs' America: selections from the writings of the Hudson River naturalist
summary: In a selection of essays from his many published books, the author talks about what he sees and thinks about in the natural world around him.

title: I lay down my cap
summary: The story of her 25 years as a registered nurse, her courage, drive, and common sense.

title: A search for man's sanity: selected letters, with biographical notes
summary: A collection of letters by a prominent psychiatrist, selected to reveal the thought and feeling of a man engaged in the stress of daily analysis of group and individual behavior, a man genuinely interested in the arts as well as science and highly respected by his colleagues.

title: Honest, Abe: is there really no business like show business?
summary: Author, producer, director Burrows tells the story of his life, from salesman, gag writer, and Wall Street runner during the Great Depression to success in radio and television. Also an articulate drama critic, Burrows enjoys a host of Hollywood celebrity friends.

title: Rabbi with wings. Illustrated
summary: 'The Flying Rabbi' describes four exciting years, 1948-51, when he worked in the fledgling state of Israel, helping to establish an air force and train pilots, as well as to teach aerodynamics, mathematics, physics, and English. With a patriotic Zionistic spirit, Burstein discusses the economic and military development and Sabra spirit of the new country.

title: Next thing: autobiography and reminiscences
summary: An author of several books related to Catholic heritage writes of her conversion to Catholicism, her childhood, her marriage to Harry Burton (editor of McCalls), her devotion to the medical theories of Dr. John Henry Tilden.

title: Three parts Scotch: an informal biography
summary: A rambling, sentimental narrative by a New England woman describing her life, friends, and her poetry.

title: Diary of Richard L. Burtsell, priest of New York: the early years, 1865-1868
summary: Recording the day-to-day activities of a busy Catholic priest, the Burtsell diary reveals his concern for difficulties of church law, the paro- chial school system, celibacy among the clergy, and anti-Catholic bigotry.

title: Pieces of the action
summary: During a period of evolution, change, and the advancement of science and technology, Bush was a chief actor in his roles as inventor, educator, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, director of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, advisor to presidents, and chair- man of Merck and Co.

title: My three years with Eisenhower: the personal diary of Captain Harry C. Butcher, USNR, naval aide to General Eisenhower, 1942-1945
summary: An inside story of the war against Germany and Italy by Eisenhower's naval aide.

title: Laurel Hill and later: the record of a teacher
summary: Describes his education at Johns Hopkins and Oxford; professor of literature, and later Dean at Sophie Newcomb College, Tulane University.

title: Unhurried years: memories of the old Natchez region
summary: Youth on family plantation near Natchez, Mississippi, 1873-93.

title: After the good gay times, Asheville — summer of '35: a season with F. Scott Fitzgerald
summary: Reconstructed from his own notes of visits, events, encounters, phone calls, and letters, these recollections describe the author's life during the summer of 1935 when he became well acquainted with Fitzgerald.

title: Iowa outpost
summary: A mixture of fact and fiction describing life in rural Iowa, specifically of a settlers' community in Lapham, their values, their religion, their recreation and routine life.

title: I'm an endangered species: the autobiography of a free enterpriser
summary: Byrd has enjoyed life as a multimillionaire, partly through wildcat drilling of oil wells, for which he obtained leases through ruthless and flamboyant tactics. He married a millionaire's daughter, expanded his various businesses, and became active in the Civil Air Patrol and in philanthropic activities.

title: The Black experience in big business
summary: Byrd, a Black electronics engineer, recounts various experiences of racial discrimination, promotion, and the reactions to his race by those he supervised, concluding with a survey justifying Affirmative Action programs.

title: Discovery: the story of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition
summary: An eloquent memoir of the 1934 return voyage to Antarctica, featuring descriptions of exploration, geological experiments, and survival perils.

title: London diary (1717-1721) and other writings
summary: Byrd's meticulous diary details his life in Colonial America after inheriting his father's estates in Virginia.

title: The secret diary of William Byrd of Westover, 1709-1712
summary: One of the earliest diaries by a Southern colonist, detailing life in Tidewater Virginia during the early eighteenth century.

title: All in one lifetime
summary: The life of a distinguished statesman who served in various capacities including Congressman, Senator, Supreme Court Justice, Secretary of State, and Governor.

title: Surgeon of hope
summary: Byron's career as a surgeon is intertwined with his evangelical Christian faith, illustrating both his surgical skills and personal beliefs.

title: As I remember it: some epilogues in recollection
summary: A narrative about his career as a writer, including descriptions of his interactions with influential figures.

title: Between friends: letters of James Branch Cabell and others
summary: Letters revealing varied opinions from authors during the post-World War I years, including discussions on Cabell's controversial novel.

title: The letters of James Branch Cabell
summary: Most letters by this Southern novelist are addressed to literary figures, detailing their interactions and thoughts.

title: Preface to the past
summary: A collection of commentaries and autobiographical notes reflecting on Cabell's life and the contemporary literary scene.

title: Quiet, please
summary: Reflections on the author's feelings and thoughts about his youth and aging.

title: Beggar on horseback: the autobiography of Thomas D. Cabot
summary: Cabot's autobiography reflects on his successful business career and philanthropic efforts, along with his family's traditions.

title: Show me a miracle: the true story of a man who went from prison to pulpit
summary: Cacopardo's journey from being wrongfully imprisoned to becoming a Presbyterian minister, focusing on his faith and redemption.

title: The education of Abraham Cahan
summary: Cahan's life story highlights his journey from immigrant to influential journalist, advocating for social justice and communication.

title: Earth angels: portraits from childhood and youth
summary: Cahill narrates her journey through childhood and adolescence, exploring her evolving faith and experiences in the Catholic Church.

title: Widow
summary: The author shares her experiences and feelings as a widow — 'the emotions of bereavement that leave even the strongest psyche tattered.' She writes of the onset of her husband's cancer, the months of illness, his death, the progression of her grief.

title: Calder; an autobiography with pictures
summary: Famous for his mobile and stabile sculptures, this artist first trained as an engineer. In his twenties he turned to art, creating intricately balanced and shaped structures which changed the direction of twentieth-century art.

title: Autobiography of Charles Caldwell, M.D.
summary: This is the hyperbolic, self-defensive autobiography of 'the Horatio Alger of medicine, the enfant terrible of Philadelphia and the West, the fiercest and fightingest of pioneers, the non-stop medical orator.' Caldwell was a physician in the War of 1812, professor at the Philadelphia Academy of Medicine and the medical schools of Louisville and Lexington, and a prolific author.

title: Call it experience: the years of learning how to write
summary: Beginning with his early days as a stringer for local Georgia newspapers, Caldwell describes the hard work getting started as a writer, publishing his first fiction, his collaborations with Margaret Bourke-White, and the difficult business of developing his career.

title: Growing up tough
summary: One of the world's most widely read writers looks at her early years in England and America. Her story becomes a strange polemic for her anti-feminist stance.

title: Somewhere the sun is shining
summary: Calhoun, a journalism major at the University of California, Berkeley, enlisted in the Army Air Force shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor and received flight training in Texas before being stationed in England and Belgium as a fighter pilot. His mother, editor of the collection, reports her son's death in battle on February 22, 1945.

title: The papers of John C. Calhoun
summary: This thorough, scholarly collection of Calhoun's papers, mostly letters he wrote as Secretary of War under President Monroe, focuses on his presidential prospects and their gradual disappearance; relations between the U.S. government and various Indian tribes; monitoring the educational quality of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point; discussions of whether to establish military outposts in the Northwest; the Monroe Doctrine; and some minor aspects of his personal life.

title: And hearing not — : annals of an adman
summary: Deaf from early childhood, the author writes of his difficult adjustment to the world with this handicap. He emphasizes that over six million people of the U.S. are seriously hard of hearing, causing considerable disadvantage in a society which carries on the business of living largely by speech.

title: Rocky Mountain warden
summary: Primarily a description of life in southern rural Utah where he worked five years as a game warden, the book gives an earthy portrait of Western country life.

title: Kenneth Callahan: universal voyage
summary: Primarily a collection of his paintings printed with a text edited from the recent tape recordings, lectures, and writings of a major artist in the Pacific Northwest, whose work is seen as primordial, metaphysical, mystical.

title: Lieutenant Calley: his own story
summary: He gives his own account of what happened before, during, and after the controversial incident in the village of Mylai, Vietnam, which resulted in a military jury finding him guilty of premeditated murder.

title: Of Minnie the Moocher and me
summary: Calloway tells of his exhilarating career as band leader and singer, which included fame, fortune, and bevies of females. He loved his work, which included a full roster of celebrities during the Jazz Age and the Big Band Era.

title: My Arabian days and nights
summary: Medical missionary describes her family and professional experience in Kuwait, where she was the first woman doctor (1912-1930).

title: Point of departure
summary: English journalist Cameron writes a compelling philosophical account of his globetrotting career as a reporter of diverse and significant international events since World War II.

title: It's good to be alive
summary: Paralyzed by an accident in the prime of his career, a popular baseball player describes his early life, his years with the Brooklyn Dodgers, and the difficult recovery from total paralysis.

title: Here I raise mine Ebenezer
summary: Her life, character, and opinions are reflected in anecdotal sketches of her childhood, married family life, children, legal issues, and incidents related to her career as a lawyer.

title: Marching without banners: and other devices
summary: A loosely structured narrative which reads like a journal, with entries responding to particular events in her life after retiring from a legal career.

title: Arkansas lawyer: reminiscences of a lifetime
summary: Arkansas lawyer Tom Campbell recounts in abundant detail the highlights of his childhood in Randolph County and notable cases of his fifty-year law practice throughout Arkansas.

title: All my patients are under the bed: memoirs of a cat doctor
summary: Veterinarian Camuti has spent sixty years treating cats — all house calls, which he believes reduces feline anxiety.

title: Life at eighty: memories and comments by a tarheel in Texas
summary: Canada describes his childhood, youth, and college education in North Carolina, focusing on his fifty years of farm work in Texas.

title: Copies of Calamity Jane's diary and letters
summary: In plain language, Calamity Jane writes an annual letter to her daughter, assuring her of her legitimacy.

title: American memoir
summary: A perceptive, well-written analysis of his childhood and experiences throughout his life, including the influence of World War I.

title: The breach in the wall; a memoir of the Old China
summary: Candlin describes China and its cities as she knew and loved them, along with historical and political insights.

title: All and sundry; an oblique autobiography
summary: A miscellany of prose and poetry revealing the stages of Cane's long life as a practicing poet and lawyer.

title: Up and down and around: a publisher recollects the time of his life
summary: His long association with Harper's has brought Canfield into contact with many well-known authors and significant events.

title: Bishop Cannon's own story: life as I have seen it
summary: Cannon discusses his life experiences and political efforts as a church lobbyist through various significant events.

title: Letters from prison
summary: Cannon penned 182 letters to his wife while imprisoned, offering a coherent system for establishing a structured political party.

title: Uncle Joe Cannon: the story of a pioneer American
summary: N/A

title: The way of an investigator: a scientist's experiences in medical research
summary: He writes of his experience as a teacher and researcher during a forty-year career at Harvard Medical School — his problems, his mistakes, and his satisfactions.

title: Frontier trails: the autobiography of Frank M. Canton
summary: Although he was an outlaw in Texas in his youth, he later changed his name, moved north, and became a peace officer, serving as sheriff and deputy U.S. Marshal in various places, then as adjutant general of the Oklahoma National Guard.

title: As I remember them
summary: A performer recalls with warmth and affection the events and friends of his show business career.

title: Take my life
summary: A Broadway comedian describes his early life on New York's Lower East Side and his long and happy career in entertainment.

title: The way I see it
summary: The homespun life and philosophy of a prominent entertainer is full of anecdotes about family, friends, and the famous.

title: The autobiography of Yakima Canutt
summary: A narration of Canutt's exciting life, ranging from being a championship rodeo rider to a stunt man in films.

title: A highly ramified tree
summary: Canzoneri writes lyrically of the interplay of generations in his extended Italian family and of the effects of time and change on them.

title: Slightly out of focus
summary: A photographer and war correspondent writes of his experience in love and war during World War II.

title: Dogs bark; public people and private places
