summary: The author's collection of his short pieces depicting his personal landscape and characters he has found memorable.

title: The Thanksgiving visitor
summary: An autobiographical story about Capote's childhood years focusing on his relationship with his cousin, Miss Sook Faulk.

title: Frank Capra: the name above the title: an autobiography
summary: An immensely successful movie director, Capra rose from humble beginnings to eminence in the arts.

title: Silent Hattie speaks: the personal journal of Senator Hattie Caraway
summary: The diary verifies the harsh judgment against Caraway, the first woman elected to the U.S. Senate, reflecting her infrequent focus on Senate business.

title: Carew
summary: Carew describes his rise from an impoverished childhood to a comfortable life and discusses his experiences with racial discrimination.

title: Autobiographical sketches
summary: The author wrote a series of letters addressing his views on the rise and progress of the American system.

title: Island in time: a memoir of childhood
summary: Carlisle, a Russian emigree painter and writer, analyzes her wartime exile on the lie d'Oleron, France, from the dual perspectives of her teenage years during World War II and her current viewpoint.

title: Bill Carlisle, lone bandit: an autobiography
summary: Cowboy turned bandit, imprisoned twenty years and rehabilitated.

title: Two on the rocks
summary: His fascinating adventures among the Eskimos on Little Diomede Island in the Bering Strait, 150 miles from Nome, Alaska.

title: Sometimes I wonder
summary: A fuller narrative of his life in the center of the jazz world, his boyhood in Indiana, his college bands, his success on radio and in Hollywood.

title: Stardust road
summary: The early days of jazz and Tin-Pan Alley, in a rhythmic narrative that carries the droll humor of one of the great jazz pianists and songwriters.

title: Prison to praise
summary: Colonel Carothers writes of his criminal youth, his life as a soldier-paratrooper-demolitions expert during World War II, and his conversion to Christ.

title: Victory on Praise Mountain
summary: Carothers describes incidents that occurred during his ministry of Praise Center in Escondido, California, focusing on overcoming trials.

title: We seven: by the astronauts themselves
summary: A collective autobiography and description of their training and missions by the seven Project Mercury astronauts.

title: Lucky 7: a cowman's autobiography
summary: "Lucky 7" chronicles the odyssey of his adventuresome life as a cattle driver and trail boss.

title: A Cavalryman in Indian country
summary: Carr's narrative concerns his three years in the blistering Arizona frontier at Fort McDowell.

title: The continuing education of William George Carr: an autobiography
summary: Carr focuses on national and international aspects of education and the NEA's involvement in various educational reforms.

title: Voyage to Lourdes
summary: This book relates a French-American surgeon's personal reconciliation at Lourdes, France, between Catholic faith and science.

title: Yankee batboy
summary: The author discusses his association with the New York Yankees during the time of Mickey Mantle, Casey Stengel, and Yogi Berra.

title: Home to the wilderness
summary: A writer and naturalist describes her childhood and early years, focusing on the tense relationship she had with her mother.

title: Journal of Charles Carroll, 1776: during his visit to Canada, in 1776
summary: Carroll's journal records his trip from New York to Montreal, detailing the conditions of soldiers there.

title: To remember forever: the journal of a college girl 1922-1923
summary: An account of her first year at Bates College portraying life at a women's school.

title: Years away from home
summary: Recalling some experience from her first book, this one shows the influence of her home life on her development as a writer, up to the success of her first novel, As the Earth Turns.

title: The John Carroll papers: Vol. I, 1755-1791; Vol. II, 1792-1806; Vol. III, 1807-1815
summary: This beautifully printed, carefully edited collection contains about ninety percent letters, but also includes ecclesiastical reports and a journal of Carroll's European tour, 1771-72. Together, these letters illustrate Carroll's concerns, human, theological, and political, pertinent to establishing the Catholic Church in America, and significant communication with Catholic clergy and laity throughout America and Europe.

title: Kit Carson's autobiography
summary: A dictated unsentimental account of his career as a Western scout and Indian fighter by one of America's most romanticized figures. Carson was brave, resourceful, an indefatigable traveler with extraordinary common sense concerning military strategy and peaceful relations with Indian tribes.

title: Education of Little Tree: a true story
summary: Carter (named 'Little Tree' in Cherokee) was orphaned at five and in 1930 went to live with his grandparents in the Tennessee mountains. Taught the lore of nature by his grandmother and his Cherokee heritage by his grandfather, he had little contact with the world of white prejudice until placed in a Christian orphanage where he was beaten and ostracized. He finally left the orphanage and returned to the mountain cabin to share his grandparents' last years.

title: Cousin Beedie and Cousin Hot: my life with the Carter family of Plains, Georgia
summary: Among various people capitalizing on their relationship to Jimmy Carter is 'Cousin Beedie,' a Plains, Georgia, worm and cricket farmer, antique dealer, and state legislator. He affably gossips about all the members of the Carter family, their children, wives, cousins, and other relatives, rehashing familiar stories and telling some new ones.

title: The spiritual journey of Jimmy Carter: in his own words
summary: The collection of excerpts from speeches, interviews, and writings of Jimmy Carter before and during his presidency is arranged to provide the commentary of a devout, fundamentalist, evangelical Christian on his religion. It covers 'The Life of Faith'; 'Temptation, Sin, Forgiveness, and Grace'; 'Religion and Politics'; and 'Teaching and Preaching.'

title: The diary of Colonel Landon Carter of Sabine Hall: 1752-1778
summary: A rich account of the day-to-day life of a member of the colonial Virginia gentry, this diary includes much information on agriculture, crops, slavery, medical practice, scientific activity, social life, and politics, and a look at his personal traits and values, his problems, his motivation, and the world as he saw it.

title: Ms. Lillian and friends: the Plains, Georgia, family philosophy and recipe book
summary: This peculiar book contains autobiographical interviews with Lillian Carter, mother of President Jimmy Carter, who wrote the foreword. It also contains a history of the Carter hometown, Plains, Georgia; sketches of Southern stereotypes, and recipes of Southern food.

title: Letters of Robert Carter: 1720-1727, the commercial interests of a Virginia gentleman
summary: The letters of a great planter and colonial leader provide important historical information on business relations with English and European merchants and the preoccupation of early Virginians with trade.

title: Dear Bet: the Carter letters 1861-1863
summary: Carter's straightforward and unassuming letters to his wife cover the period from his enlistment in the Confederate Army in August 1861, to January 21, 1863. He was killed at Gettysburg a week later. The letters comment on Carter's food supply, supplemented from home when the viands survived the journey, on his intermittently bad health, and on the war in his immediate vicinity.

title: The Bern book: a record of a voyage of the mind
summary: Though not strictly either an autobiography or a travel book, this book states the author's faith in himself and describes his experience of being an unpublished writer and the only Black man in Bern, Switzerland, where he gives English lessons and writes.

title: First person rural
summary: The editor of the Delta Democrat-Times in Greenville, Mississippi, recounts stories of Southern life, travels, hunting expeditions, and people he knew.

title: Where Main Street meets the river
summary: A journalist describes the first newspaper he started in a small Southern town, the development of his career, his years as a war correspondent, and his return to the South after the war.

title: Autobiography of Peter Cartwright: the backwoods preacher
summary: Cartwright elucidates church doctrine, describes camp meetings and church conferences, and recounts cultural particulars in travelogue fashion.

title: The journals of Jonathan Carver: and related documents, 1766-1770
summary: A scholarly edition of Carver's journals and related documents detailing his travels throughout Michigan, Wisconsin, and the Great Lakes region.

title: Life of Dr. William F. Carver of California: champion rifle-shot of the world
summary: This oral history focuses on his capture by the Indians and his life among them for a period of sixteen years.

title: Out of his treasure: unfinished memoirs
summary: Dr. Carver recounts his rural Tennessee upbringing, education, and experiences as a pastor.

title: Lazy-man-rest-not: the Burma letters of Brayton C. Case
summary: A collection of letters detailing thirty years as a Baptist missionary in Burma.

title: Among my klediments
summary: June Cash focuses on her favorite things and people, detailing her experiences in music and marriage.

title: The secrets of grownups
summary: A sparkling account of Caspary's development as a celebrated novelist and screenwriter, detailing her life in writing.

title: Heart beat: my life with Jack and Neal
summary: Letters and accounts from Cassady detailing her life with Neal Cassady and Jack Kerouac during the Beat Generation.

title: Ford White House: the diary of a speechwriter
summary: Casserly's diary details the challenges of writing speeches during Gerald Ford's presidency.

title: Never a dull moment: the memoirs of Countess Marguerite Cassini
summary: The daughter of a Czarist diplomat describes her colorful career among royalty and her success as a couturiere.

title: Doctor in many lands: the autobiography of Aldo Castellani
summary: Castellani describes his international experiences in medical research and surgery.

title: Castles in the air
summary: Until her husband Vernon's death in a training accident during World War I, they danced and entertained for the cafe society of New York and Paris, their lives and performances characteristic of the glamour of the pre-war era. Thereafter she continued her life as an entertainer and pace-setter for women's fashions.

title: Willa Cather in Europe: her own story of the first journey
summary: The journal of her first European travels in 1902 reveals much about the mind of a young writer and the kinds of people and ideas she would later write into her fiction.

title: My life and the Times
summary: For many years chief news executive of the New York Times, Catledge recounts his rise from poverty-stricken Mississippi boyhood, through his early jobs as a reporter in the South and later in Washington, to his long, eventful service with the Times. The book is full of anecdotes and inside views of rivalries, personalities, and crises.

title: Waiting for the morning train: an American boyhood
summary: A nostalgic look at his childhood in a small Michigan town by a well-known author of popular histories of the Civil War era and other books.

title: Kingdom within
summary: Blinded as an infant, she studied to be a teacher, became fascinated by Japan, and in 1923 after years of teaching to accumulate savings, went to Japan where she taught the blind. When World War II began, she established a school for the blind in Bangkok and later in Vietnam.

title: Four years behind the iron curtain
summary: In 1942 he joined the U.S. diplomatic service and was immediately sent to Lebanon, then Russia and Yugoslavia. His book is staunchly patriotic, harshly anti-communist.

title: You never leave Brooklyn: the autobiography of Emanuel Celler
summary: A congressman from Brooklyn, New York, recalls his childhood and the realization of his political ambitions. The book is mainly concerned with the congressman's opinions about U.S. immigration laws.

title: At random: the reminiscences of Bennett Cerf
summary: A fascinating account of Cerfs profound influence on American book publishing. Beginning as an assistant to Horace Liveright, he bought the Modern Library, then founded Random House, building it into a multi-million dollar corporation. He fought to have Joyce's Ulysses published in the U.S. and helped bring many writers to prominence. His anecdotes illuminate the personalities of many of the century's greatest writers.

title: Mr. Mayor
summary: A two-term mayor of St. Louis, the epitome of mid-America geographically, ethnically, and economically, tells of his struggle to rebuild a faltering city by fostering low-cost housing, by persuading businessmen to combat prejudice and unemployment, by wooing tourists, by tightening anti-crime measures, by fighting social decay.

title: In search of something: the memoirs of a public relations man
summary: Cerwin describes his varied career as a United Press correspondent, as head of the Rockefeller office in Mexico, as a diplomat in Brazil, and as a public relations specialist.

title: Marian Chace: her papers
summary: Dance therapist Chace briefly discusses her development as a dancer and her increasing understanding of the therapeutic potential of dance throughout the 1930's, as a preface to her papers, published and unpublished, on dance therapy schools and hospitals (notably, St. Elizabeth's, Washington, D.C.), from 1940 to 1970.

title: Looking at the sunset upside down: the autobiography of Margaret Lee Chadwick
summary: Educated in rural Utah, Salt Lake City, later at Western College (Oxford, Ohio) and Stanford, she then taught for six years in Nevada, had a number of offers of marriage that did not work out, and on a round-the-world trip met and married career naval officer, Joseph Chadwick. She bore three children and started a day nursery. For thirty years they directed the Chadwick (boarding) School on the Palos Verdes Peninsula in California.

title: My first eighty years..; the life story of a California surgeon
summary: Dr. Chaffee describes his childhood in California, his college days at Stanford, his medical education at Johns Hopkins and residency in Maryland, and his military duty during World War I in Georgia and France. The book is particularly useful for its information on American medical education, 1900-1920.

title: Presence of the actor
summary: The author, who has received several off-Broadway acting awards, founded the open theater in 1963, which became a celebrated influence in the theater during the sixties. Here he writes notes on productions he has taken part in, on acting experiences and training, and on other influences on his professional work.

title: Where the Sabia sings: a partial autobiography
summary: A well-written, empathetic recollection of her childhood in Brazil by a daughter of Baptist missionaries.

title: Etched in sunlight; fifty years in the graphic arts
summary: His work in graphic arts is both respected and popular. This book combines reproductions of his etchings, drawings, lithographs and photographs with a well-written account of his life in the arts, conveying the humane perception and intellect for which he is recognized.

title: My confession: the recollections of a rogue
summary: The story of his adventures as a cavalryman in the Mexican War (1846-1848), often in the style of flagrant melodrama, but interesting as a comment on the times.

title: Wilt; just like any other 7-foot black millionaire who lives next door
summary: Chamberlain, who holds innumerable basketball records, knows and writes about his own career, other players, his million-dollar house built to his scale, and his views on racial questions and politics.

title: The evolution of a conservative
summary: A journalist and foreign correspondent for many years, including twelve in the Soviet Union, describes his political philosophy in the context of an analysis of world politics since 1940, when he published his life story, 77ie Confessions of an Individualist.

title: Cold Friday
summary: A controversial figure in the Alger Hiss case, Chambers here reflects on his formative years at Columbia, his career as a journalist, his family life, and his concern for his children.

title: Odyssey of a friend: Whittaker Chambers' letters to William F. Buckley, Jr., 1954-1961
summary: Buckley describes the letters as 'spontaneous personal and philosophical reflections which will help the reader to judge the plausibility of the attacks on Whittaker Chambers' character,' since the case for Alger Hiss 'relies increasingly on efforts to discredit Chambers personally.'

title: Witness
summary: The author's and his family's involvement with the Communist Party from the mid-20's to the celebrated spy case of Alger Hiss in 1948. He interprets his feelings and actions as a confession.

title: Journal of the Rev. George Champion: American missionary in Zululand, 1835-9
summary: After a period of adjustment in Cape Town and Bethelsdorp, a band of American missionaries journeyed to Dingane to set up a school and missions for the Zulus. Champion's journal records his observations about the people, the country, and the work of the missionaries.

title: Raymond Chandler speaking
summary: The extant letters of a prominent mystery writer, edited according to themes, e.g., 'Chandler on Chandler,' 'Chandler on the Mystery Novel,' 'Chandler on Cats.'

title: Remembering; the autobiography of a mystic
summary: From humble beginnings to a movie career and eminence as a mystic and founder of Astara, Chaney writes of psychic experiences, cosmic illumination, communication with those on the other side, astral flights, and the pilgrimage of the soul upward into light.

title: From gaslight to dawn: an autobiography by Julie Chanler
summary: Raised in New York high society, she became devoted to the B'hai religion as a young woman. Her book conveys an image of her wealth and privilege, her international travel, her charitable work for B'hai, and her pet terriers.

title: Memory makes music
summary: Recollections of the changes in musical taste and fashion since the late nineteenth century and the autobiography of her musical interests, by a writer and music critic.

title: What's a woman doing here?
summary: As a photojournalist and war correspondent, she wrote front-line reports of the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa in World War II.

title: Charles E. Chapin's story
summary: Chapin was a newspaperman and city editor for forty years before he took the steps that led to his life imprisonment in Sing Sing.

title: Long Wednesdays
summary: The editor of a small country weekly in Minnesota reminisces about his job in the 1930's.

title: A countdown at eighty
summary: An articulate account of Chapin's attempt to lead the simple life he believed conducive to becoming a great writer, first in his native state of Massachusetts, then as a married expatriate in Paris.

title: Musical chairs: a life in the arts
summary: A monied childhood in Mt. Kisco, New York, helped to instill in Chapin a love of music which he pursued at NBC, then at Columbia Records, and finally at Lincoln Center, where he became General Manager of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Wobbly: the rough-and-tumble story of an American radical
summary: For fifty years he worked in the American labor movement as rebel editor, writer of battle songs, agitator, and organizer.

title: Frank M. Chapman in Florida: his journals and letters
summary: One of America's great naturalists, Chapman recorded in these letters and journals his own work in Florida in the 1880's and 1890's.

title: A camp on the Yukon
summary: Episcopal missionary in Anvik, Alaska, 1887-1930.

title: Brother Ray: Ray Charles' own story
summary: The story of a famous Black musician, from his extremely impoverished rural Southern beginnings to his great talent for playing instruments, singing, and composing.

title: Always in vogue
summary: The editor of Vogue Magazine recalls her years in New York working on that magazine and the people connected with it.

title: Auto-biography: recollections of a pioneer motorist 1896-1911
summary: An entertaining story of Chase's life-long love affair with turn-of-the-century automobiles.

title: Carthaginian rose
summary: With candor and relish the author-actress recreates her memorable journeys to Europe and the exotic East.

title: Free admission
summary: A shapeless, chatty Hollywood memoir which dwells on gossip and the small details of the author's life.

title: Face value: autobiography of the portrait painter
summary: Portrait painter, designer, and teacher, Chase tells charming stories about painting presidents, soldiers, statesmen, actors, authors, and explorers.

title: My friends look better than ever
summary: Painter-illustrator reminisces about his life through anecdotes about his friends and people he has painted over the years.

title: A goodly fellowship
summary: A sequel to A Goodly Heritage, this volume is a tribute to the author's teachers, from her mother to her professors at the University of Minnesota.

title: A goodly heritage
summary: In tribute to New England at the turn of the century, the author traces the influence of a tempered Puritanism, the simplicity of coastal life, and the value of a classical education.

title: White gate: adventures in the imagination of a child
summary: The book describes the memories of an author's childhood in Maine in the 1890's.

title: Diary and correspondence of Salmon P. Chase
summary: A U.S. Supreme Court Justice during the Civil War, he corresponded with antislavery journalist Edward S. Hamlin, with Charles Sumner, and with George S. Denison.

title: Inside Lincoln's cabinet: the Civil War diaries of Salmon Portland Chase
summary: The diaries of the author detail his political career during the years Lincoln was president. He relates experiences in Washington, D.C., as Secretary of the Treasury, a Republican candidate for the presidency, and the beginning of his career as a Supreme Court Justice.

title: The life-line of the lone one: or autobiography of the world's child
summary: It is difficult to tell whether the subject, identified only as 'The Lone One,' is autobiographical or not. Chase identifies this book as a 'true and literal history' of the struggles of an ambitious mind to 'rise from a dishonorable birth'; he published it as a moralistic guide for the humble.

title: Russell Cheney, 1881-1945: a record of his work
summary: This record of a painter's work includes excerpts from his diary and his letters as well as plates of his paintings.

title: The education of Anna
summary: Chennault writes of her luxurious childhood in Peking, reared by her grandparents. Her youth was shattered by the Sino-Japanese War and devastated by World War II, which broke up her family. As a reporter, she fell in love with General Claire Chennault, 35 years her senior. They married in 1947, founded an airline, and were fighting communism when he died in 1958.

title: A thousand springs: the biography of a marriage
summary: A description by his wife of General Claire Chennault and their life together, against the background of war and peace, China, and The Flying Tigers.

title: Way of a fighter: the memoirs of Claire Lee Chennault
summary: After a few pages about his early life, he describes his army experience in China (1939-49), where he organized the crack bomber squadron The Flying Tigers, converted after the war to transport food, supplies and trade goods throughout China. American air adviser to Chiang Kai-shek.

title: Maxine Cheshire, reporter
summary: She describes the violence that permeated her hometown, Harlan, Kentucky, and the many scandals she uncovered in later years as a reporter for the Washington Post. Cheshire deals specifically with the Tongson Park scandal (Koreagate), the Nixons' keeping of gifts from foreign dignitaries while in office, and John Kennedy's extra-marital affairs as Senator and as President.

title: A diary from Dixie
summary: The diary is edited from a manuscript of 50 notebooks, covering the period of the Civil War, from 1861 to 1865. The author emerges as an intelligent, articulate, well-informed member of Confederate society.

title: Cell 2455: Death Row
summary: An expanded version of the 1954 edition, including material from personal letters, interviews, his other books, and his last long letter of appeal to Governor Pat Brown of California, written by a convicted murderer.

title: Trial by ordeal
summary: A criminal in San Quentin's Death Row describes what it is like living there. The book is essentially an appeal for a reprieve from the death sentence. As a part of his argument, the author discusses capital punishment, sex crimes, and the criminal mentality.

title: Memoirs
summary: Chester is an energetic social activist who served briefly in the army in France in 1918 before World War I ended, worked as a teacher in North Carolina in the 1920's, and as a social worker in Los Angeles until 1935. Determined to be granted his civil rights, he secured a job with the Railway Mail Service, at which he worked nearly twenty years.

title: Oppenheimer: the story of a friendship
summary: Chevalier presents in agonizing detail the story of his friendship with J. Robert Oppenheimer in the late 1930's and early 40's, the subsequent betrayal, and its aftermath.

title: My eyes have a cold nose
summary: A radio script writer writes of becoming blind in middle age and learning to adapt to it. An intense, articulate book.

title: Through the flower: my struggle as a woman artist
summary: Reared in Chicago, Illinois, by communist sympathizer parents, feminist painter and sculptor Judy Chicago was devastated as a teenager by her father's death and similarly distressed by widowhood at 23.

title: Roots in the rock
summary: An artist describes his experiences homesteading on a remote coastal region in Maine.

title: Letters of Lydia Maria Child
summary: The most popular literary woman of her day, she published historical novels, was editor of Juvenile Miscellany, a children's periodical, and became an outspoken supporter of abolition, temperance, prison reform, and equality of civil rights, irrespective of sex.

title: Sails and whales
summary: Whaler captain describes his experiences on several boats fishing for sperm whale in the South Atlantic during the early years of the twentieth century. During World War I and II, he served on cargo ships.

title: The good fight
summary: Her impressions of events and personalities as she perceived them during the 1972 Presidential primary campaign when she ran for the presidency, despite hopeless odds, in order to open up the political system and 'to demonstrate sheer will and refusal to accept the status quo.'

title: Unbought and unbossed
summary: The first Black woman to be elected to the U.S. Congress describes her childhood in Barbados, her education and early political experience, her opposition to the Vietnam War, and many current social issues.

title: Out of step: the autobiography of an individualist
summary: A lively analysis of self and society by a journalist who was a professional individualist.

title: When you and I were young, Nebraska!
summary: Written at age 82, her book describes her arrival in Nebraska at age two, the difficult life of pioneering in the late nineteenth century, the loneliness, boredom, physical suffering, as well as the happier moments of daily life and survival.

title: "Inga-play!": the memoirs of Inga Hoegsbro Christensen
summary: Mrs. Christensen's narrative describes her Danish childhood, her musical training in Copenhagen, her immigration to New York, where she specialized in teaching the works of Scandinavian composers to children of the wealthy. She continued her career as a pianist until she was eighty, with satisfaction and acclaim.

title: Linda: my own story
summary: Her life and loves in Hollywood, including her early romance with Errol Flynn, her marriage to Tyrone Power, and later to Edmund Purdom.

title: Medical missionary to Africa
summary: Christie spent his first fifty years in a fairly conventional American way: he worked his way through medical school, married, raised a family, practiced general medicine in Pontiac, Michigan, and during World War II served in Australia and the South Pacific as a physician with the U.S. Army. In 1964 he went to Zambia as a medical missionary, particularly to treat people with Hansen's disease.

title: One man's gold: the letters and journals of a Forty-Niner
summary: The editor acknowledges that the original documents have been 'quite freely condensed and edited,' augmented by newspaper clippings, and that names have been changed. The letters and journal entries follow Christman's passage from Philadelphia around Cape Horn to California and wealth, and back to Philadelphia. A plainspoken, simple account of one man's three years spent prospecting in the California Gold Rush.

title: My American pilgrimage
summary: Describes the experience of a Macedonian immigrant in and around St. Louis, 1915-1920, his first five years in America, working first in a factory, then with his father laying railroad tracks in the Northern Plains.

title: Road across the Plains 1850: a guide to the route from Mormon Crossing, now Omaha, Nebraska, to the city of Sacramento, California...
publisher: Fred A. Rosenstock, Old West Publishing Co.
summary: Especially valuable because it includes route maps and diary, this is an unusual record of the mass overland immigration to the California gold fields in 1849-50.

title: Life of an American workman
summary: Automobile manufacturer describes his rise from childhood in Kansas in a railroad family to corporate responsibility in the auto industry.

title: Big Sam
summary: With warm nostalgia, Churchill writes of his father, his family, and life in the logging camps of Oregon during the early days of the twentieth century.

title: Bellamy Park: memoirs
summary: Born into an army family, Chynoweth spent his life at various army posts and duties from Cheyenne, Wyoming, and London to the South Pacific. He concentrates especially on describing his experiences during World War II when he commanded the Visayan Force with headquarters in Cebu Island.

title: Backstairs mission in Moscow: the diary of an American worker compiled during three journeys in the forbidden land of the Soviets
summary: Chauffeur to Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, 1936-1938.

title: Detective Marie Cirile; memoirs of a police officer
summary: As a detective on the New York police force for over ten years, she achieved some notoriety for cases she broke wearing various disguises. Her book reveals the tough, squalid side of urban life, especially crimes affecting women.

title: A measurable difference: the reminiscences of Walker Lee Cisler
publisher: University of Michigan, Graduate School of Business Administration
summary: This volume focuses on the world's energy resources (including atomic energy) and technological developments that contribute to the efficient production of inexpensive power. Cisler, president of the Detroit Edison Company, 1959-1973, has an unusual public-spirited, international perspective on energy production.

title: Didn't we have fun!: stories out of a long, fruitful and merry life
summary: Claessens, a Socialist Party leader elected to the New York State Assembly in 1917, thoroughly enjoyed his career as assemblyman, his speechmaking tours of the United States, and the people he met.

title: My fifty years in rodeo: living with cowboys, horses and danger
summary: A rambling account of rodeo announcer and promoter Clancy's fifty years on the rodeo circuit, detailing tragedy, thrills, romance, love, comedy and great sportsmanship.

title: Doctor come quickly
summary: Chronicle of a urologist-surgeon's experiences with patients during thirty years of practice in Seattle, begun after World War I service as Navy doctor.

title: Memoirs of Roger Clap: 1630
summary: A brief description of his good fortune in immigrating to New England seeking religious freedom and settling happily there.

title: Autobiographical sketches and recollections: during thirty-five years' residence in New Orleans
summary: His book describes the life of the city, including tragic epidemics of cholera and yellow fever.

title: Parson Clapp and the Strangers' Church of New Orleans
summary: The autobiographical sketches of a minister in New Orleans, providing a concise view of his life, his ministry, and the city.

title: The Shirley letters from the California mines, 1851-1852
summary: In 23 letters to her sister in New England, the author precisely describes the activities, people, and locale of a California mining camp.

title: One lucky woman
summary: With her husband, journalist Raymond Clapper, she lived and worked as a writer-lecturer amidst the Washington international set from the Harding to the Eisenhower administration.

title: Reminiscences of a centenarian: as told by Amasa Gleason Clark, Veteran of the Mexican War to Cora Tope Clark
summary: Still active at 101, he dictated his recollections of boyhood, friends, and his extensive family.

title: Australian adventure: letters from an ambassador's wife
summary: Out of the need to share her new interests and experiences in Australia as a U.S. ambassador's wife, Anne Clark wrote letters to her friends and family in the United States.

title: Adventures of a home economist
summary: An articulate, comprehensive account of Clark's career as a professor and Dean of the School of Home Economics at Oregon State College, intertwined with a history of the Home Economics movement.

title: Lady and the sharks
summary: The sequel to Lady With a Spear adds twelve years to her memoir as a marine biologist.

title: Lady with a spear
summary: An ichthyologist from New York describes her life-long love affair with fish.

title: Man's reach: the autobiography of Glenn Clark
summary: After describing his family and educational background, Clark tells how the power of prayer was revealed to him.

title: Skylines and detours
summary: An account of the author's life, focusing on his 45 years teaching biology at Pacific Union College.

title: Telling it like it was; a country preacher tells his story
summary: Clark writes with humor and compassion of his busy life as a minister.

title: Carrier admiral
summary: Involved with many of the men and events which made naval aviation history, especially related to the development of the aircraft carrier.

title: Calculated risk: the story of the war in the Mediterranean
summary: Commander of Fifth Army recounts his campaign in Italy.

title: Captain's bride, general's lady: memoirs
summary: A warm personal narrative of army life by a general's wife.

title: Echo in my soul
summary: As Director of Workshops at the Highlander Folk School, she worked to educate the poor and combat segregation.

title: The papers of Walter Clark
summary: The letters, speeches, and articles of a prolific writer who became Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of North Carolina.

title: Village life in America 1852-1872
summary: A record of childhood in ideal conditions amid the village life in New York State.

title: Man of the world: recollections of an irreverent reporter
summary: Recollections of his work as a reporter for The World and his psychoanalytic treatment for alcoholism.

title: Joy of service: memoirs
publisher: Nat'l. Board of the Young Women's Christian Association
summary: A leading figure in YWCA work, Elizabeth Dodge led an active life of Christian service.

title: Back home in Oneida: Herman Clarke and his letters
summary: Clarke recounts his experiences as a soldier during the Civil War through his letters.

title: The letters of James Freeman Clarke to Margaret Fuller
summary: A fascinating collection of letters (1829-1848) from James Clarke to Transcendentalist intellectual Margaret Fuller, his 'first and best friend.' These cover a wide range of topics, focusing on theology, literature, religion, and the personal lives of a host of mutual friends.

title: Over there with O'Ryan's Roughnecks: reminiscences of a Private 1st Class who served in the 27th U.S. Division with the British Forces in Belgium and France
summary: From diaries, memory, and published accounts, Clarke describes the activities of the 27th Division of the U.S. Army, with which he served as a private first class, in World War I. They fought in Belgium, near Ypres, and in France, notably around St. Souplet.

title: Bertha Fidelia: her story
summary: Clawson emphasizes her fifty years of missionary work in Japan, devoted primarily to founding and directing Joshi Sei Gakuin, a Christian girls' school that eventually included an elementary school, high school, and Bible college.

title: The life of Cassius Marcellus Clay: memoirs, writings, and speeches showing his conduct in the overthrow of American slavery, the salvation of the Union, and the restoration of the autonomy of the states
summary: A loosely organized account of his personal and public life, including his early conversion to the anti-slavery movement by William Lloyd Garrison, his political career in Kentucky, his diplomatic appointment in Russia, the context of the Civil War, his divorce, and Reconstruction.

title: The papers of Henry Clay
summary: The letters and personal papers from his developing career as a lawyer and statesman, his growing influence and presidential candidacy, his tenure as Secretary of State, and his position as a political leader.

title: The private correspondence of Henry Clay
summary: Unlike other collections of Clay's papers, this volume includes only his personal correspondence. The editor has chosen to present those letters to and from Clay which shed light on the history of the period without the cautiousness characteristic of more formal public documents.

title: A pioneer grandmother's story of her life
summary: Recollection of a frontier life in the West including her youth, school teaching experiences, wedding trip in Wyoming, and farming in Montana.

title: Selected papers of Will Clayton
summary: A successful business man and 'Southern gentleman,' Clayton served in Washington as Deputy Federal Loan Administrator, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, 1940-1944; Assistant Secretary of State, 1944-1946; Undersecretary of State, 1946-1947; was a prime mover in the Marshall Plan; and was an important delegate to the International Trade and Employment Conference in Geneva in 1947, the International Trade Organization, and the Atlantic Union.

title: The diary of a student at Delaware College: August, 1853, to November, 1854
summary: From a manuscript of the lost original, entries in the diary record Cleaver's daily activities and feelings and include descriptions of the old college building. The editor has provided extensive notes with information from faculty meeting minutes, Athenean Society minutes, and entries from the manuscript diary of his friend David Lewis Mustard.

title: Sea fever: the making of a sailor
summary: After finishing his undergraduate education at Harvard, he shipped out on cargo vessels for eight months, filled with romantic notions of life at sea. The voyage taught him much — that his love for the sea was real and that life at sea in modern times was impractical. That era had passed.

title: Hello, hello, hello, Doc
summary: A collection of humorous, occasionally sentimental anecdotes concerning the author's practice of medicine in rural Virginia for 44 years. The autobiographer finds jokes concerning drunkenness and obstetrics particularly amusing and, though white, often writes in Black dialect.

title: Letters from the Earth
summary: Consists of two main parts: (1) 'Letters from the Earth,' 'Papers of the Adam Family,' and 'Letter to the Earth,' all on Biblical themes, and (2) DeVoto's selections from unpublished Twain manuscripts, some autobiographical in nature.

title: Letters from the Sandwich Islands: written for the Sacramento Union by Mark Twain
summary: In 1866, he convinced the Sacramento Union to pay him for journalistic accounts of his travels to Hawaii, still called the Sandwich Islands. Much of the material in these letters was used in Roughing It and Innocents Abroad.

title: Letters of Quintus Curtius Snodgrass
publisher: University Press in Dallas/Southern Methodist University
summary: A series of letters printed in the New Orleans Daily Crescent in 1861 satirizing military life, previously thought to be written by Mark Twain.

title: The love letters of Mark Twain
summary: Letters to Olivia Langdon from courtship through 34 years of marriage. This edition has a checklist of the letters and a list of persons mentioned in the letters.

title: Mark Twain, business man
summary: Family and business letters, largely concerned with Twain's publishing venture with the editor's father, intended to show Twain was responsible for his business losses.

title: Mark Twain and the three R's: race, religion, revolution and related matters
summary: An anthology of Twain's radical social commentary and other matters selected from autobiographical and other writings.

title: Mark Twain to Mrs. Fairbanks
summary: Author's development during the years between 1867 and settling with his wife in Hartford.

title: Mark Twain to Uncle Remus, 1881-1885
summary: Letters from Clemens to Joel Chandler Harris, mostly concerned with publishing.

title: Mark Twain's autobiography
summary: This work concerns his experiences in the West as a miner and journalist and his later career as a humorist.

title: Mark Twain's correspondence with Henry Huttleston Rogers, 1893-1909
summary: Their letters reveal a business relationship and a friendship Twain valued highly.

title: Mark Twain's letter to William Bowen: Buffalo, February sixth, 1870
summary: A warm, lively comment on his past friendship and recent marriage.

title: Mark Twain's letters
summary: A collection of his letters depicting the rich and varied character of the artist and philosopher.

title: Mark Twain's letters from Hawaii
summary: A collection of travel letters based on his daily log, describing life in the Islands.

title: Mark Twain's letters in the Muscatine Journal
summary: Letters written 1853-1855 for Orion's newspaper in Muscatine, Iowa; his first professional writing.

title: Mark Twain's letters to his publisher, 1867-1894
summary: Includes the complete texts of 290 letters revealing his ambivalence toward business affairs.

title: Mark Twain's letters to Mary
summary: Letters from Twain to Mary Benjamin Rogers, expressing many moods in response to her.

title: Mark Twain's notebook
summary: A set of journals or commonplace books where Twain recorded various thoughts from 1865-1904.

title: Mark Twain's notebooks and journals
summary: A wealth of information about Twain's multifarious literary projects, business ventures, and personal life.

title: Mark Twain's travels with Mr. Brown, being heretofore uncollected sketches
summary: Weekly letters for the Aha California newspaper covering six months of the author's travels between the time he left San Francisco until he sailed from New York in 1867 on the journey described in Innocents Abroad.

title: The pattern for Mark Twain's, Roughing It; letters from Nevada by Samuel and Orion Clemens, 1861-1862
summary: Written by Twain before he had any notion of a literary career to Gate City, a newspaper in Keokuk, Iowa, describing what he observed in the frontier mining country around Carson City.

title: Selected Mark Twain-Howells letters, 1872-1910
summary: A selection of their letters from the previous two-volume edition (Harvard Univ. Press, 1960), with the addition of two letters discovered since 1960, revealing the rich, enduring friendship of two outstanding literary figures.

title: Letters of Grover Cleveland: 1850-1908
summary: Selected from the mass of his correspondence, this edition portrays more of the political than the private man, essentially, Nevins says, because Cleveland chose to reveal so little of his personal life and feelings.

title: A human touch
summary: A collection of parable-essays about his parishioners, primarily in Peru, where he was a Maryknoll missionary. His gently pious prose focuses particularly on the very old and very young.

title: Generations: a memoir
summary: A Black poet describes ways in which her identity grew within the facts and legends of her parents and ancestors, all storytellers who passed on the pain of slavery and the self-respect to survive it.

title: When the heavens frowned: an autobiography
summary: Youth and teaching experience in Tennessee; then life as a meteorologist in Galveston, Texas.

title: Pawns of dishonor
summary: Clodfelter devotes all but one chapter of this long book to his experiences as an infantryman in the 101st U.S. Army Airborne Division in the Vietnam War, 1964-1967. It is an anti-war book which paradoxically acknowledges his desire for the thrill and glory of battle.

title: This for remembrance
summary: Clooney writes with candor about her mental breakdown and institutionalization, partially brought on by her presence at the assassination of her friend Bobby Kennedy. She describes her Irish Catholic upbringing, marriage to Jose Ferrer, her rise to fame as a singer and actress, and finally her struggle back to sanity and happiness.

title: Let the hammer down!
summary: The title means 'do the best you can, with maximum effort,' and Clower's anecdotes, told in down-home folksy Southern humor and dialect, are intended to make this point. He is a Christian moralist in a comic vein and from that perspective describes his tours, TV appearances, lectures, and people he has met.

title: The witness and I
summary: A career diplomat, he was appointed director of the State Department's Office of Chinese Affairs in 1950. In 1951 he was accused of being a communist sympathizer by Whittaker Chambers. His book describes the impact of McCarthyism and the Cold War on the State Department, the Foreign Service, and his life.

title: Main Street beat
summary: Experience as a journalist in Rochester, New York, 1910-1947.

title: All people are famous (instead of an autobiography)
summary: A stage director, critic, and founder of the Group Theatre recalls his encounters with many of the great creative people of the twentieth century and his own part in shaping the cultural history of America.

title: Black man in red Cuba
summary: In 1964 Clytus arrived in Cuba determined to leave the capitalist United States behind forever. After three years of attempting to be accepted, he returned disillusioned to America 'convinced that a 'Negro' Communist is an absurdity and a black Communist is an impossibility,' and that communism exploits all, 'rich and poor, who do not dance to the dictatorial tune of its ruling hierarchy.'

title: The view from here
summary: Reflections on his childhood, his warm relation to his parents, the coming of the automobile, of World War I, and a personal view of his experience in Paris during the Twenties, which he saw as an era of hope.

title: Maine memories
summary: N/A

title: Maine ways
summary: Contented with her life, Coatsworth writes pleasant, low-keyed stories about daily events, eccentric characters, and the ways of nature down East in her beloved Maine.

title: Personal geography: almost an autobiography
publisher: A Janet Greene Book/Stephen Greene Press
summary: Coatsworth, poet and author of a Newbery award-winning children's book, has assembled a collection of excerpts from her notebooks and accounts of travel to Europe and the Far East, bridged by poetry.

title: Woman into space: the Jerrie Cobb story
summary: After a brief description of her childhood in Oklahoma and her early interest in flying, she describes the rigorous training and testing program she passed in order to be considered for the position of first female astronaut.

title: Great spirit
summary: A golf pro recalls his difficult childhood years in various Indian schools and his career in professional sports.

title: My life in poetry
summary: A thoughtful account of his development as a poet and an articulate defense of traditional verse against modern verse.

title: From the life of a researcher
summary: In his narrative autobiography, Coblentz provides family background and descriptions of four decades of research in physics.

title: Alvin Langdon Coburn, photographer; an autobiography
summary: This book combines Coburn's story as a photographer with many of his photographs.

title: Walt Coburn: Western word wrangler; an autobiography
summary: Coburn, a prolific writer, published over one thousand short stories in popular Western pulp magazines.

title: The first hundred years of Nino Cochise; the untold story of an Apache Indian chief
summary: The grandson of Chief Cochise tells the story of the Chiricahui Apache Indians led by his mother.

title: Stars at noon
summary: The author describes her poverty-stricken youth in Florida and her career as a cosmetologist and aviator.

title: FBI man: a personal history
summary: An account of Cochran's pre-World War II years as an FBI Special Agent.

title: The Cochran family book of ski racing
summary: Cochran devotes the first third of the book to an autobiographical account of his family's passion for skiing.

title: Theodore D.A. Cockerell: letters from West Cliff, Colorado, 1887-1889
summary: These attractive letters, enhanced by the naturalist's drawings of settings, animals, and insects, discuss Cockerell's life and scientific investigations in West Cliff, Colorado, where he was sent from England to recuperate from tuberculosis.

title: The life and times of an involuntary genius
summary: A poet born and brought up under the repression of a communist regime, Codrescu fled from Transylvania after being expelled from the university and sent a notice of military conscription.

title: Letters from Buffalo Bill: taken from the originals now on exhibit at the Wonderland Museum, Billings, Montana
summary: Buffalo Bill Cody's letters (1876-1916) to his 'mother-sister,' Julia Cody Goodman, discuss business matters pertinent to his Wild West Shows and investments, good and bad.

title: Life and adventures of Buffalo Bill: Colonel William F. Cody
summary: A myth in his own time, he includes stories of his childhood in Kansas, his service on the Pony Express, his career as a hunter and Indian scout, and his touring Wild West Show.

title: Life of Hon. William F. Cody: Known as Buffalo Bill, the famous hunter, scout, and guide: an autobiography
summary: This Bison Book edition claims to be the first complete reprinting of Cody's original 1879 autobiography — a partly plagiarized book that was frequently modified by many ghost writers.

title: Young man in Vietnam
summary: A striking account of his experience as a Marine lieutenant in Vietnam reveals the horror and confusion of a strange war in a strange time.

title: Frontier fighter: the autobiography of George W. Coe, who fought and rode with Billy the Kid
summary: Recollections by Billy the Kid's best friend of the excitement and hardships of frontier life during the settlement of the Western territory, as outlaw then as homesteader.

title: Reminiscences of Levi Coffin
publisher: Arno Press and the New York Times
summary: An abolitionist who assisted nearly three thousand runaway slaves to escape was called the President of the Underground Railway. His book tells of many dramatic escapes, of mobs and riots, of risks incurred by the friends of slaves.

title: Lost paradise: a boyhood on a Maine coast farm
summary: A poet's third person narrative describes his Maine boyhood with affection for its simplicity, the warmth of his close family life, the strength of their New England values.

title: Once to every man: a memoir
summary: Coffin aspired to be a concert pianist before World War II made him a Russian Liaison Officer, followed by Yale, Union Theological Seminary, and a stint training Russian agents for the CIA.

title: America in the rough: the autobiography of W.M. (Bill) Coffman
summary: The youthful, often rowdy adventures on land and sea of the man who became a promoter for the Shriners, raising millions to establish homes for crippled children.

title: Memoirs of Mrs. Coghlan
publisher: The New York Times and Arno Press
summary: The daughter of Major Moncrieffe includes in her memoirs descriptions of America during the Revolutionary War.

title: A Canterbury Tale: experiences and reflections: 1916-1976
summary: Cogley reflects on his spiritual and theological discomfort in a church unresponsive to changing times, which gradually determined his conversion to Episcopalianism in 1973.

title: Twenty years on Broadway, and the years it took to get there: the true story of a trouper's life from the cradle to the closed shop
summary: In his day, his book might have been called scrappy, sometimes fresh. It conveys a sense of what Broadway and New York were like during the early twentieth century, focusing on the theatrical life and family of an actor, composer, and playwright.

title: They builded better than they knew
summary: General Counsel for the New York Port Authority for over twenty years, an important contributor to labor law, author of Commercial Arbitration and the Law, describes the times, people, and events during his fifty years as a public servant.

title: Dreamer's journey: autobiography
summary: Following a description of childhood in Russia and adolescence in New York's East Side, the book primarily describes Cohen's development as a philosopher and teacher at New York City College and Harvard and his important contributions to social, legal and scientific philosophy.

title: Portrait of a philosopher: Morris R. Cohen in life and letters
summary: The letters, diaries, and other papers of a prominent philosopher at Harvard, edited by his daughter to depict his rich and varied character in his words and those of his friends, including Albert Einstein, Felix Frankfurter, and Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.

title: Honorable men: my life with the CIA
summary: Colby's account of his directorship of the CIA reads like the penultimate spy novel, as he details the complex, violence-ridden undercover operations.

title: Autobiography of Charles Francis Colcord: 1859-1934
summary: Recognized for many years as 'First Citizen of Oklahoma City' and then as 'First Citizen of Oklahoma,' Colcord's history as cowboy, rancher, sheriff, real estate and oil executive parallels the fortunes of the state in its progress from wild, unsettled early days through the development of its wealth and resources and the evolving of stability.

title: Victorian lady on the Texas frontier: the journal of Ann Raney Coleman
summary: Coleman recalls nineteenth-century Texas — the rough terrain, the Indians, the abundance of men and scarcity of women, the Negro slaves, the rugged transportation, and personal poverty.

title: Experiences of an Arkansas backwoodsman
summary: Coleman tells of his childhood in rural Arkansas, focusing on daily activities such as farming, hunting, and going to school, punctuated by the circus, pranks, and accidents. He then describes his career as a professor of physical education and coach at Georgetown (Kentucky) College, the University of Akron, State College at Minot, North Dakota, and the University of Nevada at Reno.

title: Blue-collar journal: a college president's sabbatical
summary: The journal kept for eight weeks during spring of 1973 when Coleman, on sabbatical from his presidency of Haverford College, worked at blue collar jobs in order 'to break the lockstep for a while.' He started as a ditch digger laying sewer pipe, then was a porter-dishwasher and salad man in a restaurant, and finally a trash collector. His experiences were both amusing and instructive.

title: I buried Custer: the diary of Pvt. Thomas W. Coleman, 7th U.S. Cavalry
summary: This twelve-page diary provides a terse account of Private Coleman's participation in the Battle of the Little Big Horn, June 25-26, 1876. The rest of the book provides a biography of Coleman and amplifies the historical information about the battle and General Custer.

title: From every zenith a memoir, and some essays on life and thought
summary: A committed humanist writes of his life as a social scientist devoted to the struggles of American Indians, with considerable analysis of government policy on Indian affairs.

title: Soul rush: the odyssey of a young woman of the '70s
summary: A wealthy flower child of the late Sixties and Seventies writes to demonstrate how much she has done, and how well. She dropped out of several schools, was raped while hitching, had a number of casual love affairs, and had been a disciple of Guru Marahj Ji and a organizer of Divine Light Mission, from which she resigned in order to write this book.

title: Oh, didn't he ramble: the life story of Lee Collins
summary: One of the great jazz cornet players, first in New Orleans and later in Chicago, started to dictate and write his story in 1943. Later the material was updated and edited to form this chronological account. Included are a discography and a record made by Collins of several performances, 1948-1953.

title: Carrying the fire: an astronaut's journeys
summary: Astronaut Collins, who orbited the moon while the first moon-landers Armstrong and Aldrin walked on it, traces his participation in the selection process, the training, the Gemini 10 flight, and the moon orbit. He explains how the machines operated and what it was like living in the artificial, high-pressure environment. An appendix includes information about U.S. manned space flights up to 1974.

title: Out of the depths; the story of a priest-patient in a mental hospital
summary: A description of the ordeal of a young priest who worked his way through emotional illness. He writes with careful detail of his learning experience acquired through therapy.

title: Captain Moses Rich Colman: master mariner, Scituate, Massachusetts, 1807-1872; letters of a Yankee clipper ship captain
summary: Excerpts from his letters depict the life of a typical seaman in nineteenth-century New England.

title: Born again
summary: Colson, a talented, ambitious lawyer, joined President Nixon's inner circle as one who ruthlessly cut through legal red tape to solve political problems. His illegal actions led to a jail term, but a religious conversion enabled him not only to survive but to prevail.

title: Three years in California: together with excerpts from the author's Deck and Port, covering his arrival in California and a selection of his letters from Monterey
summary: Responsible for the jurisdiction of a large territory of California around Monterey from 1846 to 1849, a naval officer and chaplain describes military operations and the daily life of a diverse population living there at the time.

title: Life and the dream. Revised with additional material
summary: Before moving to America in 1914, Colum was active in the literary circles of the Abbey Theatre in Dublin, in Paris, and in London. Her book includes rich descriptions of her intellectual growth in the world of letters.

title: Sixty years with men and machines: an autobiography
summary: Describes his experience in the world of invention, machinery, and production from 1884-1944, including his participation in the development of the bicycle, the automobile, the airplane, and the railroad locomotive.

title: Myself: the autobiography of John R. Commons
summary: The informal story of a labor historian and economist who held positions on numerous state and federal boards and commissions and whose economic ideas expressed in his writing and teaching have had considerable influence in shaping modern economic theory.

title: Atomic quest: a personal narrative
summary: "A personal story of the release of the atom's energy," by a physicist who was at the center of atomic research through World War II and after.

title: Memories of a librarian
summary: A librarian in Seattle and Nebraska discusses libraries, other librarians, and recounts parts of speeches given at various library conferences.

title: A girl of the Eighties at college and at home, from the family letters of Charlotte Howard Conant and from other records
summary: As much a family portrait as autobiography, this collage of reminiscences and letters describes the New England girlhood and college life of a woman who was to teach, work in a law office, serve as charity supervisor, and finally became headmistress of the Walnut Hill School for Girls in Natick, Massachusetts.

title: My several lives: memoirs of a social inventor
summary: Conant's lives include several positions of importance including the presidency of Harvard University. He 'invented' scholarships, professorships, MAT degrees for future teachers, the Nieman Defense Research Committee, the Committee on Present Danger, and the Education Commission of the States.

title: The Eddie Condon scrapbook of jazz
summary: A scrapbook of photos and clippings with explanations and narrative becomes an autobiographical account of a half century of the jazz age by one of its outstanding participants.

title: We called it music; a generation of jazz
summary: First-class jazz musicians are few; Condon is one of the best. Here are his memories and assessments of his fellow musicians.

title: And then we moved to Rossenarra; or, the art of emigrating
summary: The travels of a peripatetic American family which has moved about 29 times — to Ireland, Spain, France, Switzerland, Mexico and back to Ireland several times.

title: Jocko
summary: Conlan describes his career in baseball, first as a player in the AA League and for the Chicago White Sox, 1919-1936, followed by 25 years as an umpire in the major leagues...

title: My name is Tom Connally
summary: A former senator from Texas discusses his political career from 1915 to 1952...

title: Arkansas
summary: Dictated to his daughter when he was 82, the book describes his experience on the Arkansas River and in Arizona Territory...

title: Voices offstage: a book of memoirs
summary: The memoir of an era of outstanding American theater and literary life reflected in the life of an outstanding playwright...

title: Oil business as I saw it: half a century with Sinclair
summary: A petroleum executive describes his beginnings in the oil industry, his association with the Sinclair Oil Company in Oklahoma...

title: No excuse to lose: winning yacht races
summary: Conner remains a determined amateur in boat racing and has sailed and won in America's Cup...

title: What Father forbad
summary: In a sprightly account, the socialite wife of an Army general describes an active life including entertainment...

title: Fun while it lasted
summary: At nineteen he jumped into a Mexican bullring on a dare...

title: Stop-time
summary: A re-creation of Conroy's childhood and youth, ranging from rural Chula Vista, Florida...

title: The enchanted islands
summary: Pioneering for five years in the Galapagos Islands (1937-1942).

title: Return from the Pole
summary: Written between 1930 and 1935, Dr. Cook's narrative describes his party's dangerous journey back from the North Pole...

title: Fifty years a forester
summary: Cook began his forestry career in 1907 when Theodore Roosevelt and Gifford Pinchot were leading the forest conservation movement...

title: Fifty years on the old frontier: as cowboy, hunter, guide, scout, and ranchman
summary: Cook went west, learned to be an expert cowboy, hunter, and guide...

title: The advisor
summary: For 25 months he was stationed in Vietnam...

title: Letters of a Ticonderoga farmer: selections from the correspondence of William H. Cook and his wife with their son, Joseph Cook, 1851-1885
summary: Farm life in Ticonderoga; son's experience at Andover, Yale, Harvard; and his career as a lecturer for YMCA.

title: The other Mrs. Simpson: postscript to the love story of the century
summary: A former alcoholic socialite in the 1930’s and 1940’s writes of her unfulfilled relationship with her sister, Mary, who married Emest A. Simpson, former husband of the Duchess of Windsor.

title: Scientific blacksmith: autobiography
summary: Boyhood in western New York; training at the U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis; professor, then Dean of the College of Engineering, University of Michigan, 1881-1928.

title: Da Capo: a paper read before the Mothers' Club, Cambridge, Mass., March 13, 1951
publisher: Library of Congress, Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation
summary: Coolidge describes her activities as a patron of music, 1916-1950, particularly of the Berkshire Quartet and Berkshire Festival, and of concerts in the Library of Congress.

title: Trial and triumph, or, I never gave up, never!
summary: Published in the early era of Women's Liberation, this book tells the story of a woman widowed during World War I who kept working, established an independent business, remarried, and developed a life of contentment, all 'on her own.'

title: Attica diary
summary: A day-by-day account of Coons's fifteen-month's term in Attica prison, his thoughts, conflicts, and rage at the inhuman debasement of prison life.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore Cooper
summary: Despite the fact that much Cooper material was destroyed, his character is revealed in his extant letters.

title: The letters and journals of James Fenimore Cooper
publisher: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: These six volumes of his letters and journals, 1800-1851, have as their central theme his relationship to his country and record almost every phase of American life.

title: Kent Cooper and the Associated Press: an autobiography
summary: Much of his sixty-year career in journalism was devoted to organizing the Associated Press.

title: Dark lady of the silents; my life in early Hollywood
summary: Her book describes her life in early Hollywood as a star and later as a friend and participant in the film world.

title: Letters and papers of John Singleton Copley and Henry Pelham, 1739-1776
summary: These papers provide interesting information on the painter's early work.

title: Psychic summer
summary: An interior decorator describes fourteen Ouija board seances at Fire Island in the summer of 1976 that conjured up tormented spirits.

title: From dawn to sunset
summary: A sculptor discusses his life and work, primarily in San Antonio.

title: As I look back
summary: Corey became an ordained Disciple of Christ minister and traveled to Africa, the Orient, Latin America, India, and Palestine.

title: Cowboy Pete: the autobiography of Major General Charles H. Corlett
summary: Raised in the cattle country of Colorado, Corlett attended West Point and served in World War I.

title: Sheepherder's gold
summary: Writing in language surprisingly formal in comparison with the rough-and-ready prospector's life he describes, Cornelius tells of the searches he and others made for gold in New Mexico and Colorado during the early part of the twentieth century. Forgotten or misplaced caches; friendly and hostile Ute Indians, Mexicans, and rural prospectors; and rugged terrain and weather complicate the quest.

title: Anatomist at large: an autobiography and selected essays
summary: Corner's details of his student years at Johns Hopkins and his career in biology as a professor and physician. Citing many distinguished members of the profession, he gives a short history of medical advancements in the first half of this century.

title: Miss Aunt Nellie: the autobiography of Nellie C. Cornish
summary: Cornish traces the development of the Cornish School in Seattle, from its birth as a school for music lessons to an academy offering dance, puppetry, and drama as well as instrumental instruction. She recalls many of the 20,000 students she knew in her 25 years with the school, emphasizing their successes all over the world.

title: Bush rebels: a personal account of Black revolt in Africa
summary: A white journalist has recorded her experiences and observations while living with Black guerrilla revolutionaries fighting for their independence from Portugal in Mozambique, East Africa, and Portuguese Guinea, West Africa.

title: In spite of the handicap: an autobiography
summary: Born in Michigan and educated at Northwestern University, he became a journalist, a poet, and a Baptist minister. His book describes the difficulties faced by Northern Blacks and by intelligent Blacks whose early success made their brothers uneasy.

title: Off and running
summary: This is the tape-recorded transcription of Corum's life, focusing on his 35 years as a sports columnist for the New York Journal. His specialty was baseball, though he also covered several Kentucky Derby races and some boxing matches. He fought in France in World War I and served as a war correspondent in World War II.

title: Cosell
summary: An interesting account of his life in sports, especially as a sportscaster on radio and television. The book begins with the 1972 Olympics in Munich, where he recorded the scene as Palestinian guerrillas held Israeli athletes hostage. His book frequently focuses on the heroism of athletes.

title: Like it is
summary: Cosell thrives on being a controversial and abrasive sports broadcaster. In this sequel to his Cosell, he continues to follow his self-proclaimed goals of the pursuit of truth and the correction of wrong-doing. He writes of people he respects, answers questions he finds stimulating, and discusses his reactions to issues in sports.

title: Cocktails for two: the many lives of giant songwriter
summary: A composer of over 500 tunes for films and Broadway musicals describes his fifty-year career in show business which also involved stints as a vaudevillian, singer, piano player, band leader, and film producer. In the mid-1950's, when music moved from big bands to rock, Coslow became a successful investment service advisor as publisher of Indicator Digest.

title: Wanted
summary: Coss ecstatically recounts his experience as a born-again Christian, which began in 1969 when he was converted in prison. A twelve-year record of 33 arrests for car theft, assault and battery, and other crimes had landed him in various detention homes and prisons, but Christianity and marriage to another born-again Christian completely reformed him; he now runs a full-time ministry for prisoners.

title: Spark for my people: the sociological autobiography of a Negro teacher
summary: A Black teacher who lived in Virginia, Kentucky, and Alabama describes her growing racial and humanitarian awareness and how her teaching developed from such growth.

title: In the Senate: amidst the conflict and turmoil
summary: Cotton covers the years he was a U.S. Senator and Congressman, from Truman to Ford. He discusses presidential policy, the problems in the land of politics. But basically, Cotton uses this book as a soapbox to propound his conservative views: he especially rants against government spending and Democratic presidents.

title: Basketball is my life
summary: Basketball player for the Boston Celtics describes his career in the game.

title: Heart is the teacher
summary: A teacher and principal in the New York City public schools for 45 years describes his childhood in Italy, his adolescence as an immigrant in East Harlem, and his devotion to education in immigrant neighborhoods.

title: Friends and memories
publisher: Reynal and Co., William Morrow and Co.
summary: Cowles, an energetic journalist and jet-setter, describes her passion for travel and flying and her interest in art, including publishing the arty Flair for one year and painting. Among famous people she has met are Queen Elizabeth II, Bernard Baruch, Eva Peron, and Harry Truman.

title: Russell Cowles: forty-eight reproductions of paintings and twenty letters by the artist
summary: This volume consists of a 27-page biographical and critical introduction, 47 reproductions of Cowles' paintings, followed by 24 pages of letters to his representatives explaining the way he painted some of the pictures.

title: The dream of the golden mountains: remembering the 1930's
summary: This sequel to Exile's Return focuses on New York in the 1930's as the focal point of left-wing politics, viewed by Cowley from his position as editor of The New Republic.

title: Letters and memories: 1944-1962
summary: The letters that passed between novelist William Faulkner and the literary critic Cowley over eighteen years, with connecting narrative supplied by Cowley.

title: The view from 80
summary: After writing an article for Life Magazine on growing old, Cowley expanded it into this book, adding examples, anecdotes and observations as a personal message to his peers.

title: Journey through my years
summary: Describes fifty years as journalist and public servant, including experience as Governor of Ohio and Democratic nominee for President.

title: The sphinx wore an orchid: memoirs of Marian Cox
summary: Cox writes about her life as a 'feminine parasite,' and her experiences with family hardships and exploration of societal expectations.

title: Sunward I've climbed: a personal narrative of peace and war
summary: Craig devoted himself to airplanes and the U.S. Air Service/Air Corps, eventually becoming commandant of the National War College.

title: Storm and sorrow in the High Pamirs
summary: A story of adventure and tragedy climbing mountains in the Pamirs Range during a 1974 expedition.

title: We shall rise
summary: Mrs. Crain tells of the personal problems faced by her family, including mental illness and alcoholism, and how her faith and nursing career helped her cope.

title: Life and letters of Christopher Pearse Cranch, by his daughter Leonora Cranch Scott
summary: After a career as a minister, Cranch became a poet and painter, his life documented through letters and autobiography combined by his daughter.

title: Clinton Crane's yachting memories
summary: A naval architect describes his sixty-year career and provides a history of twentieth-century yacht design and racing intertwined with autobiography.

title: Letters of Hart Crane, 1916-1932
summary: The poet's letters are arranged chronologically and geographically, primarily discussing daily events and literature, many of which are addressed to his mother.

title: Letters
summary: This scholarly edition of Crane's lifetime correspondence includes letters to and from Crane and his relatives, publishers, and other authors, including Joseph Conrad and H.G. Wells. These cover his career as a war correspondent and author.

title: Reports of war: war dispatches; great battles of the world
summary: This volume includes Crane's known newspaper war dispatches from Greece, Florida, Cuba, Puerto Rico, and England, as well as his 'Great Battles of the World.'

title: Stephen Crane in the West and Mexico
summary: Seventeen newspaper articles written by Stephen Crane during a trip in 1895, covering his experiences in Nebraska, New Orleans, Texas, and Mexico.

title: Stephen Crane's love letters to Nellie Crouse
summary: The letters were written primarily from New York to Nellie Crouse and cover Crane's experiences, including his trip to Mexico.

title: The autobiography of a Winnebago Indian
summary: Written around 1917, the book is a series of confessions about his life as a drunkard and womanizer who eventually returned to his true religion, the Peyote Cult.

title: Again calls the owl
summary: An account of her journey to becoming a writer and her life experiences starting from her college days during World War I.

title: One naked individual: my fifty years in the theatre
summary: Crawford's unsentimental account of her fifty-year career in theater provides insight into the complexities of producing and directing plays.

title: Stay with it, Van: from the diary of Mississippi's first lady mayor
summary: Covers her time as the first female mayor in Mississippi, along with snippets of her childhood and college experiences.

title: A portrait of Joan: the autobiography of Joan Crawford
summary: An autobiographical account detailing Joan Crawford's challenging childhood and her multifaceted career in Hollywood.

title: The West of the Texas Kid, 1881-1910: recollections of Thomas Edgar Crawford, cowboy, gun fighter, rancher, hunter, miner
summary: An entertaining collection of stories and yarns reflecting 'The Texas Kid's' life experiences in the American West.

title: Rebel at large: recollections of fifty crowded years
summary: Creel's account reflects his journalism career and the social political changes he witnessed.

title: Blood and grits
summary: Essays that evoke Crews's earthy Southern personality while capturing diverse experiences.

title: Childhood: the biography of a place
summary: A re-creation of Crews's childhood in Georgia, blending tough family dynamics with the richness of friendships.

title: George Crile; an autobiography
summary: The remarkable career of an outstanding surgeon and medical researcher who was one of four founders of the Cleveland Clinic.

title: Adventures of Davy Crockett: told mostly by himself
summary: This book concerns Davy Crockett as a frontiersman in Tennessee and Texas.

title: A narrative of the life of David Crockett
summary: Narrative of his life published in 1834; account of his tour to the north and down east, and his exploits and adventures in Texas.

title: Troubadour; a different battlefield
summary: A modestly told and heartwarming account of the author's tour as a 'troubadour of goodwill.'

title: Mariemont
summary: The American dream, embodied in a house, is related in George Crompton's account of the family estate.

title: General George Crook: his autobiography
summary: Covers the period from graduation from West Point to after the Civil War, leading campaigns against the Indians.

title: Call me lucky
summary: A Hollywood actor recalls his Catholic upbringing, his career in radio, on stage and screen, and his family life until 1952.

title: Passionate years
summary: A poet and editor explains what it was like being a member of the Lost Generation.

title: The last stitch
summary: Crosthwait describes his boyhood, medical education, and career as a surgeon in Texas.

title: My life on the road: the autobiography of Cleo Crouch
summary: A trucker recounts building a trucking line and retiring in Florida.

title: Forbidden diary: a record of wartime internment, 1941-1945
summary: Crouter's secret diary of internment focuses on social organization, family life, and relations with Japanese captors.

title: Frontier doctor: the autobiography of a pioneer on the frontier of public health
summary: A doctor in Dodge City, Kansas describes his career and contributions to public health.

title: Crying Wind
summary: A halfbreed describes her life on a Kickapoo reservation and adjustment to city life.

title: Always on the run
summary: Insights from two Miami Dolphins running backs about football and their lives.

title: The autobiography of Delfina Cuero
summary: Cuero reflects on her life as a hunter-gatherer in the Diegueno traditions.

title: Rumba is my life
