summary: In the Forties he became part of the Hollywood myth, famous as a band leader, composer, entertainer. His book is witty and intelligent.

title: American pastor in Rome
summary: A charming account of Father Cunningham's boyhood and early career as a pharmacist in Danbury, Connecticut, followed by 25 years as a pastor, missionary in the United States, and Navy chaplain in World War II. Most of the emphasis, however, is on Cunningham's twelve-year pastorate at Santa Susanna, the American Catholic Church in Rome, which he, his parishioners, and the Romans thoroughly enjoyed.

title: I'd do it again: a record of all my uproarious years
summary: The story of his political career in Massachusetts, where he served as mayor of Boston and governor, by a colorful and unpredictable statesman.

title: George Curry, 1861-1947: an autobiography
summary: A frontier storekeeper in his teens, he sought work and adventure in New Mexico, joined Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders which took him to the Philippines, and returned to devote his energy to the development of New Mexico, where he served as governor and elder statesman.

title: Early letters to John S. Dwight: Brook Farm and Concord
summary: Interesting because of his early years with Ralph Waldo Emerson and Brook Farm, his letters to his close friend also reflect his philosophy, his views on major issues of the day, and everyday details.

title: Recollections of a scientist: an autobiography by Harvey Lincoln Curtis
summary: Curtis focuses on his work for the National Bureau of Standards, where he was employed as a physicist for 47 years concentrating on ballistics and insulation. He describes his trip to Europe on ballistics matters during World War I. A ballistics table and Curtis family genealogy are appended.

title: Keep off my turf
summary: Written because 'there's too much anti-football sentiment in the air these days,' the book is a celebration of the game and his life in it.

title: Other people's letters: a memoir
summary: Had Proust lived longer, Curtiss would have been his Boswell. Drawing heavily upon her own journal and her letters to others, Curtiss writes of the years in which she collected Proust's letters for publication, drifting among the elite of Paris searching out manuscripts and letters.

title: Journal and letters: of the late Samuel Curwen, an American refugee in England from 1775 to 1784
summary: An American loyalist, he left for England in 1775. His detailed journals describe the London political circles, travel conditions, and everyday routines in England during the American Revolution.

title: My adventures in Zuni
summary: Cushing, a young ethnologist with the Bureau of Ethnology at the Smithsonian Institution, lived with the Zunis, 1879-1884, studying and recording their culture, myths, and folktales in this thoroughly fascinating volume, even though he violated Zuni trust in publishing their secret legends.

title: Plenty of room and air
summary: Cushman tells a series of extended anecdotes, mostly good-natured, about his childhood in Box Elder and Zurich, Montana. Through accounts of wheat farming, chicken raising, and escapades with horses, cows, and rattlesnakes, he conveys some of the rough-and-ready atmosphere of the homesteader's life in the West that was gradually being tamed. Cushman describes his parents as hardy, pragmatic, fearless, happy-go-lucky.

title: Father Culligan; selfless shepherd
summary: He was educated and ordained a Jesuit priest in Connecticut. In 1950 he was sent to the Philippines where after a few years of parish work he was assigned to the Ateneo de Manila as student counselor and professor of theology and psychology. This is a collection of his letters, homilies, talks, and tributes by several close friends, one of whom edited this volume.

title: The Curtis-Culligan story: from Cyrus to Horace to Joe
summary: The controversial former president of Curtis Publishing Company, who battled to save the company from bankruptcy and himself from character assassination and charges of mismanagement, tells what happened to Curtis between 1945 and 1962 and his part in the events.

title: Occupation: angel
summary: Along with entertaining stories about the Broadway theatrical world, the author explains something of the workings of stage production and the backing of plays.

title: Your affectionate husband J.F. Culver: letters written during the Civil War
publisher: Friends of the University of Iowa Libraries
summary: This book contains 233 intimate and loving letters from a newly married soldier to his young wife, dealing with his reactions to war and information about the many friends and relatives from his hometown, Pontiac, Illinois.

title: The genteel gentile: letters of Elizabeth Cumming, 1857-1858
summary: Eighteen letters written by the loyal wife of the first non-Mormon governor of Utah reveal the fundamental opposition between the Mormon and gentile worlds.

title: Eimi
summary: Ostensibly a travel diary, this book shows the author's experimentation with compressed language, dislocated syntax, and typographical variations.

title: Selected letters of E.E. Cummings
summary: A selection of some 260 letters written over a sixty-year span to family and friends, showcasing the range of emotions and thoughts of this complex, gifted writer.

title: My days with the diesel: the memoirs of Clessie L. Cummins, father of the highway diesel
summary: Cummins relates his experiences during 48 years of banking and his assessments of his associates.

title: Marine flyer in France: the diary of Captain Alfred A. Cunningham, November 1917-January 1918
publisher: History and Museums Division Headquarters, U.S. Marine Corps.
summary: He kept this diary of his tour of the battlefronts and flying fields of France, after which he organized the Marine Corps Aeronautic Company.

title: Of battles long ago: memoirs of an American ambulance driver in World War I
summary: An American volunteer ambulance driver for the French army in World War I describes hospitals and rescue missions at the front lines.

title: No time for rest
summary: In a lifetime marked by enthusiasm and devotion to hard work, Cutler describes his experience as a student, a lawyer, a military officer, and a government official.

title: Mighty timber
summary: Half of his book is a nostalgic recollection of his early rural life in southern Ohio; the rest depicts his education and professional life.

title: Across the years: memories of a Virginian
summary: A Pulitzer Prize for Journalism winner reminisces about his childhood and career, chronicling the changing South.

title: Banker Dahl of South Dakota: an autobiography
summary: A banker relates his experiences during his 48 years in banking and his assessments of his associates.

title: Because I was flesh: the autobiography of Edward Dahlberg
summary: Colored by background reality of urban life, this is a son's portrait of his relationship with his remarkable mother.

title: The confessions of Edward Dahlberg
summary: As writer and critic he came into contact with many others among the intelligentsia of the Twenties and Thirties. In remarkable aphoristic prose, he describes Edmund Wilson, Gertrude Stein, Charles Olson, and others.

title: Epitaphs of our times: the letters of Edward Dahlberg
summary: A sampling from the many letters he wrote to literary and intellectual friends including Theodore Dreiser, Robert M. Hutchins, Herbert Read, William Carlos Williams, and Allen Tate, among others. The letters are grouped according to their recipients rather than by chronology.

title: The spider and the marionettes: an autobiography
summary: An unusually egocentric, disturbing autobiography in which the author, a night club, radio, and television singer, discusses the vicissitudes of his career and unsatisfying relationships with women and men — mostly the result of his volatile temper and unstable personality.

title: Oklahoma lawyer
summary: Charming story of his life and career as an attorney in rural Oklahoma, by a man who became a district judge and spent most of his life in Guymon.

title: Father feelings
summary: Clergyman and family counselor Daley has written a series of vignettes of life with his family — wife Patti, adolescent daughters Alison and Shannon, and young son Jad — which become parables about parenthood.

title: Diary of George Mifflin Dallas: United States Minister to Russia, 1837-1839
summary: An interesting record of diplomatic life in the early nineteenth century and the court of the Czar.

title: September child: the story of Jean Dalrymple, by herself
summary: Widely respected as a theatrical director and producer, she recounts her experiences directing various performances, packed with activity and celebrity.

title: Forged in strong fires: the early life and experiences of John Edward Dalton
summary: World-wide travels of a cowboy, boxer, and adventurer, around the turn of the century.

title: My musical life
summary: His life in music began in Silesia, where his family was visited by Liszt and Saint-Saens, featuring stories about them and his career as a prominent orchestra leader.

title: An autobiographical sketch (1815-1842)
summary: A cryptic but eloquent account of Dana's education at Cambridge-Port grammar school, William Wells' boarding school, and Harvard College.

title: The journal of Richard Henry Dana, Jr.
publisher: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Prefaced by his 'Autobiographical Sketch,' this edition follows Dana's text as he wrote it, providing a wide assortment of historical data.

title: Signor Dottore: the autobiography of F. Michele Daniele, Italian immigrant doctor
summary: He settled in Youngstown, Ohio, to practice medicine in the Italian community and became an outspoken leader of the birth control movement.

title: Fatal flowers: on sin, sex, and suicide in the deep South
summary: A bitter, yet ambivalent analysis of Southern sexual mores in terms of her own life.

title: Life with the Lyons
summary: With good humor, actress Daniels and actor-producer Lyons recount their careers in films and family life.

title: White House witness, 1942-1945
summary: During World War II, wartime secrecy shrouded the White House, the key power center of the world. Daniels' diary tells what it was like to work in the hidden corridors of the President's office and captures the hopes, labors and intrigues of the Capital.

title: The Cabinet diaries of Josephus Daniels, 1913-1921
summary: Woodrow Wilson's Secretary of the Navy kept these diaries during his tenure of office from 1913 to 1921 (1914 and 1916 are missing). Through them can be seen Daniels' relations with the President, other government officials, and subordinates, including Franklin D. Roosevelt, chosen by Daniels as his assistant. Daniels was the subject of much controversy despite the success of the Navy during World War I.

title: Editor in politics
summary: Volume two of his memoirs describes his life from 1893 to 1912, when he was an editor and journalist becoming more involved with politics.

title: Shirt-sleeve diplomat
summary: The fifth volume of his autobiography, describing his years as U.S. Ambassador to the Republic of Mexico (1933-1942). Previously he had served as Secretary of the Navy (1913-1921). Shirt-sleeve diplomats contrast with stuffed shirt and spats diplomats.

title: Tar Heel editor
summary: The first volume of his memoirs, describing his life from 1885-1893, written by a journalist and statesman who was then editing a paper in North Carolina.

title: The Wilson era, years of peace — 1910-1917
summary: A personal memoir of the times, written by Wilson's Secretary of the Navy, with more detailed accounts of the era than of himself, although he calls it the third volume of his autobiography.

title: The Wilson era, years of war and after — 1917-1923
summary: Called the fourth volume of his autobiography, this work is, like the previous one, more a memoir of the times than of the man. This volume is based extensively on Daniels' World War I diary.

title: A tour from the city of New York, to Detroit in the Michigan territory, made between the 2nd of May and the 22nd of Sept. 1818
publisher: Published for the author by Kirk & Mercein
summary: A tour the author took observing the natural history and geography of the region around the southern shores of Lake Ontario and Lake Erie, including the Thousand Islands and Niagara Falls.

title: My safaris via inferno: life and thoughts of an Armenian-American lawyer
summary: A collection of sporadic memories and opinions written by a Detroit lawyer who immigrated to the U.S. from Turkey in 1912 as a young man.

title: When in doubt, fire the manager: my life and times in baseball
summary: After his career as a baseball player, Dark became a baseball manager, often hired and fired by such teams as the Kansas City Athletics and the Cleveland Indians. His zealous Christianity was compromised by family difficulties and an extramarital relationship of five years that eventually led to a second marriage.

title: A Hoosier parson: his boosts and bumps (an apologia pro mea vita)
summary: Individualist, sportsman, and Christian, Daugherty affirms his faith in an autobiography which is candid and friendly.

title: Duffy: an autobiography
summary: The well-loved coach of the Michigan State Spartans for nineteen years, who later became part of the ABC College Game of the Week team, recalls his successful career and tells tall tales of collegiate sports.

title: Chill yblast: a narrative
summary: Youth in rural Iowa; college professor of math at Iowa State Teachers College and Kansas State College; narrated in eighteenth-century comic style.

title: Too strong for fantasy
summary: Devoted to the world of music (her mother was opera star Alma Gluck) and of fiction writing, Davenport writes also of her support for Willkie's presidential campaign, her attachment to Czechoslovakia, and her admiration of the Masaryk Republic.

title: A Rhode Island chaplain in the Revolution: letters of Ebenezer David to Nicholas Brown, 1775-1778
summary: The author joined the Continental Army soon after his ordination and wrote these letters to Brown, a merchant in Providence. They describe the life and activities of an army chaplain of the time and contain valuable accounts of actions in which Rhode Island troops took part.

title: Transfigured: the autobiography of Solomon D. David
publisher: Disciples Divinity House of the University of Chicago
summary: In 1908 he immigrated to America from Syria to begin his education. He went first to Macalester College in Minneapolis, then on to medical school at the University of Minnesota. He established a practice as an orthopedic surgeon in Houston where he was also active in the Lebanese community. He published four books of Arabic poetry.

title: Bruce Davidson photographs: (including autobiographical sketch)
summary: Davidson's eloquent autobiographical introduction to this handsome collection of photographs representative of his life's work reveals the intimate interweaving of life and art.

title: The literary correspondence of Donald Davidson and Allen Tate
summary: This literary correspondence began when the two were apprentices to poetry and in 1922 agreed to exchange poems and criticism, resulting in a remarkable dialogue about the nature of the literary vocation.

title: The expedition of Capt. J.W. Davidson from Fort Tejon to the Owens Valley in 1859
summary: Army Captain Davidson describes the territory and the tribes he encountered, providing precise ethnographic and geographic notations, and discusses the expected establishment of an Indian reservation.

title: Reverend Samuel Davies abroad: the diary of a journey to England and Scotland, 1753-55
summary: Davies' journal chronicles a trip to England on behalf of American Presbyterians to solicit funds and support for the College of New Jersey and Presbyterians in Virginia.

title: With my mind on freedom: an autobiography
summary: In the late Sixties, Davis emerged as a central figure in revolutionary politics, focusing on political activism and personal experiences related to the Black Panther Party.

title: On my own
summary: Recounting the story of his youth, army experience, and the founding of his own public relations firm, Davis writes in simple language suitable for children.

title: Clive — inside the record business
summary: Davis focuses on his years with Columbia Records, discussing his role in the revolution of the record industry and his work with rock artists.

title: The age of indiscretion
summary: Reflections on his childhood and youth in Missouri and observations on how conditions have improved over fifty years.

title: By Elmer Davis
summary: This is a collection of fiction and essays by a news commentator who dared speak for individual freedom during the McCarthy era.

title: The world is my country
summary: Davis renounced his U.S. citizenship in Paris in 1948 and traveled worldwide, aiming to prove that an individual can obtain world legality based on freedom and justice.

title: World on my doorstep: a venture in international living
summary: Life in Geneva 1931-1941, while raising a family; revealing a deep concern for international peace.

title: World without a roof: an autobiography
summary: The international adventures of an explorer, writer, and combat soldier.

title: The messages and papers of Jefferson Davis and the Confederacy: including diplomatic correspondence, 1861-1865
summary: This work compiles and edits all messages, proclamations, and inaugural addresses of Jefferson Davis, as well as the diplomatic correspondence of the Confederacy.

title: The papers of Jefferson Davis
summary: Davis, the leader of the Confederacy, was blamed by both sides — by the South, because he failed, and by the North, because he tried to succeed. Later assessments recognized his unquestioned integrity, courage, dedication to duty, and strong leadership qualities. Volume I includes his autobiographical sketches, letters and other papers from 1808 to 1840; other volumes are forthcoming.

title: Private letters, 1823-1889
summary: This selection of private letters by the President of the Confederacy includes some previously printed, but a large proportion have not been printed before in their entirety.

title: A teacher's story: an autobiography
summary: A strict conservative moralist depicts the spiritual and professional achievements of his life as a teacher in Chicago.

title: A life adventure for peace: an autobiography
summary: Davis describes his life of social activism to promote peace, which took him to Russia and to the German death camps before World War II, and which led him to establish and subsidize Promoting Enduring Peace, Inc.

title: The saga of a schoolmaster; an autobiography
summary: Davis achieved eminence as an educator through talent, kindness, and extraordinary energy, providing a micro-history of American secondary education in the modern era.

title: Legacy of love
summary: Memories of life in an extended family surrounded by loving individualists including her grandparents and father, John W. Davis.

title: A surgeon's odyssey
summary: A wise, humane review of his medical practice and related experience by a man who became a neurological surgeon.

title: The neglected thread: a journal from the Calhoun Community, 1836-1842
summary: Diary of the early years of an educated writer gives an account of people and customs of the rural South and her feelings about them.

title: A narrative of the life of Rev. Noah Davis, a colored man: written by himself, at the age of fifty-four
summary: This narrative was written to raise money so that Davis could buy his last two children out of slavery, recounting his early slave life and multiple efforts to raise money for his family's freedom.

title: My first fifty years in the theatre
summary: In recounting many happy memories of his working life, the writer briefly lists his plays, producers, and casts over the years spent in New York and Hollywood.

title: Recollections of Mississippi and Mississippians
publisher: University and College Press of Mississippi
summary: Describes his prominent role in the development of the state of Mississippi before the Civil War.

title: The adventures and letters of Richard Harding Davis
summary: Davis reported for Philadelphia and New York newspapers and was particularly noteworthy for his accounts of six wars, including the Greco-Turkish War, the Spanish-American, and the first part of World War I.

title: Year from a reporter's notebook
summary: A journalist's notes on major international events from May 1896 to June 1897, including Czar Nicholas II's coronation and President McKinley's inauguration.

title: What?
summary: Written when he was over ninety, this book describes the long, successful career of a businessman who began his career in Marion, Ohio, and finally settled in Tulsa.

title: Yes I can: the story of Sammy Davis, Jr.
summary: After struggling many years to reach star status in show business, he was set back by a serious automobile accident and the loss of an eye, but still made top billing, overcoming racial prejudice along the way.

title: California Gold Rush merchant: the journal of Stephen Chapin Davis
summary: An interesting view of the Gold Rush by a seventeen-year-old merchant from New England (1850-1854).

title: Seventy-five years in California: recollections and remarks
summary: A human and mercantile history of San Francisco (1833-1906) from the lively and humanistic viewpoint of a civic-minded merchant.

title: Half remembered; a personal history
summary: A poet examines his life and his parents' gifts to him, remembering and unraveling the past.

title: Len Dawson: pressure quarterback
summary: Star quarterback for the Kansas City Chiefs (1963-69), he wrote his life story after he was accused of gambling connections.

title: Confederate girl's diary
summary: Written during her twenties, the diary is a lively and detailed record of her life in Louisiana during the Civil War.

title: Career in Cathay
summary: The book gives a lively and pleasant account of a missionary's extensive travels and relations with the host countries.

title: Doris Day: her own story
summary: Eighty percent of this volume is Doris Day's as-told-to account of her life, which focuses on her career as a movie actress and her prolonged unhappy marriage.

title: The long loneliness
summary: Raised an Episcopalian, she converted to Catholicism, became co-founder of the Catholic Worker.

title: Not without tears
summary: A Black Catholic convert describes her work as a nurse in Memphis at the Blessed Martin House of Hospitality.

title: Ghost waltz: a memoir
summary: An Austrian immigrant to New York explores her ambivalent attitudes toward Jews and her parents' native culture.

title: Day with the Giants
summary: An account of family life with Leo Durocher, a famous baseball personality.

title: Through Hell to Heaven
summary: Day, a Methodist minister in Wabash, Indiana, describes his serious injuries and struggles with depression following an automobile accident.

title: Pharisee among Philistines: the diary of Judge Matthew P. Deady, 1871-1892
summary: A robust account of a vigorous man intimately involved as a judge and state legislator in the development of Portland in particular and Oregon in general. The abundant appendixes following each chapter interpret the significant events and the judge's legal decisions, thereby providing a history of Portland as a supplement to the diary.

title: Blind ambition: the White House years
summary: With compelling and chilling detail, the counsel to President Nixon (1970-73) describes his role and the roles of other principals, including Haldeman, Ehrlichman, Colson, Magruder, Kleindienst, Mitchell, and Richard Nixon, in covering up the break-in at Democratic headquarters in Watergate during the 1972 campaign to reelect Nixon.

title: "Mo": a woman's view of Watergate
summary: "Mo" Dean's marriage to John Dean, counsel to President Nixon, began concurrently with the national trauma. Ignorant of any specific Watergate details until they were revealed in John's sworn testimony, she reflects on the stresses in their lives before, during, and after the break with the President over the illegal actions of many top members of Nixon's political team.

title: General Dean's story
summary: A major general in the United States Army recounts his days as a prisoner-of-war during the Korean War.

title: Butter at the old price: the autobiography of Marguerite DeAngeli
summary: DeAngeli, illustrator and author of many children's books, won the Newbery Prize for the book The Door in the Wall in 1950. Her story is full of warm memories of her family and friends.

title: Reminiscences of a vocal teacher
summary: Voice teacher in Cleveland for 24 years, she was well-known and respected in music and literary circles in the United States and Europe.

title: Speaking out
summary: The daughter of a Menominee Indian father and a white mother tells of her youth, education, and career in social work.

title: Out of my cabin
summary: The author, a schoolteacher, describes how she, her ailing mother, and intermittently invalid husband lived through the Depression in "Owl Center," a home they built on ten wooded acres in the Ozarks, near Neosho, Missouri.

title: Union officer in the Reconstruction
summary: An agent of the Freedman's Bureau in Greenville, South Carolina (1866-67), a young Union officer writes with compassion a first-hand account of whites and Blacks, Northerners and Southerners, the high-minded and the low-down in a country beggared by war.

title: Volunteer's adventures: a Union captain's record of the Civil War
summary: DeForest's outstanding record of camp life in letters mostly to his wife (1862-1864); the author of Miss Ravenel's Conversion (1865).

title: Father of radio: the autobiography of Lee DeForest
summary: Recollections of his personal life and long years of work in developing radio by electronic engineer and inventor.

title: Life among the doctors
summary: Scientist-writer chronicles ten years (1938-1948) of medical practice advances.

title: God, woman and ministry
summary: Demarest, granddaughter of Salvation Army founder William Booth, followed in her parents' and grandparents' evangelical footsteps and spent a vigorous lifetime preaching around the world.

title: And promenade home
summary: The story of her developing success as a dancer and choreographer and of her marriage to Walter Prude during the war years, 1942-1945.

title: Dance to the piper
summary: The story of an American dancer and choreographer from her youth and early career to the success of Oklahoma and her marriage.

title: Speak to me, dance with me
summary: Based on her diaries and correspondence, the book conveys the essence of her driving need to dance and the hardship involved in her struggle to become a successful artist.
